review: Hi: Newly disabled (use a cane presently) and at a loss for planning vacations for my family, all of whom eat vegan. Prefer domestic travel to start. Any recommendations?

Looking for accessible stuff to do in Charleston. We will be close to Daniel Island. We like the beaches, Looking to rent/use beach chair. What other cool stuff is accessible and avilable that tourists don‚Äôt know about?

My name is Mark. I am 51 years old Marine Veteran I got paralyzed from the Covid vaccine second shot on September 5, 2021. I had taken the second shot Moderna on September 3. At the time I was in peak shape. I was taking a shower, I put my head down I went numb from toe to neck. I initially could only move my head. Now, I can talk, move my arms, not fingers everything else paralyzed neck down, but I have a stand up wheelchair to get around and I bought a 50lb hoyer to travel with. Before paralyzation traveled 300 days a year for 10 plus years. Since I haven‚Äôt. I hope to start traveling this new year.

We‚Äôll be in Quito for 2 nights before heading home next week and would like to stay in the Historic District in a nice hotel. I‚Äôve been scouring the typical search sites (booking.com, kayak, Trivago, etc) and oddly none of them seem to have the filter (that I know I‚Äôve seen/used before) present for ‚Äúelevator‚Äù when searching Quito. Definitely in need of some 1st hand intel. Anywho‚Ä¶ I am in a wheelchair and although we can manage a flight of steps here or there, being that it‚Äôs at the end of our trip, it would be great to find somewhere with an elevator or ground floor rooms (and little to no other steps necessary to get into/around the building). Our max budget is around $130/nt. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

From a member of our community: I have a spinal cord injury where I can stand or sit for very limited amounts of time. In the past, I have bought 3 airline seats in order to lay down on certain routes, mainly Southwest, but wondering if anyone has advice here. Can anyone recommend domestic airlines that allow you to lay flat (probably only business or first class), or transportation companies you can hire for long rides where you can lay down? Thanks everyone!

Hi, I was recently put into a Powerchair/wheelchair and am traveling for the first time in years. Due to a mix up, no transport was set up for me to get from the airport (Reagan DCA) to the hotel (Yotel DC) and back again, after the stay. I‚Äôm traveling Oct 19, 2021 thru Oct 21, 2021. If anyone has any experience with this and /or could possibly suggest a company I could call to get this set up, it would be very much appreciated. I‚Äôve never used a wheelchair before (well, not all the time anyway) and am still getting used to it.I plan on using an overnight bag, as a carry on and will hold it in my lap. Looking for my owners manual, I think I might have to remove the batteries‚Ä¶but wanted to get this posted. üòä Thank you very much for any help!

The New Premier Caribbean Hotel for Wheelchair Accessible Travelers has now opened in St. Maarten The Morgan Resort & Spa - St Maarten Luxury ResortMy husband and I were lucky enough to get to be the very first wheelchair guests at the new Morgan Hotel this past May and we were in love at first sight. From the moment you arrive at the property you know you have arrived somewhere very special as you pass through two sets of gates and guard houses before reaching the glamorous front of the hotel; where the amazingly friendly valet/door-people will help you out of your vehicle. Whether it‚Äôs helping to assemble back your manual wheelchair or safely unloading a power wheelchair, the staff was obviously trained well as to how to best assist us wheeled travelers. (They will even help carry every last piece of equipment you may have traveled with; and we brought a lot)As you enter the glamorous but modestly sized lobby, you can‚Äôt help but take your eyes off of the giant, gorgeous infinity pool overlooking the ocean that‚Äôs just on the other side of the lobby(*Will come back to the pool in a sec). The amazing front desk staff and concierge will not only help you get checked in, but will personally escort you to your room to help orient you with the hotel amenities and make sure you have everything you need while settling in (ask for Arielle; she‚Äôs phenomenal). After taking some time to explore the giant accessible room and attached living room, I noticed how they remembered all the little details that are most important to us accessible travelers: lowered closets, electrical controls all within reach, access to the entire room; accessible bathroom with roll under sink, safety toilet (with good amount of grab bars), roll-in shower (flip down benches on order to replace shower chairs); handheld+waterfall shower heads; as well as having the coffee machine, safe and fridge within reachable zone.Honestly I was blown away by how much they got right with the room; especially after staying at some insane nightmare hotels in the caribbean that claimed to be accessible prior to booking the room. Whoever designed this hotel really took the time to plan out what was needed for their 9 (yes I said 9) accessible rooms and oceanfront suites. What impressed me even more, was the General Manager (Saul) took the time to sit down with us to get some feedback about how we were finding the accessible features of the hotel; and took the time to walk around the property and room with us and his builder to see what else could be improved on as they were finishing up the property. (Which was not much at all. Just some little stuff like a lower peep hole for the door, changing the bathroom door handle to add a few inches of entry area and changing from shower seats to benches for safety).Just like many hotels where we try to give some critical feedback on the accessibility of the property, they could have just humored us and pretended to care; but no, not these folks. They truly seem to be concerned about making the changes ASAP so that ALL guests get the chance to enjoy their property equally. That‚Äôs not something you find often in any hotel; let alone a hotel in the Carribean. They even are ordering some beach wheelchairs to use for the pool and maybe even the neighboring beaches. (They can even rent you a beach wheelchair from a local company to be able to take to the other beaches on the island who will bring the chair right to you at that beach and come back at the end of the day for it).Now speaking of their fabulous pool. Never in my life have I seen such a large pool with zero-degree entry going around the entire sides of this football field sized pool. (There is a regular entry point of the pool too if that‚Äôs easier). You‚Äôll never want to get out of this pool and you probably won‚Äôt need to since the fantastic pool staff bring you anything you need and the bar in the water will fulfill all your cocktail and food fantasies. What I loved was the fact they had these soft pool chairs surrounding the pool (1‚Äô away) that I could easily pull myself out of the water and right into the chair from. The only negative I will say about any of this is the fact that they put the hot tub in the middle of the pool with no other entry point and you have to go up stairs and down stairs to switch bodies of water. There also is a really cool swim in a cave in the corner with a built in waterslide; but no way to get to the top of the slide if your legs don‚Äôt work (not that my spine Dr. would appreciate me trying slides‚Ä¶lol).If you can drag yourself away from the pool, you must try the restaurant and bar. Chef David will BLOW YOUR MIND with his food. He hit it out of the park on his first try with the opening menu for the hotel. My spouse couldn‚Äôt stop raving about the Lobster and the Seafood Paella and I was obsessed with the vegetarian items on the menu; especially the Empanadas (They even serve an Impossible burger; which is so hard to find in St. Maarten). Every single thing we tried for breakfast was delicious and will fill you up well for your busy day on the island. Try the fruit and bread platter if you can or the pancakes will have you licking the plate. Or if you don;t feel like dining, try out the bar and let the Bartender Nigel make you one of his enticing cocktails (let alone he‚Äôs the nicest guy to talk to on the island).I wish I could list every single person who went out of their way to take care of our every need at the hotel; but it would add an entire page to this review. Let‚Äôs just say I can‚Äôt say one negative thing about any of the employees at the hotel. They all made us feel so welcome and treated us as if we were visiting their own home. Leaving was the most difficult part of our entire visit at the hotel. We spent two life changing weeks at the Morgan and tried out every aspect of that resort and they passed every test we threw at them. There are very few hotels I have ever fallen in love with, but this one definitely moved into my heart for life and I can‚Äôt wait to return. (Or move to the island‚Ä¶ that is how much they made us fall in love with St. Maarten here) Please trust me, you won‚Äôt be disappointed and you‚Äôve never enjoyed yourself more on vacation till you stay here. (You don‚Äôt even have to have a wheelchair to have as good of a time as us).

Hello everyone. My name is Diane Wildowsky and my friend and I have started a new website/blog helping people navigate NYC using a mobility scooter. I include wheelchairs where I can. I ride the subway and buses almost daily with my scooter. And while a restroom might be marked ‚Äúaccessible,‚Äù you learn very quickly, it isn‚Äôt always accessible for everyone. Look forward to meeting you all and happy to answer questions. Thank you in advance for taking time to look at our site. Paint the Town Mobile Paint the Town Mobile

If you do an extra special thank you.

Hello and good afternoon! My name is Karen and I am a 59 year old plus sized woman (currently 305 lbs coming down from originally being 430 lbs). I currently own a Pride Victory 10 mobility scooter because at the time I got it (5 years ago) that was the only mobility scooter Medicare would cover (at 80%) for a person weighing over 430 pounds. I would be very grateful on any advice/opinions any of you have on folding wheelchairs. Being as I have had my mobility scooter for quite a few years now, it is time to get something new again. Do I get another scooter, do I get a power wheelchair, or do I get one of those plus a folding wheelchair??? All decisions I need to make and would sure appreciate your input. I do not own and cannot afford to buy a vehicle with a lift (on SSDI with very limited income), so I got ADA certified and ride a paratransit bus that has a lift here in Phoenix, Az to my doctors appointments, pharmacy, etc‚Ä¶.The problem is I have no social life, or way to go out to do anything fun like out to dinner with friends, going to a mall, craft fairs, visit friends houses etc because paratransit will not take me to anywhere other than medically related places. I did not know about folding wheelchairs until just recently. It folds up, I can put it in the trunk of a friends vehicle, put it in the trunk of a Uber‚Ä¶..I could actually go places and do things again!! Plus just on a side note in case this helps someone else decide on a scooter‚Ä¶my Pride Victory 10 has been wonderful, very relaible, never a problem. However it is big, wide, heavy even broken down into pieces, and longer than most other scooters because it is a bariatric sized scooter as well. It for sure causes issues at times because of the turning radius, space in restaurants, it‚Äôs longer than most street vans with ramps up the back can usually fit. Allll of that being said (whew!!) what do you all think of FOLDING wheelchairs? It would still have to be for a plus sized me, so I would need a weight capacity over 305 lbs. Are they comfortable, relaible, can I even lift one by myself or would I need constant help to be able to use it by myself? Brand names you recommend and why?? Sorry for the book, I just wanted to tell you as much as I could so you could know what I would need better maybe??? Any information or suggestions would be very much appreciated. Thank you and have a great day! Karen

We finally went, we stayed for a whole week. My daughter with multiple disabilities, autism intellectually delayed and others had the best time of her life. What a super great birthday. What Disney World is handicap accessible however I did have a hard time navigating in Universal Studios. Definitely need two. Good pair of walking shoes day three red wheelchair and my oldest did push me around everywhere we went. The staff is very helpful. Very understanding and compassionate. The characters are very awesome with the kids and adults with disabilities, we stayed at the Drury Plaza Hotel in Orlando Disney Which we had a good time we had a blessed they have shadows to take you to and from all Disney theme parks and yes, it is very accessible for people in wheelchairs. They even ask you if you need the tamp down if they see you have issues with walking, they saw that I was blinding hand mobility issue so they asked if I wanted the wrap down even though I was not in a wheelchair no trouble airport they were very helpful. My daughter had a Great time my oldest had fun with the fast pass cus we didn‚Äôt have too wait in long lines lol going off peak season is great cus 1 less people 2 shorter lines for rides 3 just overall a lot better for people with disabilities, especially if they are autistic

I want to share info about a trip my husband & I just took to Texas. I have a Pride Baja scooter & several places we wanted to go were accessible for my scooter! We visited the Waco Mammoth National Monument & all the trails & the dig site were easy for me to navigate. Pretty exciting to see actual mammoth bones! We went to Cameron Park & there were many trails for my scooter & my husband‚Äôs bike. The bridge over the Brazos River was scooter friendly, too. We spent a couple days in Austin after leaving Waco. We stayed at the Lakeway Resort & Spa on Travis Lake. The room had a lovely view of the Lake & we even saw a doe & 2 fawns in the wilderness below our balcony. The bathroom was spacious & had a low tub with plenty of grab bars & a slide bar for the shower head. The only problem was that the bed was extra high, so somewhat difficult to get up onto. Lots of wide open spaces & a beautiful place. Visited Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center. The trails were either cemented or pea gravel. Lots of shady spots to get out of the sun if needed. The gift shop was large & spacious, plenty of room for scooter to navigate. Also hit the Roy & Ann Butler Hike & Bike Trail, a waterfront trail loop around Lady Bird Lake. It was also pavement & pea gravel all around. Hope this helps anyone with TX tourist ideas!üíô

My first trip after the amputation 2 years ago then a stroke in Feb 2023 was a solo trip to Bogota, I had never even been out of the country before and had just got my first passport,, I am Glad I chose Alaska and American Airlines, called their disability phone lines, they even moved my seats closer to the front even though they did not show available when I was picking my seats, I told them of my condition and that I was fearful of getting lost in the airports even though I gave myself 3 hour layovers, and living in the mountains most of my life,, they gate checked my chair so it was waiting at the next stop, they escort me to my next gate (via a train - another first) . they helped me thru customs on both ends and helped me transfer my bags and at the destination they got them at baggage claim took them to the hotel shuttle area and waited with me,, they were all Angels in my eyes. That was May 2023, since then I traveled to Texas and back and now less than 2 weeks from leaving to return to Colombia to spend the winter there for 6 months. My advice is get out there and Live and Enjoy yourself

My husband watched the 1956 Moby Dick with Gregory Peck and said ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs have a Moby Dick weekend in New Bedford‚Äù and we did. He is a full-time wheelchair user, only able to use his right side. We have recently ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù from Hoyer lift to slide board transfers wheelchair ‚Üê> bed, and that makes finding a hotel easier. It was a wonderful trip with no ‚Äúsurprises‚Äù. Hotel: Fairfield Inn at Marriott. ADA room with 2 queens. I called the hotel directly 2 days before arrival and Jaz at the front desk was very helpful. She measured top of bed height (24‚Äù) which made for a pretty level transfer. I explained that getting out of bed would require backing the wheelchair up to the headboard, so any nightstand must be movable. The left-hand bed did not have a nightstand on the left so that worked. I also asked for bathroom grab bars to be on the right, and she double checked that our room had that config. When we arrived, everything was as specified. My husband and I did not need assistance, but I saw our check-in person Mallory helping a couple with mobility issues load their bags on a dolly. Free breakfast was a better than average self-serve. I served my husband, but there was staff refilling food and I bet they would help someone if asked. Activities: Harbor-walk: beautiful, wide 1.5 mile walkway along the water. Made of large concrete sidewalk slabs and the transitions, while pretty good, were still painful for my husband. Whaling museum: A great museum. You could spend a whole day there. Roomy elevators to all floors, even the observation deck. The only thing inaccessible is climbing into the whaling ship model. I took the highlights tour (even though my husband chose not to) and it was also accessible. Fort Tabor: Lots of paved paths around the fort and by the water. Totally smooth sailing. Walking: Historic center roads are cobblestones, uncomfortable even in a car. Sidewalks are slate, which wasn‚Äôt too bad, and crosswalks are slate. I managed to find street or lot parking everywhere. I took a guided whaling themed walking tour for an hour while my husband sat on the whaling museum patio, but the walk covered just one city block and we did not enter buildings, so it would have been possible in a wheelchair. Restaurants:All were accessible and people went out of their way to be helpful. Antonio‚Äôs: They put out a ramp so the wheelchair could climb the one step to get in. There was room to navigate to a table. Tia Maria‚Äôs: We ate outdoors at a table. We loved the food and went twice. Lots of authentic Portuguese faire. Indoors would not be accessible. Black Whale: Large parking lot, easy ramp, lots of roomy table choices. Coastal Bubbles Wine Bar: On my walk I saw a lovely deck with the sign ‚ÄúSip, slurp, Sundays. Oysters $2‚Äù. The deck was up a flight of stairs, but the manager showed me that entering at the back of the restaurant was street level. Best oysters of the summer. Lovely fall weather and a great trip. I recommend it.
I‚Äôm flying to Colorado for a MS bike adventure. I have a scooter that folds up nicely. How do I put it on the plane? What do I need to do with the airline? Thanks for any help!

Hi guys - as a service, accessibleGO is currently focused on American/domestic travel, but I couldn‚Äôt resist sharing these very cool international travel opportunity that somebody shared with us recently. If any of you have ever had a safari on your bucket list, this might be a game-changer. üôÇ Ximuwu Lodge is a new, wheelchair-friendly lodge located in South Africa, on the border of Kruger National Park. Their representative describes their offering as: Our lodge, located in the greater kruger, is designed specifically to accommodate guests with mobility challenges, with a range of wheelchair-friendly features throughout the property. Our gameviewer, shuttle bus, bar, spa, photographic hides, boma, and all other amenities are fully accessible, ensuring that guests with mobility challenges can enjoy every aspect of their stay. In addition to being wheelchair-friendly, our lodge is also exclusive use, offering guests a private and luxurious experience that is unmatched in the region. We believe that this combination of accessibility and exclusivity makes our lodge an ideal choice for travelers who are looking for a unique and unforgettable experience. Thought you guys might appreciate! Sounds like an exciting experience.

I am Que. I have severe osteoarthritis in both hips and my right ankle due to a bizarre accident 50 years ago.I spent a year on crutches, with all my weight on my left leg, then another year using a cane. this was in 1974 and 1975. when the Pandemic started my Y closed and I didn‚Äôt keep up with my exercise routine.I have become increasingly disabled over the years, finding various helps when I needed them. I now use one ski walking pole and one Strong Arm. I am looking at getting either an electric wheelchair or a scooter for traveling as I am super slow when walking and my hip starts hurting after walking about a block. I understand from reading these posts that Viator has good accessible tours. are there accessible boat tours? the other times my wife and I have traveled in Europe we have taken boat tours of the canals and rivers but some of them were really hard for me to get to with one cane. I don‚Äôt think I could go down the stairs or clamber around a boat now.

Am a below knee amputee with prosthetic leg planning a cruise to the Antarctic. Am over 70 and active only need a walk-in shower in my cabin vs a full ADA cabin. Interested if any recommendations for a cruise line with excursions that I can manage. Will not walk on ice but can ride zodiacs. Like Silver Seas. Any suggestions?

I‚Äôm just back from a three week, six country vacation in Europe. As a person with a spinal cord injury who cannot stand/walk, the past 35 years of air travel has been extremely frustrating and sometimes physically painful. I always come home saying I never want to stop traveling, but I wish, just once, the air travel would go smoothly. Well this time was oh so close! Nearly as perfect as it could get. I fly United out of O‚ÄôHare a number of times per year. In comparing O‚ÄôHare against most of the European airports I‚Äôve been through, it has always provided the least attention to me as a wheelchair user. This time, something was different. More special treatment, a specific line at customs, and better trained personnel from the agents to the lift assistants. What, Finally?? It would have been an absolutely mind blowing experience had my chair been at the plane door when I arrived back in Chicago. The agent said I‚Äôd have to go to baggage claim to get it. Knowing my rights, I said my chair must be delivered to the door. (Ok, technically ‚Äúas close to the door as possible‚Äù). Funny, within literally seconds, my chair appeared. What? OK. That was it. The attendant wheeled me through the wheelchair line at customs and we were out the door. Just wanted to share. Hope this is the start of a trend. ü§û For the trip we flew into Amsterdam and out of Zurich. I splurged and hired a driver for the Netherlands and Belgium where we attended the Fomula 1 Dutch Grand Prix practice day and visited a few WWI & II memorial sites. I set up the hotels and sites on my own for this part of the trip. Then we made our way to France where we met some friends and hired the Claire & George Foundation (C&G)based in Bern Switzerland to drive us through Luxembourg, Germany, and Switzerland. C&G provided a driver, set up all accessible hotels, and any attraction and event tickets for us They even arranged a hoyer lift for me to be delivered to our hotels It was a wonderful, stress-free trip that included the Mosel Wine festival and a Champaign region tour I highly recommend C&G. They are easy to work with and can help plan the type of travel you like. Last year they set up a mostly train tour of Switzerland for us. After all the years of setting up my own travel, it was nice to have someone else do the work. Now, if they could only take care of those cobblestones‚Ä¶ Happy to share locations and hotels. Just ask. ~Wendy

Anyone here who flies frequently notice an increase in the number of passengers who are taking advantage the pre-board option? Especially on Southwest?I use wheelchair full time and always need to preboarder and use a aisle chair. If I am flying Southwest I can transfer directly from my chair to a seat in the front rows but only if they are not already occupied. The gate agents are always really good about getting me on first but there is always a line of at least ten other ‚Äúdisabled‚Äù people jockeying for position behind me and giving me dirty looks because I get to board first. What‚Äôs amazing is that the majority of them are all ambulatory and walk down the jetway without any assistance at all and when we get to our destination pop right up and sprint out the plane.Am I wrong in being totally annoyed with this or is it just my imagination that this seems to be happening more and more. I also fly other airlines that have assigned seats and I never see the number of pre-boarders that I do when I fly Southwest. I understand that there are a lot of peoples who need assistance to get through the terminals to the gates because of the distances involved but to then get preferential seating for no real reason seems wrong to me.

Last spring my mother and I traveled to Austria and Italy and took her new ATTO mobility scooter. It was fabulous. The scooter is FAA approved so you can take it on most airlines. It folds to the size of a carryon suitcase and has a travel cover (suit of armour) to protect it from harm. Assembly/disassembly takes about 1-2 minutes and it is VERY sturdy. Without ATTO Mom wouldn‚Äôt have been able to travel. Very highly recommended! You can find info about it at https://www.movinglife.com/. This is NOT an ad. I just really love this scooter and, as my own disability gets worse, I‚Äôm sure I will use it, too.

Title: From Healthcare to Travel‚ÄîStill Supporting the Disability Community üíô Hi everyone! My name is Laurel Grant, and I‚Äôm thrilled to be part of this amazing community. For over 25 years, I worked in the health field supporting individuals with disabilities. That experience shaped my heart and my purpose and it continues to guide me today. Now, I‚Äôve transitioned into a new chapter as a travel advisor , specializing in accessible vacations, group travel, and destination weddings. I‚Äôm passionate about helping people with disabilities explore the world with confidence, comfort, and joy. I‚Äôd love to stay connected with this community and continue being a resource for accessible travel. If you ever need help planning a trip or just want to chat about travel ideas, I‚Äôm here! üìß laurel.grant@onvigo.com üåê laurel.grant.onvigo.com üìû 1-866-341-5475 ext. 7844 Looking forward to learning from all of you and sharing what I can. üåç‚úàÔ∏è Warmly, Laurel

I would prefer to write a complete review of this hotel after my stay, but my experience with Hyatt while trying to make reservations has been nothing less than miserable. My husband and I are planning to attend a conference in July 2024 that will be held at the Hyatt Buffalo. After registering for the conference, I followed the instructions on the conference website and attempted to make reservations for two rooms at the special conference rate. I reserved both an accessible room with a roll-in shower for my husband and myself (an amputee and wheelchair user) and a standard room for my aide. While I had no problem making a reservation for my aide at the conference rate, I was told by the Hyatt reservation agent that I would be charged nearly double for the accessible room because there were no accessible rooms within the conference room block. I contacted one of the conference planners to request assistance in getting both rooms at the conference rate. During the contract process, he explained, the conference planners were told by Hyatt sales staff it was impossible to contract for accessible rooms as they needed to be made available to all Hyatt customers. While this is a nice thought, it is just not true. This conference, and others like it are held annually. It is the custom of the meeting planners to make sure that there are accessible rooms available within the room block as there is a large percentage of individuals with disabilities who attend the conference, and they require accessible rooms. Attendees of this conference in previous years are surveyed about their need for accessible rooms so the planners can ensure that an appropriate number of rooms are available in subsequent years. I contacted Hyatt Global Customer Care Center. I was told I could not have an accessible room at the conference rate as the room block was sold out. So why could I confirm a standard room for my aide at the conference rate? The practice of charging one rate for a standard room and a higher rate for an accessible room is blatant discrimination, and a violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and, I imagine, any number of state and federal laws designed to enhance interstate commerce and to prevent similar acts of prejudice. Hyatt Hotels should be ashamed.

I recently flew from Eugene Oregon to Seattle Washington on an Embraer ERJ 175 Alaska Airline in which I made reservations months in advance. Three days before I traveled I received a call confirming my power wheelchair and that it was to be gate checked and put in the only slot on the airline for power wheelchairs. Upon arrival at the airport, after checking in for my flight, I was told that my power wheelchair, which is 36 inches in total height, was too tall to fit on the aircraft. I have a tilt function, which I tilted back so that the hand grips were no higher than 33 inches, and was told that this was sufficient to fit on the aircraft. After we boarded and the plane was ready to take off, the cargo personnel came on the airplane to tell me that my power wheelchair would not fit on the airplane. I was told I had two options, one was to continue on with this flight and my power wheelchair would arrive with any luck later that evening as my destination was Washington DC and my second choice was I could be taken off the airplane yet there were no other flights out that day and they could not confirm there was even one the next day that could get us to Washington DC. I continue on with our travels and made it to Washington DC on the flights that we had reserved months in advance, and my power wheelchair arrived the next day at 11 AM. On return flight we have the similar plane from Seattle to Eugene and experienced the same problem, only this time my power wheelchair did not arrive at my home until a day and a half later. The bottom line is make sure that you do not fly with a power wheelchair that has a total height no greater than 33 inches on an Embraer ERJ 175 aircraft. Alaska airline I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs not the only airline that utilizes this style of airplane. So please do your homework so you do not experience the same headaches and disruption to your vacation that we did.

Hi, I'm Pam, a proud Disney Adult! I completed an internship at Walt Disney World through Disney University, worked there for a few years, and am now a religious vlog watcher and travel agent! You would think that I would've known all that there is to know about Walt Disney World with that resume, but it wasn't until I traveled with family and friends with disabilities that I learned first-hand about accessible travel. To me, being a true ally to the disabled community is learning from their lived experiences, so I am grateful that I now have this knowledge to pass on along with all of my other tips and tricks! Walt Disney World is beloved for many reasons, and one of those is its vast options of accessible activities. I recommend reading the descriptions of the rides online ahead of time to see which ones not only seem accessible for you, but are experiences that you would enjoy! Some rides you can stay in a power wheelchair, while others require a transfer. Some rides have specific seats for those needing to transfer. One example is the brand new Tron ride at Magic Kingdom. The standard seat looks similar to a motorcycle, but there is a "caboose" in the back that is an accessible seat. If you are capable of transferring, one thing that I learned is that when the cast members (workers) ask "can you transfer?" first ask "what are my options?" One example for this is the Jungle Cruise ride in Magic Kingdom. My friend said that she could transfer and she did. The steepness of the stairs getting into and out of the ride were more steep than she thought. My daughter and I ended up helping her quite a bit, which we were happy to do, but we found out after that there was an accessible boat where she could have stayed in a wheelchair! Another great option is the Disability Access Pass (DAS) which is intended for guests who have difficulty tolerating extended waits in a conventional queue environment due to a disability. This pass allows guests to request a return time for a specific experience that is comparable to the current standby wait. This feature permits guests using the DAS to enjoy other experiences in the park instead of physically waiting in the standby line. Guests can register in person or pre-register via live video call (the guest with a disability must be present) and use DAS Advance pre-arrival planning. It is most convenient to use the DAS on the My Disney Experience app which is available for smart phones. This app has so many great features. Besides the DAS, two that are very helpful are the listed updated wait times and the ability to pre-order quick service food. Speaking of planning ahead, while there are wheelchairs and mobility scooters available to rent (for a fee) at the parks, it is much more economical and efficient to rent through an outside company. When mobility aids are rented through the park, they have to stay in the park. Renting through an outside company allows you to take the wheelchair or scooter anywhere. Some of the resorts at Walt Disney World are huge, so the walk from the hotel to the bus could be very exhausting. A company called Scooterbug is the exclusive provider of mobility devices for Walt Disney World. This distinction is important because they can drop off the scooter at your resort without you being present. With the possibility of flight delays or other mishaps, this service offers great peace of mind. One thing that we learned when asking the front desk for my friend's scooter: if you book through an agent, the device could possibly be under their name. Mobility devices and scooters aren't the only pieces of equipment available for rent (from other companies - Scooterbug only offers wheelchairs, scooters, and strollers). One example for this is that my friend rented an IV pole for her feeding tube. While enjoying is priority number one, it is also a good idea to know the medical services available ahead of time just in case. AdventHealth is the official healthcare provider of Walt Disney World. They have medical equipment for rent, urgent care services, virtual appointments available 24/7, in-park first aid, and a new full-service emergency room minutes from Walt Disney World. While we never like to think about these things happening on vacation, knowing that these services are conveniently available and accessible provides peace of mind when travelling. Walt Disney World has accessible room options in all of their hotels. It is important to think about what you need ahead of time so that questions can be asked before booking the room. Some of these questions are the height of the bed and whether you need a powered door to get in and out of the room. Only you know what you need best! Working with a travel agent who has experience in accessible travel can also help you to brainstorm some questions specific to your needs. I could talk about Walt Disney World all day long! If you have any questions, let them in the comments below and I‚Äôm happy to answer. You can also search and book on accessible GO today!

My name is Danielle and I am a disabled content creator. My channels are called ‚ÄúDaniellevates‚Äù because the content is all about elevating ideas about disability and rare disease. Full-length vlogs feature accessibility reviews from my adventures in Boston and beyond.Short form content consists of series such as Breaking the 4th Wall of Disability, Accessible Design in the Wild, and more! Since birth, I have had an extremely rare technically undiagnosed neuromuscular disease. You can watch & subscribe to me here . This vlog is part two of a day trip from Boston to New York City, and the purpose of the trip was to see "Into the Woods" on Broadway! This vlog takes us from the outside of the St. James Theatre and to our seats. I now have my own mobility scooter, but during this trip I used a transport chair that I borrowed from my local senior center. While there are many aspects to having a disability that make life more difficult, we have to utilize the advantages when they come our way! Case in point: you can see our group receive the VIP treatment and skip the line to get into the theater safely. I was very pleasantly surprised by the proactive nature of the St. James Theatre. I selected an ADA seat for myself and an ADA companion seat for my friend, and they emailed me the night before to see if I would like to transfer into one of their seats or stay in my chair. When I indicated that I would be transferring, they said that they would store my chair and bring it back at intermission or anytime that I needed it. I would say that this email is not usual, so definitely plan ahead and ask any questions that you have ahead of time. For someone like myself, sitting in an ADA seat is a must. While I can do stairs with railings, they are draining and I am dependent on them having railings and not being too steep. Additionally, in an emergency, I would likely be one of the last ones out of the building anyways, so adding stairs as an obstacle is not a good idea. The show was amazing, and the rest of the video shows us dining in Times Square, our Amtrak train ride home (spoiler alert: half of us missed the train!), a recap of the trip and an awkward bathroom mishap, and a celebrity cameo from two comedy legends! Broadway lived up to the hype, and our little day trip was definitely chock-full of New York Moments. Key Takeaways If you need ADA seating for your health and safety, don't overthink it. Utilize these seats! Think of possible situations ahead of time (seating, bathroom, entering and exiting) and contact the theater with any questions. I should not have waited for them to contact me - this is a rare phenomenon in my experience! If a situation comes up that you didn't think of (like me wanting to get to my seat safely from the dense crowd), don't be afraid to ask for assistance. New York City is crowded. The streets aren't in good condition (I highlight this in part 1 of the NYC Vlogs). Plan ahead for what mobility aid you might need in these conditions. Make a list weeks before the show of what equipment and supplies that you will need. Add to this list whenever you think of something and pack your bag at least one day before. Once the show starts, be in the moment and enjoy! With all the traveling and hustle and bustle to just get to your seat, it can be hard to unwind. Let yourself take in your surroundings and immerse yourself in the show.

Hello All, my name is Sarah, and I am a multiple sclerosis survivor, mom, army military vet, and Paralyzed Veterans of America board member, so my hands are full. I love to ride my trike because multiple sclerosis is a move-it-or-lose disease, and I refuse to lose anything to the stinky disease. 15 years is long enough to know that MS is a one-star disease that should not be recommended to anybody, but my little boys are my world. I do anything for them, so I do everything I can for them, including camping and hiking and biking, and Team Mom-ing every sport they play. I strive to keep walking and dream of running again someday with the help of CIONIC sleeves (https://cionic.com/). The VA is putting on both my legs. With all the snow this year, I plan on celebrating my 40th birthday in Mammoth Mountain, learning to sit-ski as I used to be an avid snowboarder before my diagnosis in ‚Äò09.

From a community member: Hello, In my opinion, one of the most important problems in traveling for people with reduced mobility is the showers in the hotels. People who are paralyzed in the lower limbs, encounter very serious problems with showers that are not suitable for people who are paralyzed and cannot stand without aids. I just completed a very enjoyable cruise with my family from Anchorage to Vancouver but I must complain about their airline assistance department. I booked 3 staterooms including a suite for my son‚Äôs family and a cabin for my medical aide. We decided to let NCL provide air arrangements, transfer and overnight stay at the Anchorage Hilton for myself, my wife and my aide. The handicapped rooms with roll in shower do not have hand showers! The travel department put my aide on a separate flight from mine for the return journey. I called to change this and was told ‚Äúbecause she did not have the same booking number as my itinerary there was nothing that they could do until 10 days before the travel date‚Äù even though I said it was not possible for me to travel without my aide! I tried, unsuccessfully, to resolve this sooner but finally 10 days before the flight, the resolution department agreed to put her on my flight at an additional cost of $480 which I reluctantly agreed to. I then contacted Alaska Air handicapped assistance to have my seat move nearer the front of the plane since I require an aisle chair. There I was told I should never have been put on the Vancouver to Seattle leg of the trip because it was in Embraer 160 plane which is not allowed to carry lithium batteries even in the main cabin. I called NCL travel resolution who said I should have known that it‚Äôs on their website but I pointed out that depending on how you query the mobility section of your website you may or may not be shown the warnings about the Embraer planes. They then rerouted us via Air Canada to our Newark destination. I asked him for my $480 back but they refused.

I really appreciated this candid and loving conversation about traveling with a child who has autism: https://news.delta.com/accessibility-travel-customer-shares-perspective-traveling-autism When we travel, we encounter so many strangers - and this is such a nice reminder that you just never know somebody‚Äôs story and to be kind and patient, as much as you can. I particularly liked this exchange (from the piece linked above) with some practical tips on how to make travel easier: ‚ÄúAllison: Accessibility in travel has come a long way, but we know there is still work to be done. From your perspective, what improvements could Delta and the industry make to our processes that would help your family? Donna: I was once on a flight with a woman who discreetly handed out notecards to customers that said she had an autistic child with her and to please be patient. I thought it was such a great idea. I know customers can work with Reservations and Airport Customer Service to ensure crews are notified of someone traveling with an invisible disability who may need additional assistance before boarding ‚Äì I think others would benefit from knowing that too. [I‚Äôve often thought that] having a pin or lanyard on for employees who have some experience with autism would be a massive help. It would also serve as an identifier for customers. I can sit here and tell you all about what to do, but when you have someone who‚Äôs lived it and understands it, that makes a big difference.‚Äù

We have put together a day by day diary of experiences of travelling through New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, with a family member having a high level of mobility and medical needs. These have now been consolidated into an article which includes the planning aspects and some of the challenges which had to be overcome. It can be found by clicking this link https://www.enablemytrip.com/.../australia-road-trip-in-a... which is the introduction, or by clicking here https://www.enablemytrip.com/.../Australia-by-Wheelchair... which shows the full detail and includes the stopover in South Korea. We‚Äôve been trying to rent an accessible beach home and I came across this amazing nonprofit-a few things: you can request one of their floating wheelchairs as a family (For a day/week/extended vacation) here: https://smilemass.org/request-adapted-equipment/ list of new england beaches that have their chairs: https://smilemass.org/initiative/beach-wheelchairs/ and map here: https://www.google.com/maps/d/u/0/viewer?mid=11sjOQqOCx4A_zoqpaTzASfqPOyJuoE-D&ll=42.5125589880561%2C-71.68053459999999&z=7 Update-they look to also rent other adapative equipment/mobility tools like hoyer lifts, ramps, shower chairs etc here: https://smilemass.org/initiative/equipment-loaner-program/ your new england town beach can get one of their chairs! - here: https://smilemass.org/smile-mass-floating-beach-wheelchair-award/ you can rent their fully accessible beautiful looking literally right on the beach vacation home here: vrbo looks booked out (wonder if they book out like a year in advance)-we need so many more groups and options like this-for folks wanting a home rental versus hotel: https://smilemass.org/initiative/beach-house/ and https://www.vrbo.com/4982108ha?unitId=6200951 Update: Smile Mass partners with a family to rent out a second vacation rental from a SmileMass family (great initiative-again, should be a searchable home rental program :) ) in Lincoln, NH if anyone is interested: https://smilemass.org/initiative/new-hampshire-condo/ and sign up form: https://form.jotform.com/232824236035148 They also mention an accessible ski program on the Lincoln, NH webpage called NEDS I found this nonprofit when search for Mobi-mats (beach mats)-we really need a list of all beaches that have these-and found the floating chairs and then the smile mass nonprofit-so great! SmileMass has a great website ( https://smilemass.org/ ) with other programs, including a whole accessible local Club Smile Mass program/Community Within A Community they are currently creating in MA if of interest: https://smilemass.org/capital-campaign/
This will be my first time traveling with my personal scooter. Is there anything that I should be aware of, when traveling by plane? Are there guidelines at the airport? Thank you.

Considering train, which is the least expensive and fastest option, but am traveling with my wife and collectively we have 5 pieces of luggage. Experience w/ Italian/french train stations previously proved that local station staff and will facilitate boarding and seating, but space is very limited for baggage storage (above the seat space is nominal, and end of train car where there is a small open area for all passengers to place their baggage is small); security for baggage is non-existent unless you are literally standing on top of your property. Theft is too frequent to ignore this problem. If we were traveling light, I would have no problem with the train option. So what other options are there? Anyone know? I can fly (this involves, taxi to airport - plane - taxi to hotel + $$ + time) or hire a driver which appears to amount to $800+ one-way. Lastly, rent a car (I am not in wheelchair, but driving in Italian cities for a 78 yr. old is not optimal). Any suggestions would be appreciated. Recommendations of a driver or service more economical?

If anyone is a paraplegic or has other problems that prevent them from using their legs, I can recommend a hand cycle tour of The Netherlands. I did it this summer for 9 days with my wife pulling a ‚Äúbuggy‚Äù behind her bike that held my wheelchair. We used Holland Bike Tours led by Emiel Blok. You can find his website at this link: hollandbiketours.com Emiel put together a custom tour for us and had our luggage delivered to our next destination each day. It was a great trip. All the hotels and B&Bs were very wheelchair friendly. Attached is a few picture of us on the trip.

Just remember while in US the vendor must meet ADA requirements as to accessibility and you as a disabled traveler are entitled to things like accessible bathrooms, hotels, restaurants, attractions such as Disney. BUT, once you leave the geographical boundaries of US, you are no longer pritecby ADA. BEST ADVICE. - PLAN AHEAD Make arrangements early as possible before trip. Work with airlines, cruiselines, etc. Do your research of country you are planning to visit to see if similar law exists ir provisions that country or city has made. I found once we reached some downtown areas in Mexico the sidewalks have curb cuts at each intersection. I found out the hard way. Make sure you are dead center when going up the curb cut you are approaching fr the next block or you might tip over as I did in the waterfront street in Cozumel. There a half dozen Mexican men sitting on wall smoking but they hopped ss if shot from a cannon, checked on me and helped me stand up and they got my scooter upright. I then realized after granddaughter saw it that I busted center seam of a brand neecpsir of nice slacks from waist band to crotch. First and last time worn as once back in stateriomn l threw them away as fabric was ruined.

I have been asked to be one of the sites Travel Forum Experts and I must say that I am honored to be chosen to fill this role. A little about myself. I sustained a Spinal Cord Injury in an auto accident back in 1968 when I was four years old and have been using a manual wheelchair to get around ever since. My injury is at the T-12 level which basically means I am totally paralyzed from the waist down. I successfully completed my education up to the Masters degree level and have been working in the field of human services for most of my professional life. My wife and I live in a semi-rural area outside of Philadelphia Pennsylvania along with our two dogs. I have been lucky enough to be able to travel quite extensively both for leisure and business purposes and have been to a majority of the States in the US and several countries in Central and Northern Europe as well. We have also started cruising and have been on two so far and have one scheduled for April of this year. Bucket list for travel is Southern Europe, Hawaii and Asia, Please feel free to reach out to me with any questions you may have and I will do my best to answer them. Travel is an amazing thing and I hope everyone can experience it. Cheers!

Do you know of any hotels that have a bed low enough. I am in a wheelchair and am only 5 feet tall. The last two times I went to Albuquerque I was with another person and they were able to help me. We just visited the Hilton Resort in Quebec City in Canada after a great cruise. However the hotel is terrible for assessable needs. Even though their website promotes assessable, it is NOT assessable! The only thing included was wide door openings. There was no ADA higher toilet. It was extremely low as if designed for a child. There were no handrails around the toilet either. The shower did not have a chair to sit on. The shower had only one hold bar that was opposite the controls and was under the shower head. You could not reach the hold bar while standing by the water controls. We had reserved a one bedroom suite and the bed was so wide that you could not ride a wheelchair or rollator to move upward towards the headboard to get onto the bed itself! We were extremely disappointed in this hotel, especially when we were told that all their ‚Äúassessable‚Äù rooms were the same way. I guess Canada has a different attitude toward assessability. At least we would think that Hilton would understand and mandate their hotels to minimum standards. Use caution when reserving rooms in Canada!

Hi - Before covid and my ALS diagnosis, we used to travel quite a bit. Thankfully my disease is slow-progressing so I‚Äôd like to travel while I‚Äôm still able. From a community member: I would like to know where accessible RVs can be rented and purchased. I would greatly appreciate any suggestions or tips.

I‚Äôve been thinking of a few things that ease travel & thought I‚Äôd share in case others might find them handy. Backstory: Decades ago I temped a lady whose husband had left for work one day & vanished, gone without a trace; ~ 15 years ago I went on business trips with a colleague who gave me this tip; & I watch WAY too much true crime as I‚Äôm convinced that every solo foray leads to instant serial murder. Anyway, every time the coworker left her hotel room she made a brief note giving the time, date, destination, perhaps expected return. It wasn‚Äôt formal or elaborate, just a casual set of facts that would be invaluably helpful in trying to find her if she did in fact go missing. I don‚Äôt know if anyone else knew; it would be a good safety measure for almost anyone solo, no big deal, just a voice memo with dates & time erased on return or post-it by the phone or on the door that could be tossed on return, no need to involve others (could also add to dr. appt calendar to keep track of mundane things ‚Äî ~ how often to bank, hair color, drycleaner, neighbor‚Äôs dog running loose, whatever(

Just wanted to Say Hello and Introduce myself. I am Tanya and I am now an empty nester. I have fur babies also that are becoming my registered companions. This is a process but needed very much. I have been diagnosed with many ailments but Lupus and It‚Äôs Other sister dieases have become the Issue to my life and made me Disabled ten years ago. I woke with no available to move my legs or walk. that story is long one‚Ä¶ short version is I went from Wheelchair to auto scooter to two canes to one cane to none. but wish j had one from time to time. I fall often and Thank goodness for my Fur babies being there to help me up. Just want to thank you all for listening and know I am supporting you on your journey as well.Thanks for listening and getting to know me and Excited to get to know you all on here.Pain is strong but I am StrongerTanya

I have had 2 scooters, both Pride GoGo Elite Travelers, and they have had the same problem. They have times when they slow down and speed up, kind of jerky. So still in Louisville, KY. I rented a power chair at home in Rockville through a company called Cloud of Goods. I am here to tell you they are NOT good. I have had trouble with the rental from a company in Virginia since day one. Hey there! I‚Äôm Andrew Kurka! A partial Paraplegic and Alaskan! I broke my back when I was 13 in a ATV accident, I use a wheelchair and loftstrand crutches from enabling technologies. I travel the world regularly with team USA as a Paralympic alpine skier. I have experience in over 20 different countries and different traveling situations. I‚Äôm happy to be joining the AccessibleGO team as a representative and resource, if you have any questions. I also own a BnB in Alaska, I am a boat captain and a small plane pilot. I like to accept challenges. The way I see my disability, is like a challenge. Everyday I become better, because I overcome a new obstacle that my disability presents. So I‚Äôll never stop growing. My wife Veronica is my rock, from Guadalajara Mexico and makes sure to keep me grounded so I don‚Äôt push myself to far, to often. I‚Äôll be around tomorrow and available anytime if anyone has any travel questions! I‚Äôm happy to be a resource to help ease your mind and trouble when traveling! Chances are, I‚Äôve already been there and made those mistakes.

My name is Doris and I've been on the site for almost 3mths. Today I decided to make my 1st post. My husband was diagnosed with ALS almost 7 yrs ago and it definitely changed our lives. I have a family of 4, and sometimes more when travel with my granddaughter. I required the use of an wheelchair accessible room with a roll in shower. We also foster a young lady with Cerebral Palsy and Developmental disabilities that requires supervision and can‚Äôt be left alone. The challenge is finding an wheelchair accessible roll in shower room that will sleep.The second challenge is finding 2 rooms one being an accessible with roll in shower that sleeps 2 and a connecting room.The third and final challenge when traveling with our granddaughter or if our 13 year old wants to bring a friend is finding hotel lodging that meets all of our needs. As I all the major house projects are almost done and I‚Äôm nearing retirement I plan to travel more and just need lodging. We have went as far as renting entire houses and cabins to meet our needs. We also plan to try and travel abroad.I‚Äôm hopeful we are not alone in this struggleBe WellEd

I am thrilled to announce that WheelCraft Exclusive Concierge WAV Service has officially filed its Articles of Organization and is now an approved LLC! üéâ This milestone marks the beginning of a new chapter for WheelCraft, as we continue to striving to begin providing unparalleled concierge wheelchair-accessible vehicle (WAV) services to my valued community. My commitment to excellence in reliable, affordable accessibility remains at the forefront of everything I do and I am excited to enhance the future offerings even further. Being able to provide this service to our community, puts more of a emphasis on the idea of a service FOR US BY ONE OF US! Thank you for your ongoing support and I look forward to trying to serve the disability community, with even more dedication and innovation.

hi, i have a tip for wheelchair users visiting the UK-but its only useful for those of us with blow up wheels,not rubberised. ill tell you how i found this out, a few years ago, i was using a disabled forum and a user came on explaining that they despratly needed there wheels blowing up and they went into a car/ cycle etc type huge shop/store called HALFORDS. recently,i noticed my wheels were way to soft and low,but there was no leakage,and i typed out to my suport staff about remembering this persons comment from a few years ago. he said lets try it then,so we parked outside HALFORDS, he went in with my wheelie, and they were absolutely wonderful, they looked for the corect PSI first and then pumped them up, and he also noticed my breaks werent fixed properly so he sorted them out it only needed a bit of movemtn and the guy said come anytime you need it sorting, he woudnt take any money and that is the same lovely atittude the person i saw writing on the forum a few years ago. so ive thought,just in case any of you are ANYWHERE in the UK with a HALFORDS nearby, or even if you live here like me or know someone here it coud help-its worth going to unless your able to pump them yourself,i know a few people whove bought pumps from TEMU to do there wheels but i dont know how they turned out.i hope this helps. üôÇ

For my 60th birthday year, Chet and I took my dream trip to Japan. We journeyed as far north as Nikko National Park and as far south as Nagasaki. We saw ancient temples and shrines, wild monkeys, amazing forests, and interesting museums. We ate at 7 11, Family Mart and Lawson convenience stores, restaurants, and local markets. We dipped our toes in the Japan Sea, climbed sand dunes, and even rode a camel. We traveled in a Mini Wink camper van from Japan Campers for three weeks, driving up and down crazy mountain roads, driving through rice paddies, and in the city traffic of Toyoko and Osaka. We camped at Michi No Eki roadside stops and other stops recommended by the Japan Campers app. We hope you will join us on this trip of a lifetime. We had a blast, and I hope you will enjoy joining us through this video series. We also lightly discuss accessibility that we see in our journey. This episode starts our journey from Japan Campers Narita, Japan to Nikko National Park. We spent the morning traveling pass beautiful places including rice fields, forests, stream, and small towns, and spent the afternoon starting our exploration of Nikko National Park. We are Betsy and Chet, and our oldest son, Alex. For 33 years, we thought Alex, had nonverbal autism, intellectual disability, ADHD, but a few years ago we found out that he has Phelan McDermid. Alex goes on many trips with us, but this time the plane trip is too far. Part of the reason we make these videos is to share the world with Alex and others who are unable to make a journey to Japan. We have no idea what Alex understands receptively, so videos are a way to visually communicate where we went for three weeks. He likes to use his eye gaze communication device to watch his vacation videos so now in a way he can see Japan with us. Our videos, Goal 1: Joyful Life are based on our family's journey and strategies we use to improve the quality of our life through meaningful leisure experiences. It is our hope to reach our number one goal of having a joyful life and to help others reach that goal too. We are hoping that our videos will encourage everyone to get out and have fun.
