The accessibleGO community forum is where travelers with accessible needs gather to make new friends while they share tips, recommendations, and resources. Every day there are great conversations, and each week we‚Äôll share some of our favorite highlights. Question : Who are the best, most reliable REGIONAL accessible van rental companies? MobilityWorks was a big winner for our community. They offer regional rentals across the US. According to their website, ‚ÄúMobilityWorks offers wheelchair accessible van rentals to help you decide which accessible vehicle fits your needs. We also have wheelchair van rentals available to help you with occasional transportation needs ‚Äî locally or nationwide. You can rent for a day, a weekend, or longer.‚Äù Wdavidstone shares: ‚ÄúI have had a positive experience with MobilityWorks in Nashville, TN. I think they are probably the only option here. I talked to them in the past 2 weeks and they are currently totally booked for July. I have also had a positive experience in Atlanta with AMS Vans.‚Äù Charliemitts recommends: ‚ÄúWe recently used MobilityWorks in San Diego. Was a wonderful experience. They now have it set where you can pick and drop off at the airport. Mobility Works is s nationwide franchise that it is in most major cities. ‚Äú Patty Mayer also had a positive experience: ‚Äú MobilityWorks in San Diego CA has been very accommodating for us. Nice vans. Call ahead and reserve. They are currently trying to have their rentals right at the airport but had not been approved to do so as of April 1, 2023. We needed to get a wheelchair service to transport us to and from from airport to MW, which was very good but pricey on top of renting too.‚Äù United Access also got several votes. Jstorky1 shares: ‚ÄúUnited Access in Portland Oregon near the airport was good. I have been disappointed in the quality of vans we rented at Wheelers in Seattle. Got an old dented white van, my wife used the grab strap on the ceiling to get into the van and it pulled off and we had to pay for tge whole cost of repair. Some of the vans we rented in Maui had service lights lit up on the dash and bald tires. The proximity to the airport was the main reason we used Wheelers. They have pretty much a monopoly in Hawaii. I haven‚Äôt tried other companies in Seattle.‚Äù AMS Vans got a shout-out, as well. They serve the Atlanta Phoenix, Houston, Cincinnati, and New Jersey areas. Atlanta - 800-775-8267 As did Wheelers , who bill themselves as ‚ÄúYour go to resource for daily, weekly, weekend, and monthly handicap van rentals".‚Äù Is there a regional van rental service you‚Äôve used? Sound off in the comments below. We‚Äôll keep updating the list for all to use.

Looking for a travel companion. Must pay your own way. I live in kansas and have a electric wheel chair and hate to be alone. I‚Äôm a widower, live alone. And ready to get out out and about. Please get a hold of me if interested. Open to all parts of the country. Mark L.

We had originally planned a one night stay in Vienna on the way from Krakow to Munich. But we chose to leave Krakow early because of it was not for wheelchair users. We forgot to factor in that Vienna is super busy because of the Christmas markets there. So I went hunting for a hotel. Vienna was booked solid. I finally went to sleep at midnight with no reservations. I woke at 7 a.m. and checked again. There was a hotel, near the train station, that had an open room. I booked it and we departed Krakow. *Be sure to check carefully what train station you are arriving and departing from, there are many. We arrive and find the Prizeotel by Radisson about a block from the train station. Easy to walk to. It was clean, efficient, and very wheelchair friendly. The only bad thing I can say about it is that it didn‚Äôt have an in-room coffee maker, but you could buy some in the lobby. Bed height was perfect, the shower was amazing, the staff great, very reasonable compared to other hotels. For years Paris has been my favorite city. Move over Paris, with Vienna‚Äôs wheelchair accessible subway, trams and buses I think I have a new favorite. The architecture is stunning. The people were friendly. The museums were mostly accessible. The Christmas markets are each different and beautiful (also packed). We visited the Belvedere Place to see the Klimt exhibit and the Military museum. Mostly we wandered around muttering ooohhh, ahhhhh. As with all cities this old there was a hunt for food that I could access. It is there but our budget was taking a hit, again, so we often visited bakeries, groceries and at in our room. We went 48 hours before our train trip to Munich. We then reported 20 minutes ahead of our train and off we went. We had a connecting train in Salzburg that we missed because the staff in Vienna didn‚Äôt notify the Salzburg staff of the wheelchair. But we got on the next train even though they said all the wheelchair spaces were booked. We were ushered into a wheelchair space anyway and rode the rest of the way to Munich. ***I forgot to mention that we spent the last night in Motel One across the street from the train station. A wonderful choice for wheelchair users. Also reasonably priced. ***If you are ever in Vienna and the wheel breaks on your largest suitcase you can get it repaired at Taschendoktor, Stumpergasse 36, 1060 Wien, Austria. Ph +43 1 5978701. The owner said it would take a week but when my husband said we were gone in 3 days he had it ready in 2 days. A 50 euro hit but much less than the cost of a new bag.

Last week, the Minneapolis- St. Paul International Airport, in conjunction with Delta Airlines, opened a new mock airplane cabin for people with cognitive, psychological and physical disabilities and for trainers of service animals in order to provide an experience of what it feels like to fly. The mock cabin is called the MSP Travel Confidently Education Center and is the latest part of the airport‚Äôs Navigating MSP program, which helps travelers with disabilities. Thanks to our partner Open Doors Organization in Chicago for sharing this great information! ODO is an active member of the MSP Travelers with Disabilities Advisory Committee. We‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on this new mock airplane cabin- is this something that you would benefit from? Have you ever tried a mock cabin before? Photo credit: Open Doors Organization

I currently live in IL. I work in healthcare, am 50 yrs old, and diagnosed with a slow progressing form of ALS(PLS) at 46. I‚Äôve been a traveler my entire life. I‚Äôve lived in several states across the US and have visited 4 of the 7 continents. I use a power chair 80% of the time and use a walker in my home and sometimes at work. I joined this group because I have 3 continents to go and I also travel some for work. As many have mentioned, accessible is defined differently and it‚Äôs frustrating to have to ask so many questions to ensure you are on the same page with the hotel, airline, or venue. I am looking forward to searching the various topics to gain insight on my next adventure. Best wishes to all!
Bryson City If you are looking for a smokey mountain getaway that is accessible, try Bryson city. Wife and I found it easily navigable. Friendly and the gsmr was hc accessible

Today in Barcelona I saw the most amazing accessibility invention. I have wanted to shop but many stores have steps going into them. I was bummed. I went in becaused a sign said it was accessible. People sitting on the stairs got up and moved. The stairs actually collapsed into a flat lift when a button is pushed. I‚Äôll try to post a picture, I hope it works.

This morning I went on a fantastic snorkel trip out of Kona Hawaii. The boat was wheelchair accessible, the staff super nice and helpful, the fish beautiful. The company‚Äôs name was Body Glove. They have numerous water devices if you prefer not to actually snorkel. Ok, I didn‚Äôt use the stand up paddle board as a RAKA, lol. The boat has stairs (not a ladder) down into the water so I could easily access in and out of the water using my butt. FUN!

Hello! We will be traveling to Orlando soon to get my son a service dog from Canine Companions. We are planning on dividing the trip in to 2 days. We are looking for an accessible hotel around Valdosta Georgia. Does anyone have any recommendations? Heather Hooper

Bed height has become a major stressor in my travel. Height of the bed used to never be an issue. My major concern was a flip down shower bench in the shower. I don‚Äôt travel a great deal so I‚Äôm not really sure when this happened. The last hotel I stayed at was a bad experience. I had sent a picture showing a yardstick and the 26" height of my home mattress and my knee right next to it while seated in my manual chair. When I arrived, hotel mattress was way too tall, had a very cushy top and some kind of side board frame that kept me from getting right up next to the mattress to transfer‚Ä¶ NOT good. I called to have it lowered and they basically put the mattress on the floor. Again, NOT good. They finally ended up with the mattress on some type of plastic crates. Closer to right height but side rail and cushy top still made transfer very awkward and very stressful since I was traveling alone. Any hopes of getting a standardized height for beds?

PRIOR TO ARRIVAL There were multiple contact points prior to our arrival. I was booking 3 rooms for 3 families. At the suggestion of the reservation agent, I booked 3 individual rooms: a Spa Studio 1 king, a Spa Studio 2 queens and 1 bedroom Spa Villa Suite. I explained to the agent that for the Villa Suite I needed some handicap accommodations. Basically, I need a shower chair, adjustable shower & elevated toilet with grab bars. I called multiple times to confirm that these accommodations were doable. the room. No one mentioned stairs to get to the spa studios until about a week prior to our stay. HANDICAP PARKING There was no handicap parking near our room. The curb to the parking area is not wheelchair or cane friendly. In order to avoid a dangerous fall, my husband had to leave me sitting in a wheelchair at the curb, & then drive onto the sidewalk to pick me up or let me out. When I inquired about a handicap space, no one seemed to have an answer. Training for the front desk & operators may be helpful. DISABLED ROOM After check in, they finally brought in a shower chair, but no shower mat. This is a huge fall risk for any guest. There are no bars in the shower & the shower head does not come down. The toilet riser was very loose & unsafe to use, & was delivered late. If you sat down the item would move out of place. This is a massive fall hazard. When I made the reservation I explained exactly what I needed in a hotel room; bars by the toilet, raised toilet, a portable shower chair, bars in the shower, but not necessarily an ADA room. We had to wait for shower mats, shower chair and toilet riser with arms. DANGEROUS GROUNDS The property is not handicap friendly! Or even safe for a disabled person. The property is very poorly lit & there are many areas with over grown brush & uneven pavement that made it difficult & dangerous to maneuver with a wheelchair or cane. There were multiple areas where a wheelchair could not get by. I sent this in writing to the Director, it is now 9 months later and he has yet to contact me. He keeps saying he wants to connect with me. Any of these areas of concern are fixable I let him know that I preferred to settle the situation directly with the property rather than write a totally negative review. He obviously does not care his guest's safety.

My husband and I were taking a quick trip to Washing DC over Labor Day. We decided to try a more central hotel than our usual. I found The Sofitel at a great rate through accessibleGO. When I went to book it the wheelchair accessible room was already booked up. Being a nice hotel I figured a regular room would do. Thanks to Patch for going above and beyond I got into the wheelchair accessible room. I have to say in all my travels I have never seen a truly luxury accessible room until now. I messed up my camera so no pictures. There was enough room to get in, turn, park the chair for recharging. A nice loveseat area to relax. The bathroom was one to dream about. There was a bathtub with all of the rails and such. I couldn‚Äôt use it but hubby had a good hot soak. There were 2, yes 2 showers! Mine was a spacious roll-in with adjustable shower heights and hand held fixtures. The other was a standard with all the same fixtures and a rainfall showerhead. Check in was fast and super friendly. The attached restaurant was very nice. One of our favorite things was the valet service. Such a classy, professional and happy group. To haul my wheelchairs we have a very large truck. When we drove in the valet said that they couldn‚Äôt park it in the garage as it was too big. These guys kept it parked out on the street. They moved it around as needed and we had constant access to it. It wasn‚Äôt cheap but worth every penny. The Sofitel is very close to the White House, restaurants galore, theaters.

Hi - my family and I are planning a trip to Barcelona in September. I can walk very short distances but otherwise use a foldable powered wheelchair. Does anyone have information about renting a powered wheelchair in Barcelona in case mine gets damaged on the flight heading over there OR during our stay? Damage to my wheelchair is what gives me the most anxiety about traveling. Any tips about battery charging in Spain also welcome! For ex., what sort of adapter should we bring?
I just did 2 rooms, same hotel, same beds, one handicap and one not. Mine is $10 more. Frustrating.

The train ride from Interlaken, Switzerland to Milan was fast and efficient. We wanted a certain route but they told us at the station that that train was not suited for wheelchairs. So we went back through Zurich and down to Milan. The thing I noticed about the trains in Italy were that they were mostly lower. The helper at the station would carry a roll-up ramp and lay it down to cover the gap. If I could add to my luggage pile, without losing a husband, I would love one of my own. Milan is a big city. This was our splurge stopover. We used the Hotel Korner Duomo. It was beautiful. It had the biggest pain in the behind elevator I have ever seen. But the room made up for it. We were literally around the corner from the Galleria and Duomo. We walked across to the Monument Cemetery which was jaw dropping. We did little but wander the streets oooing and ahhhing. We found a little restaurant near the Galleria(Marinos) and ate there every day. They treated us like neighbors. On my birthday (even planners can screw up now and then) we took the train to the Malpensa Airport for the night. We flew to Madrid the next day. Cobblestones are a real pain when in a chair. But I loved all the marble walkways in the shopping areas.

Hi Everyone, we have a community member with the following question, can you help? We will be spending 2-4 days in Vancouver in June. Can anyone recommend an ADA 4-star hotel with a walk in shower, hand rails, elevator, etc. ? What kind of transportation is available for a collapsible scooter user, to see the sites? What tourist sites do not involve many stairs, unstable ground, cobblestones or grass or sand? Thank you!

I have gone to Barbados in the past and most transportation services want up to $80.00 per hour for accessible transportation. They mostly get the tourist that want to see the sights and tourist traps but I just want to go to and from the airport and maybe to Ositins, to partake in a fish fry without having to pay almost $500.00. An accessible van is NOT a must, as I can lift and assist my wife in a regular van or mid-size car.
Hoping to make a trip to Honolulu in a year or two. I have a folding electric wheelchair to take along. How do I find a 2 bedroom condo or home to rent that is ADA rated? Any suggestions? Thanks!

Alaska is the last frontier, a wild, cold and crazy place with huge animals and insane weather‚ÄìBut it is also where I am from. It‚Äôs my home, and it is a large wild home, where exploration is a must, and the outdoors is part of life. Alaska is also concealed from the rest of the world. Blocked off by miles of ocean unless you want to drive for 4 days through Canada. Travel has to be by flight, and when you‚Äôre going to fly for 6 hours to get anywhere else, you might as well fly for 12 hours. So when I travel the world, I go far‚Äìto the warmest, most adventurous places I can find. Ôªø Ôªø I‚Äôm Andrew Kurka, an Alaskan and an Athlete on the US Paralympic Ski Team. I also like to think of myself as somewhat of an explorer. An explorer that is always looking for new and better ways to travel. Being an Alaskan, everyday life isn‚Äôt the most accessible. So I found ways, to adapt, to overcome, to continue doing the things I love to do. The hardest part was accepting my differences and my disability, realizing that I could do anything, I just had to do it differently. Then finding those that would support me in those endeavors.. The world isn‚Äôt built for us, and adapting can be hard. The more streamlined the better. That‚Äôs why I am excited to join the accessibleGO team. accessibleGO helps those who are freshly disabled or have had lifelong disabilities, travel with confidence and enjoy themselves on the GO, wherever that may be. Ôªø Ôªø I broke my back when I was 13 in an ATV accident. Prior to the injury I was a wrestler and avid outdoorsman, a hunter, a fisherman. But the things I miss the most about having legs that work, was the freedom, the freedom of being able to just walk outside and GO. Hike this hill, or ski that mountain. When my legs were taken from me, so was a portion of my life, and a portion of my identity. The athlete that was an awesome wrestler, the boy that would bike miles just to find a fishing spot. That person felt taken. For years I had tied my identity to the person who was built around these things, and then they were taken away. I struggled for two years, a young man lost. Alaska isn‚Äôt built for the disabled, we have pretty typical ADA standards but they aren‚Äôt typically met, especially in the winter time. Alaska, it‚Äôs wild! It‚Äôs the outdoors, and the outdoors isn‚Äôt built for us. It‚Äôs the best part about Alaska, but also the hardest part of being disabled. I struggled with these facts, trying to accept the things I loved. Ôªø Ôªø Then, when I was 15, I was nominated to be the Children‚Äôs Miracle Network Spokesman for Alaska. I traveled and met lots of other children with disabilities, learned their life stories and was inspired. I met a young man with terminal cancer who especially changed my life. He was 7 years old, but wanted to see and experience everything. He didn‚Äôt know how much time he had left, and he was completely aware of that fact. He just looked death in the eyes as if to say, ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre coming for me, but I‚Äôll make you work for it.‚Äù He was mature for his age, which was scary for me. I was 15, but he seemed like more of an adult. But he also didn‚Äôt have any fear, after all what did he have to lose? What did he do to deserve this? Nothing, but he was determined to at least give it his best shot at the life he was given. After meeting this young man, I sat down, and thought about my life. What was I even doing here? Why was I worried about who I used to be, why was I worried about my legs? Why was I sulking in the thoughts of the person I used to be? Instead of living the life of a fearless human that strives to at least experience what he can, while he can. That was when I started trying new things. Instead of focusing on the things that I used to do. I said, what can I do now? Or how can I do this? I started adapting, and in the process. I started living, I started skiing, I started playing hockey, I even started wrestling again. I started fishing, kayaking, hunting, canoeing. I started living life, I began my journey molding my life to my dreams. Seeking the experiences of a lifetime. Though they were done differently, I still did them. I pursued experiences in life and in the outdoors, in every way I could, hoping that it would one day provide me with the means of helping others, like that young man helped me. Ôªø Ôªø Today I own a Bed and Breakfast in Alaska, with multiple ADA accessible cabins, nested on an airstrip. I am working toward finishing my pilot license, I own a saltwater fishing vessel and have adapted my life to what I enjoy. I figured out how to do things with a disability. I am setting my life up so that I can do adventure camps, sharing that mindset and that freedom I have acquired with others. Ôªø Ôªø Andrew with his wife.While I still travel the world on the US Paralympic Ski Team, I am constantly learning to adapt to new situations and travel experiences. I know nothing is perfect but finding the best way to make things work is what I live for. Life will never be easy, but I‚Äôll always remain willing to work hard and try. I have had a successful career as a skier. I have received a few paralympic medals and I have been crowned one of the fastest in the world. Yet I continue to pursue another Gold at the Paralympic Games while giving my all, to my business and my life. My journeys haven‚Äôt been without consequences, I have broken over 20 bones in my 31 years. But I will continue to push forward, living a fearless life and I hope you will too, in your own way.Ôªø Ôªø This is who I am, it is my life, my goals and my dreams. It is the reason why accessibleGO and I have decided to create a partnership. So that we may help to inspire others. So that we can help answer questions that people may be unsure about. We can help make people with disabilities more comfortable away from home. So I can be an example and show you what I have made possible in my life. So that you may also do the same in yours. AccessibleGO can help people realize their possibilities and make those goals easier for them. Not to hold your hand, but to simply help you live the life you‚Äôve dreamed of, filled with experiences, travel, and fun. Those objectives are what we partnered over. The fact that I live and experience everything I can, and we want that to be possible and comfortable for anyone with a disability. Sometimes it‚Äôs all about making one person smile, helping them to do that one thing they never thought they would experience again. Or at least giving them that opportunity. Because we should all strive to live and not to merely exist.

We received this question from a community member: Is there an accessible way to visit Yellowstone National Park? This community forum is the heart of accessibleGO, a hotel booking site for travelers with disabilities. Our mission is to make sure travel is accessible and easy for all. Book your next trip with us.

(Advisory: Although this tour is willing to work with people of all abilities, it is still necessary for safety reasons that participants have strong grip capabilities with hands and arms, no neck issues, and strong swimming skills.) A few years ago when Covid restrictions first started to lift, I grabbed my husband and caught the first flight to Sint Maarten Island that we could get on. When we arrived, we practically had the island to ourselves when it came to tourists and found that tour guides were more than willing to work with me and my physical disabilities since they didn‚Äôt have to focus on large tour groups. However the one tour I wasn‚Äôt able to convince to work with me, was the new tours being offered using Sea Bob‚Äôs. (For people who are unfamiliar with what Sea Bob‚Äôs are, imagine a hand held jet ski engine that allows divers and snorkelers to fly over or under the water‚Äôs surface at speeds that match. Here is a link with more information.) You can‚Äôt imagine how angry that made me. My biggest pet peeve is when people make assumptions about what we are capable of. That is something we like to determine for ourselves. So when we got home, I started working on planning our next set of excursions for an upcoming cruise we had booked that was going to be stopping in Aruba. Usually when we visit Aruba just for a day, I always book us on a Motorcycle-Trike* tour that also loves to work with people of all abilities (that is another review I am working on); but I noticed a company, SeaBob Aruba, also offering SeaBob tours and I thought I would make my pitch to them to see about including me in the tour. Not only were they willing to work with me, they started explaining to me how they are very used to working with people of all abilities and would love to have us on the tour. I was so excited, even though the tour was still 7 months away. The day finally arrived when we docked in Aruba and I had my dream day ahead of me; a motorcycle tour all morning and Sea Bob‚Äôs all afternoon. The tour company met us right outside the dock and arranged a safe spot for me to load into the car and they were able to fit my entire wheelchair in the back of the van. Lucky for us that we were the only two people booked for the afternoon and ended up with a private tour. After a fast stop to pick up the trailer with the gear, we headed to the beach spot and our tour guides did a tutorial for us about how the equipment worked and how to use it safely in the water; while I worked to get my wetsuit gear on. Once I was ready, the incredibly strong tour guides lifted me up in their arms and carried me safely all the way to the water and carefully set me down and my husband joined us in the water. Once I am in the water I am a strong enough swimmer that I am ok without an aide; but my wetsuit does keep me floating at the surface. We were given our Sea-Bob‚Äôs and offered some time to familiarize ourselves with using the devices in the shallower water. As soon as we gave the cue we were feeling good with it, we headed out towards the sunken ship off-shore. On the way out, I took the chance to use the device under the water at top speeds and felt like Aquaman soaring under the water. The only downside was you can only stay under the water for as long as your breath lasts because we weren‚Äôt using any breathing apparatus. However this device is also used by scuba divers, so they can be used underwater for extended times if you had the correct equipment. On the way out, the guides pointed out some large turtles under us and I was able to swim right over them. After a few minutes of soaring through the water, our tour guides informed us we had reached the ship. They did forget to mention what type of ship, so I was a little overwhelmed when you look down and see a sunken WWII German warship that was HUGE and cracked in half. Plus everything always looks bigger under the water with your mask on. Once I finally got used to looking down at it, we took turns trying to fly down near it, but it was too deep for my husband and I to get too. Instead though, we were entertained by our tour guides who showed off their underwater superpowers and performed magic flying in and around the ship for the longest time. Was so cool watch and gave me fantasies of someday having that kind of breath control. When we were done exploring the ship, we headed back to an area more known for more large turtles and underwater sea life. This time when we spotted another giant turtle, I managed to swim right next to them for quite awhile. When I started to realize they were not comfortable with the Sea Bobs, I backed off and gave it more space. As we got closer to the reefs, so many fish started showing up that I thought I was in a musical number from the Little Mermaid. I only wish I knew the names of what I was seeing to tell you what was down there, but it was AMAZING! Before I knew it, the time had expired and it was time to head back to the beach. It was so sad having to head back, because my adrenaline was pumping so high from getting to experience all of that. Beyond how cool the Sea Bob experience was, there is something about accomplishing a task that someone else said you were incapable of that gives you this high about being alive and for just that brief moment in time, I have a feeling like I am capable of anything. These magical Seabob devices gave me the ability to reach areas above and under the water that I would have never been able to reach on my own due to my legs not kicking anymore‚Ä¶ so I was in love. Plus these tour guides never doubted me and let me try everything without any hesitations, giving me that brief moment where I didn‚Äôt have to feel like I stood out with my disabilities. I wish I could explain how good of a feeling that is (to me at least), but as the guides carried me out of the water and back to the van to de-wetsuit; I was overwhelmed and didn‚Äôt know if I wanted to cry or just grin because I was so happy. They were just lucky it was too far for me to summersault back to the waters edge or I would have been back on that SeaBob for another lap around the bay. I forgot to mention that they do offer a photo package that was very reasonable and then you get a ton of photos and movies sent to you digitally that is so much easier than trying to photograph yourself at the same time you‚Äôre trying to control the Bob. However it might be interesting to also attach your own go-pro strapped to your head for a first-person perspective, but I warn you that you go much faster than you can imagine under the water and not sure if it will stay attached? But definitely get the package because they capture all of the great moments with you in them, not just what you saw happening. To me, this was the most perfect day of activities on an island I could fathom for myself. I got to fly above in the morning on the Trike; and then flew below with the Bob in the afternoon. There was so much adrenaline pumping that I was awake all night just glowing (don‚Äôt worry, it wasn‚Äôt a sunburn). Not only was the Sea Bob tour amazing itself, working with a company like SeaBob Aruba that understands that people with all types of physical abilities can do way more than we are ever given credit for; meant everything to me. The tour guides were phenomenal as tour guides and as human beings. Felt like we had also made new friends that day too**. So now I have 2 things that I always HAVE to do when I get to Aruba, but I think the Sea-Bob‚Äôs have secured my #1 spot. **(And to help my tour guide who could not stop whistling a song he couldn‚Äôt remember the name or lyrics to; it was Scorpions doing ‚ÄúWind of Change.‚Äù I hope that helps?) üèç Trike Tour Review Coming soon üèç

Greetings - my gf and I will be traveling through South America for the last 3 weeks of April. She is able-bodied and I am c5 quadriplegic that can walk with crutches for short distances/durations (like down the aisle of an airplane). We‚Äôve traveled extensively in USA, with a bit of Europe and the Caribbean as well. However I believe this will be quite different because for all of that past travel, we‚Äôve always flown one of the major airlines here (American Airlines, Delta, United, Southwest, etc) and on these airlines the policy is pretty much the same across the board: I‚Äôm able to remain in my wheelchair and check it right at the gate I‚Äôm allowed to bring a carry-on bag containing medical supplies in addition to whatever the standard cary-on allowance for that specific airline and class of ticket I‚Äôm allowed to carry on yet another bag containing my Freewheel (and its parts), which is essentially a 3rd wheel that attaches to my wheelchair allowing me to navigate some rougher terrain ‚Ä¶all this for no additional charge. I‚Äôm starting to get concerned as we look at flights between countries within South America (ex Ecuador to Argentina) and also flights with the same countries. What I‚Äôve been seeing is some pretty high costs for standard carry-on as well as checked baggage and not much more information on what I‚Äôm allowed to bring (paid for or not) medical supplies/equipment-wise. Does anyone know if there is a standard policy in place of any sort with respect to this in South America? Anyone who has done any traveling in South America, any anecdotes to share that might give me an idea of what to expect? Or other tips?
If members who are interested in accessible travel are on LinkedIn, I would like to recommend three people to follow:Roberto Castiglioni MBEChristopher Wood MBEAntti Suopaj√§rviThanks.

I‚Äôve had bone-on-bone osteoarthritis in both hips since 2018 and have cardiac issues including a mechanical aortic valve, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter. Doctors won‚Äôt approve hip replacements because of the heart conditions. Nonetheless, I‚Äôm a young 69 y/o and I love getting out and traveling. I‚Äôm in Indiana and short trips are easy but few buildings are accessible here. I can load my portable chair into my car with a lift and make it to art class, aquatics and local restaurants. My next project is flying alone to Portland OR for a family get-together. Any help on finding accessible places that are really accessible is much appreciated. My granddaughter is getting married in a few weeks. She and her future hubs reserved a block of rooms at the Marriott Detroit at the Renaissance Center. When they arranged for the rooms, they provided their contact person with our specific needs, i.e. a mobility handicapped room for one person (son, 34) with a connecting or adjoining room for 2, so we can assist our son as needed. The reservations clerk took note of the wedding party and seemed very competent. When I received email confirmation after the rooms were booked, the following note was at the bottom of the confirmation page: ‚ÄúDetroit Marriott at the Renaissance Center will make every effort to accommodate the below requests, however they are not guaranteed. HANDICAPPED; C1‚Äù The hotel front desk refuses to discuss, saying I must use the 800# for reservations. The reservations people say they are powerless to guarantee the handicapped room. My granddaughter has reached out to her contact person who set up the block of rooms, but has been ghosted for over a week. We are only planning to stay one night, so my son can survive an overnight without a shower. What is not negotiable is the installation of grab bars at the toilet, as he is unable to transfer without them. The lack of a guaranteed handicapped room puts us in an impossible situation. I can still cancel our reservation, and find another hotel, or we can drive home several hours late at night in unpredictable early March weather, following a long and very busy and tiring day. Has anyone else had this experience with hotel reservations? It seems like a violation of ADA. I am trying not to go nuclear for my granddaughter‚Äôs sake, but I am maddened by this policy and the inability to reach anyone at the hotel in a position to effect change. Does anyone have advice on how to handle this situation?

I‚Äôm a longtime Marriott member. However, their website is unfriendly to people with disabilities. One can‚Äôt reserve a guaranteed accessible room on the site. One can‚Äôt view whether an accessible room is available. You can‚Äôt request such a room until you‚Äôve picked a room type from a list of all rooms (not knowing whether that type actually has an accessible room.). Then your reservation summary says accessible room is a non-guaranteed request. So I guess After a flight one is supposed to just show up at the hotel in a wheelchair and hope they have a room. Shameful.

Not sure if this is allowed‚Ä¶.my husband recently passed away and I have an accessible van that I would like to sell. Please let me know if it allowed to list, it‚Äôs a wonderful van in great shape. Thank you, April Griffin

We had been to Munich years ago so were a little familiar with it. We booked the Eurostar Book Hotel. It was very close to the main train station. We had an accessible room and it met all the needs we usually look for. I will say Europe in general knows how to do wheelchair accessible bathrooms. The one draw back of the hotel was the front door. It was one big twirling entrance. They really should make an accessible door to the side. I let them know that. Munich was packed. It is Christmas Market season and it was crowded. We have learned that if I want to see more then other peoples legs and backsides we have to visit the markets during the week days. Not as pretty without all the twinkly lights but easier on my nerves. I was proud of myself for not running over too many people, but the urge was real. A person (usually female and young) would look right at me as I was moving through the crowd and then step right into my path and stop. I resisted the urge but it was difficult. On our last day in Munich we were out wandering. A block from our hotel I went to cross the road, yes the pedestrian light was green, and an impatient driver decided that he should have the right of way. Thank goodness my wheelchair is very sturdy. I took a broadside hit from the idiot. My chair stayed upright and I made sure my arms were inside so the injuries were limited. I heard the gasp of the onlookers but not one came to help. So important note **make sure you buy a sturdy wheelchair. Munich was very easy to get around and the public transit is all wheelchair accessible. The helper to get me on the train was very efficient. Our journey had us making a train change in Zurich. Per usual our train was late and we had a 2 hour delay for another train. But the helper there took our bags and stored them for us for free. He gave us coupons to get a coffee or snack on the train too. I would love to come back to Zurich one day if our budget can handle it. Our next destination is Interlaken, Switzerland for Christmas.

accessibleGO is spotlighting accessibility-related companies who offer services and resources that serve our community. Today, we feature RightHear , an app that helps visually-impaired people navigate any environment. Introduce yourself and your company: Idan Meir is the Co-founder and CEO of RightHear, an innovative startup on a mission to turn public spaces into accessible environments for people with spatial orientation challenges, including people who are blind or visually impaired. Idan is originally from Israel but relocated with his family to Rockville, Maryland in 2021. Idan holds a bachelor‚Äôs degree in Psychology and Business from The Open University of Israel. He loves building companies, running, and eating hummus. Not necessarily in that order. RightHear provides real-time audio descriptions to help the blind interpret and understand their surroundings. They have a free app on iOS and Android, over 2,500 accessible locations worldwide, and an ever-growing user base and community. RightHear has partnered with leading international brands like McDonalds, Microsoft, and Costa Coffee to improve accessibility compliance as well as promote inclusion. Here is a video of the app in action. How did the idea for this company come about? It happened almost by accident. Along with my partner, Gil Elgrably, we had created a technology to offer virtual on-the-spot coupons to shoppers based on Apple‚Äôs iBeacon technology. iBeacons are small self-powered Bluetooth transmitters that can be placed on walls and roofs in a retail location. But the business model wasn‚Äôt making sense. We needed to build a very large user base for this to work and that was turning into a very large challenge. Then, during a 24-hour hackathon sponsored by the Ra‚Äôanana municipality, the Tel Aviv suburb in which RightHear is based, we had an insight. Rather than marketing the app to end users, what if we pitched it to the venues as a way of making their space accessible to people with visual impairment? We didn‚Äôt even know if blind people used smartphones or apps since they‚Äôre so visual, but we put together a prototype in the hackathon and, the next day, the Ra‚Äôanana municipality connected us with several blind people in the city. They were blown away, they were so excited about it, even though we didn‚Äôt have a product yet. And RightHear was born! What accessibility challenges does your company help users over come? RightHear mimics the function of a venue‚Äôs directory board, whether that‚Äôs a sign reading ‚ÄúMacy‚Äôs this way, restrooms that way‚Äù in a mall, or orienting a visitor inside a university‚Äôs administration building. When users with the RightHear app on their phone approach the virtual sign, the app speaks to them about what‚Äôs nearby. For example: ‚ÄúThe admissions office is 100 feet ahead to the right. Hours are 9:00am to 5:00pm, Monday through Friday‚Äù or ‚ÄúRestrooms 50 feet to the left.‚Äù Any memorable stories from your community that you'd like to share? A person that your product particularly impacted? You know, we've got this user, Hani. She's one of those people who you just can't forget. One day, she was heading home with her guide dog, but something went off. Her dog got lost, couldn't find their usual way home. Can you imagine the stress? So there she was, a little lost, a little unsure. But then, she remembered RightHear was on her phone. She fired it up, and our app guided her safely back home. It's pretty wild when you think about it, right? A simple app turning a moment of anxiety into one of empowerment Ever since that day, Hani and RightHear, we're like best friends. She takes us everywhere she goes, and I mean everywhere - even when she's traveling abroad. New city, new country, new everything, but there's RightHear, helping her find her way, keeping her independent. When you get a story like Hani's, it hits you. It's not just about building a product. It's about changing lives, making people feel more in control, more confident. And that, that's the real magic of what we do at RightHear. Why does accessibility matter to you? I believe that everyone should feel able, included, and empowered everywhere. Therefore, our aim at RightHear is to make the world a more accessible place for everyone. At RightHear, when we say universal access, we mean universal access. Our beacon technology removes physical barriers to access. But that‚Äôs not enough ‚Äì we also want to remove financial barriers to access. This is why our app on iOS and Android is 100% free to users today, and always will be free, it is vital to us to ensure that the benefit of accessibility and independence for users should not come at a cost. What are some of your other favorite accessibility startups in the field right now? You know, we're living in an exciting time. All around us, startups are using technology to break down barriers and build a more inclusive world. It's inspiring, really, to see how much of an impact we're collectively making. Let me share a few of my favorites: First up, we've got OKO by Ayes . These guys are doing something pretty cool. Their app is all about making intersections easier to navigate for blind folks. Just point your phone's back camera at a crossing, and voila, the app picks up the pedestrian signal. A simple concept, but it's really changing the game for people. Next, we've got Lotus Labs . They're taking things up a notch with a wearable ring. No, not like a magic ring, but close enough. You just point with the ring, and you can control stuff at home. It's almost like they're turning us into superheroes, right? And then there's ReBokeh . This one's a bit different, it's for people with moderate vision impairment. The app lets you create custom video filters based on your unique needs and environment. Think of it like adjusting the world's focus to suit your eyesight. It's innovative, personalized, and just plain cool. Each of these startups is challenging the status quo, pushing boundaries, and reshaping how we think about accessibility. And that's the beauty of it all, right? It's not just about building products; it's about making a difference, one innovation at a time. We're not just in the business of accessibility, we're in the business of empowerment. How does somebody access & get started using RightHear? Users can simply download the app on iOS here and Android here . It‚Äôs free to download and use, we don‚Äôt even require a sign up or login, we collect no personal information on our users. For businesses and venues, we offer a quick and simple solution that allows then to ensure that their buildings are accessible to all people, including those who are blind or visually impaired. We work with companies from local stores and restaurants, museums, hospitals, airports, all the way up to governments, global companies such as Microsoft, McDonalds and others.

Jump to final paragraph if you don‚Äôt like details‚Ä¶ Looking for lodging. Everyone has different needs. My husband is hemiplegic and full-time in a wheelchair. Here are his needs. His wheelchair does a 12‚Äù vertical lift. So he can do a slide board transfer in and out of bed as long as the bed top is between the lower and higher setting of his wheelchair seat. (Otherwise, he uses a Hoyer lift which means no platform beds.) That means he needs 35‚Äù to the left of the bed for the wheelchair and a moveable nightstand because he can only move to the right, so getting out of bed means I back the wheelchair up to the head of the bed. He uses a Hoyer lift to move to toilet so there must be room for it to move into bathroom and turn to hug the toilet. (44‚Äùx22‚Äù base) Nice to have: roll in shower with grab bar and attached seat, roll under sink, roll under desk/table, no threshold balcony. As others have said, VRBO and AirBnB either filter to nothing, or accessibility is exaggerated. Photos don‚Äôt highlight what needs to be seen so lots of communication is needed, The Hilton Grand Vacation properties look good. Has anyone stayed at their Ocean 22 or Ocean Enclave properties? What are the pros and cons? Open to other ideas. Thanks.

A new study came out regarding the accessibility of State Parks. Michigan ranked first. There are currently 15 state parks that have Track Chairs that can be rented free, on a first come, first served basis. 10 more parks will have them this year. Bridge Michigan, a local news service, has an article about it. Currently the State Park system has: * 15 Locations with Track chairs for use on the beach, on trails, and in snow. 10 more parks this year. 31 state run beaches with accessible walkways and other features. * Hunting Blinds available at 10 locations. * Kayak launches accessible in 7 locations from Detroit to Cadillac. Other accessibility features include viewfinders for people with colorblindness, accessible campsites, cabins, trails, and shooting ranges. So check out Michigan this summer if you are wanting to get back into the great outdoors. *

Hey Everyone, it‚Äôs Pinky üßö again; your friendly neighborhood Forum Moderator. Today I bring you something that I hope will solve a nightmare for other wheelchair travelers, that I suffer from all the time with my luggage. I‚Äôm not even sure how I got on the mailing list for a company called Phoenix Instinct from the U.K., but I recently got an email about a sale for their luggage trolley system for chairs. Typically I would ignore ads that I don‚Äôt subscribe too, but this sounded too good to be true, so I had to check it out. What I found was the coolest invention. A luggage trolley that fits multiple size bags (you can change them out as needed), that just hooks on to the back bar of your wheelchair. Plus they put some serious wheels on the trolley to be able to go over different surfaces. (Reminded me of the wheels Whill chairs uses.) Those of you like me, who have tried to balance the bags on our laps or push them in front of the chair while alternating free hands; know what a pain in the tushy luggage can be when we travel. Especially when our focus is more about the safety of our chair while it travels, so we don‚Äôt need any extra headaches when traveling like luggage not designed for us, Saving up for a set myself; so as soon as I have one, I will come back and update this review. But‚Ä¶ if anyone else happens to have these or orders them, please come back here and share with us your review of the bags. Would be helpful for everyone. Or better yet, if you have any other ideas for good wheelchair luggage; please share with us all? My brain is always open to new ideas and inventions to make life a little easier in my wheelchair‚Ä¶especially travel related. Thanks everyone,Pinky üßö Check them out on YouTube to see how it works.

Cologne was a new city for us. We found it to be a beautiful, walkable (rollable) city. The tram system was wheelchair accessible. Most of the museums and sights, even the Dom (cathedral) was easy to access. We wandered all over. So far the Christmas Markets in Cologne rank near the top of the list. But we quickly learned that to see anything I had to go in the daytime. The markets so packed that all I saw were legs. But the beer was great! We stayed at the Dorint Hotel Heumarkt. It was not the cheapest in town but the location was superb. The accessible room was great. Unfortunately they had overbooked that room. We got upgraded to a suite after the first night. That room was beautiful and very functional if you can take a few steps on your own. I made the mistake of not calling ahead of time to make sure it was the accessible room. Lesson learned. Each country has it‚Äôs own rules regarding wheelchair travel. Since we are doing all but one segment by rail we have much to learn. When leaving Cologne I knew to go to the train station early and ask about our seats. I asked at the information station and the attendant asked us to come back in an hour. She didn‚Äôt speak english. We did just that and got all set up. The train trip was very delayed and we ended up missing the connecting train from Berlin to Prague. Again we went to the information station and asked questions and got on the next train. As the rest of the trip goes along we find that while the trains may be accessible they are certainly not as dependable as they once were.

Hello everyone. My name is Matthew Brandley. I am proud to have been chosen to be one of the advisors on AccessibleGO. A little bit about myself. I was forced into retirement since 08 , retired emt former CNA. I lost both my parents during covid to dementia 18 months apart. I have chronic back problems. I am unable to stand for Ling periods or walk long distance. I also have crohns and celiac disease. My wife and I love cruising to new England and the Caribbean. We also enjoy rail excursions along the east coast. We live in Maryland and have been married for 10 glorious years. I have been answering questions on AccessibleGO for a little over 2 years. I enjoy immensely looking up info for. I am looking forward to meeting some of you down the road . One more thing. Humor. It gets you through everything. Love really bad dad jokes üôÉ

In August, I spent one night at Embassy Suites in downtown Winston-Salem, NC. They had 2 young women on their front desk they should clone, and they still have the best breakfasts. The room was OK but still has a rolling chair with no way to lock wheels. Ny room was the very last room next to stairwell; I was as far from the elevator without being outside. Parking there absolutely sucked. They use a municipal parking garage connected to their driveway. I never saw a handicapped parking space, much less a van accessible one . Ihad to ride all the way to Level J to find empty spaces side by side so that I could make my own van space. Then I had to get young woman from front desk to come find me to lead me back to the hotel. Will not stay there again.

I wanted to travel to Copenhagen in mid-September 2024 , but cannot find a Hotel where they have guest rooms with Roll-in-Showers. Does Anybody possibly know a hotel there, which I can contact about this?

I was diagnosed with EDS, Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. It‚Äôs a progressive disease with no cure and one that I have passed on to my children unknowingly. I am lucky I made it to my 30‚Äôs before the pain became unmanageable and now, I live with what I thought I couldn‚Äôt bear and all of it comorbidities. I know my children will face the same future and hopefully not have a harder path in front of them. Upon learning of my own diagnosis, we made some decisions with doctors and moved out of state for a better medical future and out of the cold climates. My spouse sold his very successful business and we started from scratch in hopes of providing the best future possible to our children. We built an ADA home for them, and we know our future holds those accommodations. It is now that I have learned there is little support for those with disabilities. So, when looking for a new business in our new town, we choose Mobility City of Las Vegas. It‚Äôs a company where we sell, rent and repair Durable Medical Equipment such as Wheelchair, Scooters, Hospital Beds, Patient Lifts, etc. It has given us the chance to work as a family. My husband and I run the business and our 16 year old works weekends with us. We are trying to build a company to pass down to them and as they grow each child will have the opportunity to work for the store or be able to utilize the equipment they will need in the future at a lower cost. We took our new family diagnosis and turned it into a new family business.

We went the 18 days with a scooter that my husband could not depend on. We had planned 4 self-guided walking tours at the ports, however, because we could not depend on the scooter, we had to book and pay for tours.Scootaround has decided not to charge us for the scooter rental but refuses any additional condensation for ruining a cruise. A friend suggests filling a small claim for the loss and inconvenience. Do you have any suggestions? Thank you,

From a member of our community: My Bucket lister is a trip to NYC. I am 63, use a 3-wheel Scooter due to MS, need a roll-in shower, an elevator, plenty of space to get around on my scooter, but and cannot afford high priced accommodations. Anyone have any suggestions?

Recently my husband and I finally got to experience our dream vacation which was a cruise to Alaska. Not only were we celebrating our 40+ anniversary but we were celebratng while I'm still able to enjoy such a beautiful place. We were also going so my husband can finally fulfill his dream of going halibut fishing, as this was our first cruise ever the night before we were due to dock for our excursion we stopped by Guest Services to ask how to go about requesting a wheelchair since we opted not to take my own. We were told to call down and request the chair 30 minutes before the time listed on ticket. We did just as instructed and were told my chair would be on it's way. Not even 5 minutes later we get a call letting me know as soon as dock official cleared the ship they would come for me. Announcement was made that ship had been cleared and no one came. We called second time and still no one. After 3rd call finally someone came, by the time we reached the area where we were to meet we instructed the bus had left 10 minutes ago. We were devasted but the man who they told us was director of excursions could care less. I even asked if I could pay for private transport to wherever the boat would be and he refused. What a horrible start to our dream cruise. He told us we could select a different excursion but we told him the main reason we chose this entire trip was for the halibut fishing one. We finally realized what a futile attempt it was getting anywhere with this man. I calmed my husband down and myself and told him we would make the best of the remaining days. So please if you choose to cruise with this line call for a wheelchair an hour before time listed on ticket and insist on it if they try telling you they'll come after ship is cleared by dock officials. Our travel agent and us as well filed a complaint against the director and how things were handled. We did receive a full refund on our tickets for that excursion.

So about a year ago we had a Garaventa wheelchair lift installed, which replaced the one that was here since 1960. If your considering purchasing a lift I would stay away from Garaventa. Their sales department seriously was only interested in a sale, not building a trouble free way to get from upstairs to downstairs.

This post is a cross-publication from one of our community members, Claire Szabo-Cassella, and was originally published on her blog Red Scooter Diaries . We‚Äôre bringing it to accessible GO as part of our ‚ÄúCommunity Voices‚Äù series, where community members share insights, tips, and tricks from their travel experiences. Other posts include community member Danielle and her review of seeing a show on Broadway . Nestled in the burgeoning college town of Cedar City, Utah, lies two gems of accessible leisure travel: Cedar Breaks National Monument and the Utah Shakespeare Festival . Limited mobility is not a problem at either venue, and there‚Äôs every reason to go. In July 2023, my husband Lou and I, together with our caregiver Josh, took in the remarkable beauty of western Utah as well as two superb Shakespeare performances over the course of a two-day visit to Cedar City. Here‚Äôs what we recommend: Where to Play Cedar Breaks National Monument A very pretty, half hour drive from Cedar City, Cedar Breaks National Monument is a welcomed breath of fresh air, quite literally. At an elevation of 10,000 feet, accessible view points lookout over colorful geological formations and abundant alpine vegetation. During summer months, wildflowers carpet the area. Taking in the view of Cedar Breaks National Monument During our July 2023 visit, Point Supreme Overlook was closed because it was being given a loving overhaul. Check here for park updates. We drove on to the alternate lookout, which was still mind-blowing and wheelchair accessible. Utah Shakespeare Festival Play on! After a global plague and a monarch change, we headed back to live theatre for the first time since 2019. At the Utah Shakespeare Festival, the magnificent acting, clever stage craft, and glorious costuming for Romeo and Juliet and A Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream demonstrated that the hiatus did not lower the exceptional quality of performances one iota. Both plays proved that the festival is still on its A-game ‚Äì on-stage anyway. When it comes to accessibility, however, we still hit a few minor glitches. Compared to four years ago, we were delighted to see remarkably more audience members, and even staff, attending performances using mobility devices at the Utah Shakespeare Festival. It‚Äôs an auspicious sign of accessibility for all. Traveling with a disability can mean having to alter plans unpredictably. My energy levels were such that we hoped to swap tickets for an alternate performance. Luckily, we could. Noah D. at the boxoffice happily exchanged the tickets. We appreciated the festival‚Äôs flexibility. Noah also enabled us to check out the actual seats in the outdoor theatre so I could decide whether I‚Äôd be more comfortable in the theatre seat or my wheelchair. Great guy. Okay, what still needs work: In any theatre, wandering, pre-show audience members and special seating arrangements can make navigating a mobility device challenging. Uniformed ushers were cheerful, plentiful, and dutiful when approached, but as noted in our 2019 festival visit, they did not offer to ease passage. To read more click here . Wheelchair users are blocked from entering the gift shop despite ADA ramp At the gift shop, we could not enter via the ADA ramp for the two performances we attended. Aubree Rasmussen, Guest Services Manager, ensured us that the ADA gift store ramp would be cleared for accessibility moving forward. Where to Stay Two hotels, both alike in accessibility, In fair Cedar City, where we lay our heads‚Ä¶ While visiting Cedar City, we‚Äôve stayed at the following two hotels, which are located across the street from one another and a ten-minute drive to the Shakespeare Festival. There are accessibility pros and cons with each. Courtyard Marriott Courtyard Marriott, Cedar City Ask for Room 225 at the Courtyard Marriott. The hotel offers accessible rooms with roll-in showers, but from what we saw, those rooms are smaller. Room 225 is more spacious with two queen beds and a pullout sofa, perfect for traveling with a caregiver or family travel. Bathroom There is an accessible tub with a foldout bench in Room 225. Unfortunately, the length of the shower hose barely extends far enough to reach the person sitting on the bench. A/C Unit Whoa, talk about clanky. Each room has its own A/C unit built-in and exposed within the room. Luckily, the weather cooled down enough at night that we could turn the unit off completely. Indoor Pool The indoor hotel pool has a mobility pool lift. However, when we called to book our stay and confirm there was a pool lift, the hotel staff was unaware that the lift was inoperable. Management Responsiveness While we were there, hotel management tried to fix the pool lift, but was unsuccessful. Instead, they compensated us for the inconvenience. Courtyard Marriott, Cedar City 1294 South Interstate Drive, Cedar City Utah, USA, 84720 P: 435-867-7300 La Quinta There‚Äôs plenty of room to roll around in Room 104 at La Quinta. The accessible room has one king-sized bed with space enough for a roll-in cot. We stayed very comfortably in Room 104 while traveling with a caregiver. Bathroom Wonderful. Indoor Pool Really great. Pool lift was operational at the time of our visit. Noise Level There was only one drawback to Room 104: the noise. The room is very conveniently located on the ground floor near a side-exit door. We heard the door bang shut every time a guest went in or out. La Quinta Inn & Suites by Wyndham, Cedar City 1377 S Main St. Cedar City, Utah 84720-3734 P: 435-865-0005

Here is a report on the Townhouse AirBnb in Atlantic City, with some info on our trip as well. Thanks to Z. for finding this accommodation. https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/8194762?adults=1&children=0&enable_m3_private_room=true&infants=0&location=Jersey%20Shore%2C%20NJ%2C%20USA&pets=0&search_mode=regular_search&check_in=2024-10-01&check_out=2024-10-06&source_impression_id=p3_1727641726_P3ZXp1TikZtXC7r7&previous_page_section_name=1001&federated_search_id=e32a5694-e6ea-4355-8be4-74dcebe7e42b You can‚Äôt say ‚Äúaccessible‚Äù without giving details about what accommodations a particular person needs. My husband is full-time in a wheelchair and I use a Hoyer lift to transfer him. So I need 1) a bed whose frame is >8‚Äù off the ground, 2) doors wide enough and rooms that allow a wheelchair to maneuver, 3) a toilet that can be accessed with the lift, and 4) a no threshold shower and floating vanity. This Townhouse had the first 3, and since we were staying just 2 days, we could forego the shower. The Townhouse has 3 levels with an elevator to go from garage level to living level, to bedroom level. The host was extremely responsive and helpful. He did measurements for me in advance; suggested which bedroom would be best for toilet access; warned me that there was carpet. He wanted to make things work. He was adamant that the wheelchair footprint could not be bigger than 30‚Äùx40‚Äù for the elevator and he was right! We brought a transfer wheelchair and used that in the townhouse, and parked the electric wheelchair in the large garage and used it when we were out. I was relieved that the Hoyer lift fit in the elevator, so whatever floor I needed to do a transfer on, it was easy. The bedrooms have carpeting so it took a little muscle to move the lift around. While the roads and sidewalks in Atlantic City were not very wheelchair friendly, the boardwalk was wonderful. Miles and miles of smooth ride along the shore with views of the water, piers crowded with people fishing, and beaches, and families enjoying bikes and other strange vehicles. We went all the way from the non-commercial end by the Basin, to the Steel Pier. The Edwin B Forsythe NWR 8-mile wildlife drive is lovely even for non-birders, and there were 2 trails that were completely wheelchair accessible: 5‚Äô wide and 1% grade.

Hi there! Wondering if anyone knows any accessible boating excursions in Key West. Was interested in a sunset cruise but the company (Fury) told me they are not accessible. They have accessible glass bottom boat trips, but I wanted something open air. Any suggestions?

We had a great experience at the Park MGM, a Marriott property, in Las Vegas when recently travelling with my sister who has Cerebral Palsy. My sister is able to walk short distances with a walker but it‚Äôs necessary to have a shower with a only a small curb and a hotel bed of manageable height. We booked a room with a roll-in shower then phoned the hotel and spoke with someone in reservations to verify room accessibility. The staff was amazing!! They sent someone from housekeeping to measure the bed (platform) from top of mattress (21‚Äù) to floor as well as verify the shower‚Äôs accessibility. The shower was indeed roll-in, with a bench and safety bars. There were additional safety bars in practical areas around the bathroom. See attached pics. Needing to arrange a wheelchair (manual) rental, the Guest Services/Concierge desk suggested using scooterbug.com. The wheelchair was delivered by scooterbug.com to the hotel bell desk and was available for us to pick up on check-in. Wheelchair was easily returned to the bell desk upon our departure. There is a free tram which runs between Park MGM, Aria and Bellagio hotels making access between these fairly easy. Vegas is big! Even with the tram there is lots of walking! We found Ubers in Vegas to be very accommodating too. After reading many of posts (nightmare stories) on accessiblego.com, I knew to check with the hotel a number of times prior to our arrival to emphasize the importance of getting the accessible room we reserved. Kudos to Park MGM Las Vegas for coming through! A great trip!! Glad we went! Thanks to the accessiblego.com community for the good advice and tips.

I am excited to join the Accessible Go Community as a travel expert. My particular expertise is traveling with Multiple Sclerosis. In that regard I have led workshops for MS groups. My wife, Martha, was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1994 after having some problems with her hand. We were lucky that the disease was recognized immediately and treated. After about 10 years of relapsing/remitting MS the disease gradually turned to secondary progressive MS. Having two children and working full time made for a pretty demanding situation. Our children were only 3 and 6 when Martha was diagnosed but fortunately Martha was able to remain active with their activities and her career until the mid 2000s when the MS had advanced to a stage that she could no longer work. At this time, Martha‚Äôs MS has progressed to the point where she is unable to perform the activities of daily living without assistance and requires a wheelchair for mobility. Martha and I worked for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Martha was an Environmental Engineer and I was an Atmospheric Research Scientist. Additionally, I was a union officier (AFGE) and provided disability counseling, especially in regards to reasonable accomodations and other rights for the disabled. We are now both retired. Martha and I love to travel and explore new places and activities. We started out our lives together with a honeymoon in Greece and have traveled ever since. We are trying to visit every state and see as many National Parks as possible. As Martha's MS has progressed traveling has become a little more difficult and requires a good deal more planning. With a significant amount of planning this past year we visited two Hawaiian Islands (Oahu and Hawaii), Barcelona (Spain), took a cruise of the western Mediterranean (from Barcelona with ports of call including Marseille, Genoa, Naples, Messina, and Valletta), visited San Diego, Hilton Head Island, Myrtle Beach, Congaree National Park (outside Columbia, SC), Roanoke and the Blue Ridge Parkway several times, and Washington, DC.

BRAINERD ARROWWOOD LODGE & SUITES IS NOT DISABLED FRIENDLY IF YOU HAVE A SERVICE DOG. It seems to me that the many, many complaints seen on this site and others boil down to two related issues: 1) there are no consistent rules about what ADA really requires and 2) - no one really enforces ADA. Additionally, one person's needed equipment and services may differ from what is necessary for others. Political action is needed. We in the disability community and our various advocacy and research organizations like the Amputee Coalition, Disability Partners, Spinal Cord Injury, Brain Injury, et. al. should lobby the White House and Congress to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to convene a series of conferences on meeting the needs of travelers with disabilities. From the conferences, enforceable standards could be developed with mandatory penalties with some teeth. These standards should apply not just to hotels, but air travel, restaurants, grocery stores, and anywhere a person with disabilities may need to travel. Senator Tammy Duckworth has been a leader in sponsoring legislation that would benefit those with disabilities, but she is just one Senator. It is also our responsibility as citizens to communicate with our elected leaders about the protections that we need. Let us hold our representatives‚Äô feet to the fire. Are we not citizens entitled to equal protection under the law? Start sending those cards and letters today to our advocacy organizations and to our political representatives.

I got interested in this website a couple days ago as a source of info regarding valued destinations for accessibility impaired travelers. As I dig into the site forums, most info seems to be linked to how to cope rather than destinations to enjoy. Is there a forum recommend for destinations that describe first person experience. A couple examples. A Progresso Texas. Park and walk/scooter across the border, about 400 yards. Festive atmosphere, cheap medical drugs, great restaurants with midday bands, margaretta street bar every 200 feet. We go several times a year for a weekend vacation. Super 8 motel has clean, dated, rooms for 75 bucks a night, US side of the border. Streets, curbs and businesses are very scooter able on the Mexican side. B Moab Utah. Rent a 4 wheel drive vehicle and explore a 120 different desert canyon trails. Impaired person has direct contact to as many rocks as they want to touch, and viewpoints give 50 miles of long distance view. Lots of hotel and campgrounds. Tourist population can be very European as Moab is a globally recognized destination. Off roading is the draw, rentals of all types make it easy. wife and I have just submitted our 5th us passport renewal and love to travel. Looking for ideas not advertisements. Am I in the right place?

Hi everyone. I am almost 40 years old (next feb), I have my own day staff, afternoon staff and waking night staff in 24 hr supported living care in the UK-I used to live in residential care but find they‚Äôre not the best for my person centered and complex needs. I am physicaly disabled and require the use of a rigid active wheel chair called the quickie nitrum,it‚Äôs a fully bespoke job inc synergy pushrims/wheels,I remember being told the brand of the inner tubing is marathon as they‚Äôre blow up instead of solid heavy weights like all my other chairs be it NHS ones or bought.I‚Äôve seen people say marathon are not the best on wheelchair sites before, but I‚Äôve never had a problem with mine. I also have speech impaired classic autism, I communicate with different forms of communication such as Proloquo2Go AAC on an iPad Pro to makaton to PECS but I am unable to write so that one has always been out‚Ä¶I have mild intellectual disability, two forms of epilepsy, severe widespread peripheral neuropathy and spinal damage ( both caused by over restraint),severe trigeminal neuralgia on both sides of my face (first started when I was 18,then this year, it also started on my right side,haha),I have severe hyperacusis and tinnitus made worse by the people who live with me and blast out music day and night,staff leaving them to it) and have 2 special behind the ears devices, they look exactly like hearing aids and work for me. my hobbies are clubbing to see specific DJs, where I live in Manchester, even our so called lift free venues may have a special chair lift that climbs the stairs like in the the Albert hall,though I emailed creamfields festival accessibility team very early this year and asked what the access is like for a manual chair user and they replied with ‚Äúbuy a ticket and find out‚Äù,I found out they had changed that team later in the year not surprisingly. I really like DJing,I‚Äôve done vinyl and controller DJing (via serato pro) since 1999, I‚Äôm a professional artist in the outsider art world and been in exhibitions, I love gaming but most of all I love my pets,including my disabled cat and rabbit and two cat fish. I desperately want to go to Ibiza within the next couple of years,and what scares me is things like,is pacha (club) wheelchair friendly, if my wheelchair will be intact by the time I get off the plane and should I save up for 1st class to avoid babies or kids screaming? It‚Äôs fine dealing with drunk or otherwise incapacitated folks when out clubbing as I‚Äôm prescribed diazepam but that and my ear defenders are not enough to cope with the pitch of kids screaming. I‚Äôve heard of so many scare stories with wheelchairs being broken,I also worry if it‚Äôs possible to find a nearby wheelchair friendly hotel or bnb or villa with a high profile/electric hospital bed as I am prescribed one and have to use it due to my needs. I‚Äôve looked around on air bnb and booking but can‚Äôt find any, plus I‚Äôve read blogs from wheelchair users who went to Ibiza and there was mixed success, not being able to organise a WAV taxi unless you do it months in advance, how on earth do you know what time your getting out a club in order to book the taxi lol? It‚Äôs ridiculous really,unless things have changed since I read that old blog. Thanks for reading this if you did,I waffle on way to much as I have no short term memory,sorry lol cheers,from Emlyn.

My husband and I had to get on an airplane really early in the morning so we stayed a night in Las Vegas NV. I specifically asked for a wheelchair accessible room and bathroom with appropriate grab bars. I'm a below the knee amputee and legless right now. I don't have a lot of experience in a wheelchair accessible room. When we first came to our room, I could barely roll in the door. There was a chair on one side of the door and a dresser on the opposite side. There were 2 queen size beds and the bathroom was horrible. I only used it twice. The first time wasn't too bad but at 3:30am, on our way to the airport I was using the grab bar at the toilet. There was no grip and I fell, slammed my stump, right leg (new reconstructive surgery) on the floor and my hand also on the right side slammed against the sharp corner of the shower. As you can guess I broke my hand. My husband thought it wasn't broken but we went down to the front desk anyway. It took SIX hefty security guards to decide I should probably wrap at least 2 fingers together (no brace or even a popsicle stick) with coband. It took them an hour and a half to decide what to do, even though my husband and I were telling them we were going to miss our flight. When we got to the airport we found out we had definitely missed our flight and had to wait 2 more hours for the next flight to Denver CO. While waiting my husband found some cardboard for a temporary brace for my fingers. To make a really long story short we ended up in Bentonville Arkansas. From Denver to Bentonville we rode in a really small plane with 45 people in it. They tried to get me down to our seats in row 19 in an isle chair but the isle was SO narrow it wouldn't fit, let alone with me on it! It was crazy. We were gone for a week. The Marriott in Bentonville was just about perfect except for the grab bar by the toilet again. I made my husband help me get onto the toilet and off again. On the way home, they ‚Äúlost my wheelchair ‚Äú between Bentonville and Las Vegas. In Denver I had to sit in an isle chair for over 2 hours. (My butt is bigger than an isle chair and it was giving me a huge wedgie! üò≥) When we got to Vegas, my wheelchair was waiting for me. The Denver airport apparently kept my wheelchair down with the luggage, as not to lose it. I about lost it. We decided to stay in Mesquite Nevada on the way home. We got there at 2 am. We had, again requested a wheelchair accessible room and bathroom. I had NO idea that they use accessible rooms for people with pets. It wreaked of animal pee and poo. I'm HIGHLY allergic to dogs and cats. There were 2 full size beds (my wheelchairdidn't fit between the two beds), and the bathroom was also a joke. My husband had to be my human forklift in the bathroom again. On our way home to Cedar City UT we decided that my hand didn't look right so we went to Instacare where I was told my hand was broken in 3 places and would require surgery. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è One week after surgery my husband was asked to go help setup another Walmart store in‚Ä¶you guessed it‚Ä¶in Las Vegas. I said absolutely not. He went alone and my best friend was able to come stay with me. Needless to say, I KNOW the exact questions to ask for next time. We're actually going to Hawaii in February and the Philippines in April. I'm worried about leaving the USA but I already know Hawaii really well because we used to live there. But in the Phillipines? I wouldn't go except our son is getting married. OK that's my rant. üòÅ
