Good Day ‚Äî Me and two friends are going out of Long Beach ‚Äî porting at Mazatlan, Puerto Vallarta and Cabo. I‚Äôd be interested in excursions that can accommodate me and my scooter. Any suggestions?

Last month we stayed just 1 night (thank goodness!) at the former Margaritaville Resort in Pensacola Florida. The new ownership had revamped the place since we‚Äôd booked the stay and the rooms looked totally different. The beds were so very high, even I needed a step stool to climb into them. And my poor hubby could not get in. So I called reception, they said they had accessible rooms where the beds were definitely lower and could send a valet up to move our things. But they refused to show us the room before moving us! So what if 1 thing was better while somethine else we required was worse? We were leaving to meet friends for dinner and I figured I would speak with the manager upon our return, to see the accessible room in hopes of moving; basically going over the front desk gal‚Äôs head since she said they have a policy to not show guests vacant rooms. Yet when we returned from dinner, they‚Äôd sent maintenance in to remove the box springs from both beds, so now when you climbed into bed, your body weight sunk the mattress down so you couldn‚Äôt get out of the wooden frame surrounding the mattress! I had to pull myself out; my disabled hubby could not figure out how extricate himself from the mattress at all. We‚Äôd stayed at 2 dozen hotels so far on our 38-day roadtrip and not experienced such a problem! But be careful - the new management is not accommodating. We would never consider returning there for several additional reasons, but this site is about accessibility.

This place is not handicap accessible. If you can walk a steep incline to the admission window, you can pay to have staff take you around on a 4 seater golf cart . Cost was 125 total for 3 plus 3 others who can walk. Between the 6 of us we have taken almost 1,000 pictures in this God given beautiful place. All bi. rds are well taken care of. We'll fed. Clean environment. You can hold them. Feed them in certain areas. If you decide you want to do this , periods of shorts walking and standing are involved. . Go during a dry day. It rained when we went. I had my scooter with me up to the entrance for the park. I was doing fine on the way back down ontil I hit the damp asphalt. My scooter and I went for a uncontrollable ride across the 3/4 length of the lot. Ôªø Ôªø

I know, how did I get so lucky, right? I‚Äôm from California. One of my sons is a combat wounded veteran (Afghanistan). He appears healthy, but is not ‚Äî and has a German Shepherd service dog that lives with us (Lt. Dan). Over the last few years, we‚Äôve traveled and taken the dog on every sort of transportation ‚Äî planes, trains, boats, you name it. We go to amusement parks with him fairly often. He‚Äôs a pro. We thought we had the disability travel thing down with the dog, but then‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶my older son (34) was diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrigs‚Äô disease) this year. That put us on a fairly urgent ‚Äúcheck-off-the-bucket list‚Äù journey. He now uses a wheelchair and has almost no use of hands and feet. His needs change almost weekly so we can‚Äôt plan too far in advance. Our first big outing was a week at Disneyland because my 3rd child (a daughter) works for the company (yay discounts!). Can you imagine our family of five, with a wheelchair, and a service dog, at Disneyland in JULY? Yup, we are THAT family. I used to think people who did that sort of thing were crazy, but now I understand. Wheelchair travel is new to me, so I‚Äôm here hoping to learn about that. Thanks for helping us!

My hubby is a right leg above knee amputee and we just returned from an amazing trip to the above destinations. I am writing this to encourage others to continue to travel and work through the challenges that travel poses to those with differing abilities. My hubby wears a prosthetic but has never recovered fully from the amputation so needs a walker for mobility & a scooter/wheelchair for long distances. We flew to Belgrade - Bozeman, MT with our two adult children. Arriving at the airport, we invested (take change as some airports require coins) in a luggage cart. I retrieved a wheelchair and away we went to our gate and flew Southwest. We checked his rollator and used the wheelchair in the airport. Seating was tight but manageable. Landing in Belgrade - Bozeman, MT, airline attendant brought another wheelchair to the plane door and pushed hubby to retrieve our luggage. In advance, we rented a large van (from Budget Rent-A-Car) to accomodate all our luggage, his walker, and a rented scooter. We did have difficulty finding a place that would rent us a scooter for the limited time we needed (7 days.) However, I highly recommend Price Rite Medical Equipment. They provided awesome customer service and acted upon our requests quickly. The scooter was delivered to our first hotel prior to arrival and they picked up from our hotel at the end of the trip. The scooter they recommended easily adapted to inclines and kept its battery strength throughout our trip. (We did charge it every night. The scooter we use at home,Go Go Pride, would never have met the inclines and sometimes rocky paths we encountered.) However, we couldn‚Äôt figure out how to break down the scooter to fit it into the van. Thank God we had our adult children who lifted the scooter in/out of the van. It probably could have been broken into smaller pieces but we didn‚Äôt want to wait for the company to come demonstrate for us and lose time site seeing. Yellowstone is very accessible to those with mobility issues. We stayed on the main loop road and did not do any back country hiking. MOST typical tourist sites (geysers, basins, canyons, etc.) have wooden boardwalks that make seeing these astonishing sites possible. Don‚Äôt miss Artist‚Äôs Point! I would suggest travelling with snacks as there can be long distances between food stops. Gasoline stations were adequate for our travels. The Grand Tetons are so close to Yellowstone, you should not miss visiting them. We also took the Jackson Hole Aerial Tram at the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort to the summit of Mt Rendezvous. My husband rode the scooter onto the tram which holds 100 people and gave us a disability discount! We had brunch at a TINY restaurant on the summit. The restaurant was too small to fit the scooter but we ate at an outside picnic table. ‚ÄúThey‚Äù were working on making better disability accomodations for the restaurant while we were there. My hubby was able to drive the scooter along the Skywalk and take in the 360-degree view of the Tetons. We also took a boat ride on Lake Jenny. Boarding and deboarding from the scooter were a little challenging. In Cody, we would have loved to see a rodeo but it was closed for the winter. There were a few other opportunities we missed because of travelling in Sept. However, we were advised to avoid the summer crowds. The Buffalo Bill Cody Museum in Cody, WY was educational, enjoyable, accessible and well done, but if I had to shorten our trip, I would have skipped this visit. Upon our return to Bozeman, we had time to visit the Museum of the Rockies. For those of you who enjoy archaelogy & dinos, this was also fully accessible with unique displays from other similar museums we have seen. Our hotel reservations varied in their ADA accomodations: Belgrade Holiday Inn (Belgrade, MT) offered free delicious breakfast and friendly, helpful customer service.. Room was large enough for scooter and walker. Nice place to stay. Reasonable price. Canyon Lodge offered convenience of staying in Yellowstone. (Distances just getting into the park can take you 2 -3 hours which is why we decided to splurge and stay in the park 1 night.) We had to travel by car to get to the cafeteria, souvenir shop, etc. from the hotel room. Walking paths appeared too rocky for the scooter. The room was very small for 4 adults and disability equipment but we made do. Beds & pillows uncomfortable. Expensive night, especially for such a small space. No vending machines available. Snow King Resort (Jackson Hole, Wy)- Lots of activities, ammenities & restaurant were offered here but the room was small. Vending machines were a good distance away from room. We liked this room space least of all. Beds & pillows uncomfortable. Our most expensive lodging. However, we did not take advantage of any of the activities or amenities as we wanted to go to the Tram at the Jackson Hole Resort. Snow King is very close to the town of Jackson Hole. However, for our purposes we probably could have stayed somewhere less expensive or stayed right at the Jackson Hole Resort. The Cody Hotel (Cody, WY) - Our favorite lodging on our trip! Very friendly front desk and custodial service. These people aim to please. Pool, Hot Tub, Steam room, vending machines. Cozy, comfortable room with plenty of space for disability equipment. Large bathroom. Very reasonable price! We absolutely had a fantastic trip and I would recommend this to everyone! Hope this wasn‚Äôt too long to read!

This April, we celebrate Passover, Easter and Ramadan. We also celebrate everyone in the limb loss community. Why? The next amputee could be someone you know. Even you! Every day, more than 500 people in the U.S. lose a limb. It is estimated that, by 2050, the number of people living with limb loss will nearly double. Why are these numbers so high? Most amputations are from diabetes, cancer, trauma, and septic infection. In the last two years as a Certified Peer Visitor, I have worked with 5 people about my own age who were not feeling well, or who lost consciousness due to diabetes and were informed in the ER that they needed an amputation. In the space of just a few hours, their entire lives changed. With the growing number of individuals with limb loss, we must ensure everyone gets access to the necessary resources to reclaim their independence. What do I mean by resources? Sometimes it is something simple, like help with co-pays for physical therapy. Sometimes it is something more complicated like making a home accessible for a new amputee ‚Äì placing grab bars in the shower, making sure there is room in the bathroom to maneuver with a walker or wheelchair, placing a ramp so one can get into their home. And then there are prosthetics. Even a part of a prosthetic like a knee or an ankle can cost thousands of dollars. Although one may think they have good insurance, the partial payments the patient is responsible for could be thousands of dollars. So, how can you help? Every year I participate in the Adventist 5K Run, Walk and Roll to raise money for the Amputee Patient Assistance Fund. You can participate too. You can join my team the Hopeful Steppers and help me reach my fundraising goal, form your own team, or support my cause by donating. To do any of these things, you can click on my race page: https://www.classy.org/team/490534 Here are the details for the race: Date: April 23, 2023 Where: Berman Hebrew Academy 13300 Arctic Ave Rockville, MD 20853 Time: 9:30 am ‚Äì Sign in 10:30 am ‚Äì Start time Thank you so much. I can‚Äôt express how grateful I am for your help and support. Hope

From community member Kendra, People don‚Äôt understand the struggles and physical pain of being handicap. Here‚Äôs an email I wrote Disney and my very recent terrible trip: I went to Disneyland on January 13th, 2019. I got there at 11:15pm but by the time I found parking and used the very limited elevator and long walk to the park it was 1pm. I am disabled and had very hard time. I got there and was told to go to City Hall once I got inside Disneyland and to let them know I was handicap. I did as instructed and was only given a map, an attitude, and no instructions as to what to do with limited mobility and how to do it. My first ride was a disaster. I went to Tomorrowland and tried going in to the buzz light year ride (I believer that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs called). I was told to park my ACV then was asked if I can transfer (which I replied yes to as long as I‚Äôm not standing long). I was standing for what seemed like a lifetime waiting for the staff to let us on the ride (15-20 minutes). My legs were in so much pain and I was sweating from the pain I was in. I then realized the park wasn‚Äôt very handicap friendly. I gave the benefit of the doubt and went to the next ride. I was told I can wait in line because my ACV fit fine. Every turn was very difficult I had to keep backing up to turn and people were getting upset and it was embarrassing for my family and I. After going on a few rides we decided to try California adventure and was given an even bigger attitude when I asked if there was any kind of pass ( I was tired of not being able to turn in line as well as feeling so much pain standing in line waiting for my transfer) I explained all this and was was looked up and down and told I will be fine as if they knew what I was feeling physically. I even upgraded to the fast pass to see if it helped but all I did was spend more money for nothing. Overall this was a once in a lifetime vacation being disabled and not able to work which was ruined by rude staff and and completely un-empathetic people. I‚Äôm truly disappointed in the lack of accessibility for the disabled. I even had a doctors letter because he was worried I would get slack for being disabled. I honestly thought it would be different I called before I took the vacation to ensure you were handicap friendly and your costumer service staff over the phone were phenomenal. Not so much in person and definitely not like universal studios which accommodated to my disability without me even having to ask.

Join John Morris of WheelchairTravel.org and accessibleGO for a live digital event to share Thanksgiving accessible travel tips & advice.Tuesday, November 14 at 7pm ET here on the Community ForumPlus, as an added bonus, attend for a chance to win a Fall Fun Travel Package!Package includes:üéÅ $250 Southwest Airlines gift cardüéÅ $250 Disney gift cardüéÅ A hotel booked on accessibleGO, worth up to $200üéÅ 30 minute accessibility consultation with accessibleGO Ôªø ÔªøJohn Morris is a thought leader in the field of accessible travel. In 2015, Morris founded WheelchairTravel.org, a hub of resources and information for disabled travelers that is now the world‚Äôs largest accessible travel website. Through his Accessible Development Group consultancy, Morris advises corporations, non-profit organizations, and destinations in the development of accessible products, programs, and services. Morris has led innovative public policy campaigns to foster a culture of inclusion. Known for traveling the world with one hand, a passport, and his power wheelchair, he has become one of the leading advocates for accessibility and inclusion within the travel industry. He is a graduate of Florida State University (B.S./M.S.) and the University of Florida (MBA) and currently resides in Boston, Massachusetts.

My husband and I recently traveled to NYC for a day at MOMA and needed a taxi to take us from the train station to the museum. By calling the number supplied by AccessibilityGo, I was able to reserve a wheelchair-accessible taxi to meet us at the train station, load the chair (with me in it) into their van, and off we went to MOMA. The driver was kind, courteous, and very efficient! A quick phone call at the end of our day brought another wheelchair taxi in less than 10 minutes who whisked us away to the train station. What tremendous service! And at the same prices that one would pay for the other yellow cabs on the streets. Bravo!

Last week we announced that we've expanded to become the first one stop shop for travelers with disabilities... This includes flights! In addition to booking flights on accessibleGO.com , customers can specify what they require assistance with including top accessibility requests such as checking a wheelchair, wheelchair assistance from ticket counter to seat or traveling with a task trained service dog. accessibleGO will contact the airlines directly to convey accessibility requests. Book a flight today!

We were actually staying at the Marriott resort which is one resort down from the Aulani but decided to take a Sail Canoe ride from the beach in front of the Aulani resort. My son is in a wheelchair and weighs about 160 pounds. The sail canoes fit about 8 passengers and leave about every hour from 9 am until 2 pm. The captain‚Äôs name is Neil and he always has an assistant. Our day the assistant was Uncle Joe. They put my son in a beach wheelchair to get him to the canoe and then power lifted him onto the net where everyone sits. We had a great time and we could have never done it without their help. They emphasized that they love to bring people onto the canoe who normally couldn‚Äôt make it onto the water and we should let friends know. They kept calling my son Little Dude. I would highly recommend it! Also, if you go on the canoe, ask Uncle Joe about his son. It is a great story!

I contacted Viking to confirm they allow motorized mobility equipment like all other cruise lines. They forwarded me a ‚ÄúFit to Travel‚Äù form (attached). Right off the bat I found that it‚Äôs apparent that they feel they are the arbiters of whether or not a handicapped person is Fit to travel with them. Before becoming handicapped, we travelled many years and many places with Viking. I was absolutely shocked to see this. They should be ashamed. I‚Äôm not sure if American ADA finds this acceptable for their Mississippi River cruise. Perhaps just having an ‚ÄúAccessible Room‚Äù is enough. (Their river boat does have elevators). American Dream River cruising here allows motorized equipment. Why can‚Äôt Viking? I wanted to share this with the group. I do not do social media, but we need to get this out there to the public to shame Viking into changing this discriminatory policy.

I‚Äôm returning from a trip with my sisters to The Wentworth by the Sea in New Castle NH. Upon arrival I did not have my requested handicap room. I was told there was an mistake in my booking despite my 3 calls! The front fest did show my other room to try to make it ok, but when I explained the bed height , the climb in shower and the toilet were not usable I got nowhere. I ended up sleeping in a sisters room and had to have her help me for the full stay. Their Handicap rooms were full and I was left to make do. It was mortifying! I ended up covered in bruises from my multiple struggles. Losing balance in the bathroom because of no grab bars and hitting the wall. Using all of my energy trying to complete simple tasks. The 2 breakfast tickets were an insult that we didn‚Äôt use. There were 4 of us anyway. This is the 2nd time I have been screwed by them, the first was when they lost my car keys a few years ago on Christmas Day and I sat alone in s hotel room. I need my scooter lift to travel to my family‚Äôs house. The rekeying cost 500 dollars that I was never reimbursed for. But family begged me to try again, and this is what I got. Never Again Keep yourself safe and stay in Portsmouth!

Has my title says, I am Phil Randall. I am a Marine, served from 1966 to 1977, then got out on a Medical Discharge due to a back injury I suffered in Vietnam. Five years ago I had a Spinal Simulator inserted into my spine. It worked great at relieving the pain, but I in did up having a Blood Infection from it that almost cost me my life. The blood infection settled in my T11 and I cannot walk now and am basically numb from my waist down. I‚Äôve been in a wheelchair since and I have a van to drive and my wheelchair locks to the floor just behind my drivers seat. We have not travel other than in my van, but we are wanting to reach out and see the world.

Hello, my name is Karen and I am new to accessiblego. I am planning a trip later this year and it will be my very first trip ever since I have become disabled and riding a bariatric sized mobility scooter (Pride Victory 10). I am able to walk short distances, and can stand for short periods of time, but I do get tired quickly doing either. I am a planner by nature, plus this being my first trip where I will need so many things that I never needed before naturally is making me quite nervous! I am single now and will be traveling alone on a very limited budget, so it will be allll up to me to pull this off without a hitch‚Ä¶yikes!! My first question is regarding ‚Äúaccessible hotel rooms‚Äù. Is there a standard list/law of items a hotel room must have to be accessible? Or does each different hotel make accessible rooms by what they think some people may need‚Ä¶for example grab bars on a step over tub vs. having a walk/roll in shower? Are they both considered accessible rooms? I have been reading many different posts on AG and learning a lot about tips people use while traveling. There are soooo many things I never even knew to ask about, just to take a vacation to a friends house for a week and back home. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúnice‚Äù way to ask this so here I go (I‚Äôm not shy ha-ha)‚Ä¶.Any tips anyone has for the ‚Äúbeginner traveler‚Äù who weighs 305 lbs and rides a bariatric mobility scooter going to Arkansas later this summer??? I sure would be grateful for your shares. Check in/Check out rules & regs, specific hotels that are nice but a bit more budget friendly would help as well. Dining is another whole area I haven‚Äôt even begun to tackle yet. What about protection for a woman who is traveling alone. Last time I traveled was prior to my husband passing away. He was a veteran, and I just always felt safe traveling when he was with me. What is acceptable now days and what is not? Pepper spray??? Sooo many things to think about! You may have seen my other post on here regarding finding a folding wheelchair for myself. If I can get one of those prior to traveling I think it would help not having to deal with bringing my big scooter. OK that‚Äôs all for now‚Ä¶..thank you all so much for all of your wonderful suggestions, and kind words on my other post as well‚Ä¶.I truly value learning from all of you! Karen

I travel about once a month for work. I have a mobility scooter that I take with me. In most airports I drive my mobility scooter through the gate, I walk back using their cane because it would, then I go through the old fashion and x-ray machine. I cannot do the ones where you hold your hands above your head. While I‚Äôm doing that, they swab down my scooter. Normally this is not a problem. Last week I was in Arizona, and they were horrible to me. I explain to them this is what we normally do, but they have a different way, that‚Äôs fine. They let me sit there for 45 minutes before they could find a qualified TSA agent who could pat me down. I explain to them several times that my plane is boarding soon and I need the extra time to use the restroom. I got yelled at and was told were sorry we don‚Äôt have enough qualified agents again. They finally finished with eight minutes for me to get to my gate. I need to know is there a written document of how they are supposed to handle scooters. I need to take this with me when I travel. They upset me so much, I almost had an anxiety attack. There has to be a document of some sort of how to handle mobility scooters.

I had to read this last paragraph a few times for the use of a shuttle service (at a hotel whom shall remain anonymous) in Orlando Florida! SHUTTLE SERVICE The Hotel does have Shuttle Service to the major theme parks and the shuttle schedule is available at the Front Desk upon check-in. Please be at the Pickup Locations at least 10 minutes prior to boarding time. Shuttle Times are subject to change due to traffic and weather conditions. Groups of 9 or more may not use this shuttle and should make arrangements for a private charter. Please note that Handicap Shuttle Services must be scheduled 24-hours in advance. Motorized Scooters and foldable wheel-chairs are not eligible for wheel-chair accessible vehicle. Your coments please!

I noticed that I need a chair that is plus sized and can sleep better in a recliner than a bed. Additionally the bathrooms need plus sized walk in showers with benches that can hold a larger weight capacity. I stayed in a hotel near Newark airport that claimed to be handicapped accessible. As I waited and had to use the bathroom the handicapped stall were each locked from the inside on the second and first levels which made no sense. I was attending an event on the second floor and missed the second part of the event because I had to go to the bathroom so badly that once I got in my room I did not go back. They did not honor the early check-in, they claimed the hotel room was on the first level, I had to wait 2 hours for them to clean a room on the 12th floor that required a long walk from the elevator and I walk with a Walker. I was alone in my room so I had no support getting in and out of bed. The furniture or chair was too small for my hips. I sat in the desk chair and it had wheels so I had no support but had to strategically try to brace myself against the foot of the bed to try to stand. The bathroom shower had a small wooden bench that had what looked like mold within the crevices of each wooden slat. What can be done to require hotel rooms that claim to be handicapped accessible more accessible also considering the conditions that I mentioned.

My wife and I just stayed here after staying with family in Florida. Accessible room 109 was perfect! Real roll in shower with grab bars and shower bench. The sink was shaky . Plenty of room to roll around if need in a wc. Restaurant on site. Free hot buffet breakfast. Elevator accessible.

My wife and I stayed at this hotel 2 nights recently in Wytheville, VA. My wife utilizes a power wheelchair. I am posting this in the community forum because I could not find this particular hotel in the accessiblego hotel listing and because I am hoping that the positive attributes of this particular hotel might apply across the chain. We booked a king suite with a roll-in shower (#215). The entry door was very easy to open and had a magnet that attached to the door stop that made it very easy to get in the room and bring in the luggage cart. I have stayed in a lot of rooms that were difficult for me as an able bodied person to open and enter. The suite is roomy. It is one large room with a sofa, coffee table, and a counter with a microwave, dorm refrigerator, and a coffee maker. The coffee table does not allow access to the counter. Other than that there was plenty of space for my wife to maneuver. The bed was the lowest I have ever seen. It was 18‚Äù - 19‚Äù high. I think wheelchair users would be able to transfer back and forth to the bed. The short closet was unusable until I was able to move the bundle of extra linens. The grab bars around the toilet were good. The space under the sink worked well for us. The shower was the biggest problem. It actually had a shower curtain that went all the way to the floor (rare) so there was not any flooding. It did not work well for us. I don‚Äôt know how someone without help could use it. The shower head was slid up to the top position making it unreachable to anyone seated. The soap and shampoo bottles were on the opposite wall from the shower head and controls. It just didn‚Äôt work well. Is this a typical layout for a Holiday Inn Express and Suites?

Just got back from participating in an Art Fair. We stayed at this hotel last year. Here is the skinny: Bed height - excellent. A Room clearance - average. C Entry Door - too hard for me to pull open F Bathroom Sink - too high. F Shower with moveable shower chair - good B Toliet - height too low C Grab bars - too few at toilet and shower C I‚Äôm going to make a spreadsheet and start rating everywhere I stay. Hoping it will make a difference in everyone‚Äôs life! Dee

Hi. I just learned this afternoon that there is a website for people with disabilities who wish to visit Disney theme parks so I felt I needed to share this info with this group. I remember my several trips to Disney World after becoming disabled, but it has been quite a few years since I last visited there. Back in that time I and my family (+ 2 adults and 3 kids) never wanted in line at any ride because the cast members would see my mobility scooter and take us right to the front of the line . I understand that changed because perfectly healthy people were using wheelchairs, etc. , to take advantage of their kindness. I do know the cast members went out of their way to accommodate me and my scooter. If I got on a ride that started at one place and ended another, my scooter would be right there waiting on me. It wasn't just me being treated with up frontcare but their 1st question was always, ‚Äúhow many are in your party?‚Äù The parks do have wheelchairs for rent but unless it changed they do not reserve them; it is first come, first served. I recommend taking your own or finding a rental place thst will deliver to wherever youare staying. On my first trip as a disabled person, the rental place delivered a scooter to the leading company where we lucked up our key to the house we rented and it included charger plus a large sign on the back of tte scooter with my name so that it was easily identified. We just brought it into tte garage each night and charged it all night for my next day. I never came close to running out of power and we stayed for fireworks a couple of times. There is also a Facebook page that is administered by a young man who is legally blind, and who visits Disney multiple times throughout the year and posts about events, etc., accessible to disabled visitors. I will say there was nothing I wanted to do that was not made accessible. I went on safari , the train, the monorail, etc. Here is the info: disabilityatdisney.com and the FB page is Disability at Disney by Gray Houser. If you go to Facebook and at the magnifying glass type in Disability at Disney you will find several FB pages offering information.

BRING ‚ÄúDISPOSABLE‚Äù ACTIVITIES. Stop at the $1 store or equivalent & get cards, books, dominoes, ‚ÄòJENGA‚Äù, dice, jigsaws, or word game books, or other activities, & plan to leave them behind. Not only does this free up space for souvenirs but many lodges, hotels, cruises, or cabins love to get activities for stranded guests. Plus ‚Äúnew‚Äù stuff especially is exciting for bored kids. Companies also offer fun educational kits (KiwiCo is just 1 ) that provide all materials needed in a small box. Kids may like the idea of picking out activities. Also stock up on writing implements to also be left behind. At the very least, less to unpack. Yes it‚Äôs a bit of waste, but how much & how often, really. If it gives someone else a few hours of fun, good job.

This post is part of accessibleGO‚Äôs ‚Äúcommunity voices‚Äù series, where we spotlight the experiences, insights, and advice of our community‚Äîfor our community! These posts focus on accessibility and accessible traveling experiences. If you have a post you‚Äôd like to submit, let us know by filling out this short form . Meet Heather: My name is Heather Graham, and I live in the city of Calgary, Alberta, Canada. I have always loved to travel and did a fair-bit in my 20s, always backpacking. In the last 15-years I have not done much‚Äîa short trip to Vancouver. I went on a cruise some years ago and realized this is the best way for me to travel now. I am so appreciative of my friend going on this cruise and giving me this opportunity to embrace traveling again. I would certainly do more traveling if I had the money and a companion always ready. Having said that, I am booked on a cruise to California in September 2024. Heather‚Äôs experience: Our original booking was made by a travel agent, but she dropped us as clients and from then on, we worked strictly with Princess Cruises. I requested from the medical team for a wheelchair accessible vehicle to be at both airports to transfer me. When we arrived in Quebec City there was no wheelchair accessible vehicle there. The cruise personnel who were there to greet guests were pushing me in my wheelchair to a regular bus. When we finally got their attention for me to say I had arranged with their office for wheelchair accessible transportation they wheeled me back inside and started a big conflab with the other employees, of course, this was all in French. Eventually someone asked if I could get into a taxi ‚Äì which I could transfer myself, so they pushed me over to the taxis. An interesting incident that happened here - again the cruise employees and the taxi drivers got into another big conflab, all in French. When everything seemed settled the cruise employees left and we got into the taxi. Now the taxi driver turned to us and haltingly said, ‚ÄúNo English.‚Äù It was then we realized that in all this big conflab they had never told him where we were going - where he was taking us. I don't know much French and what I do know is very rusty - my girlfriend was raised in the states, so she doesn't know French at all. He started spewing out words until he said the word for boat which I recognized. I was so excited I said, ‚Äúyes,‚Äù ‚Äòyes,‚Äù ‚Äúyes‚Äù instead of ‚Äúoui,‚Äù ‚Äúoui,‚Äù ‚Äúoui.‚Äù When I told my girlfriend (who was looking at me very puzzled) what he had just said she also yelled out ‚Äúyes,‚Äù ‚Äòyes,‚Äù ‚Äúyes‚Äù He then said, ‚ÄúPrincess bateaux?‚Äù And again, we yelled out, ‚Äúyes,‚Äù ‚Äòyes,‚Äù ‚Äúyes.‚Äù So, this story ends up on a good note because he drove us straight to the ship! We did have an inside cabin, which I think is often the case when you need an accessible room. I liked it though, because it seemed so quiet, and we never were in there other than that morning or evening. It was bigger than the average size which was great for moving around in the wheelchair. They also had left a lot of room between the two beds which left a wide-open space again for maneuvering in the wheelchair. On board, we quickly noticed that items I had asked for from the medical team were not in our cabin. The medical team had sent me pictures of a stool which would be used in the shower. This was not the case, instead there was an attached seat you just pulled down from the wall, which was a part of the framework in the shower. However, admittedly I liked this much better because it seemed much safer. I suggest checking with your cruise line to see if they have a YouTube video of your cabin to watch beforehand to learn what exactly is in your room and how you would like it set up. This way you can prepare ahead of time. I also asked for what I thought was an M-bar or equivalent which would have helped me to get in and out of bed. The medical team had advised me they did have one, but when we asked our cabin boy about it, he said that was an entirely different item. (Unfortunately, I don't recall now what he said it was.) Again I had previously worked with my physiotherapist by pushing down on the mattress and holding onto the arms of my chair (I use a manual while traveling) to transfer myself. Although I successfully transferred myself, I feel using the M-Bar would certainly be safer. To avoid this situation, the next time I go on a cruise (which I am booked for next September 2024) I will bring my own M-Bar in my luggage. This was one thing I would say as a warning, there seems to be a lot of discrepancies or miscommunication between the ship and the medical team. Again, note my cruise was with Princess Cruises so of course with other cruise lines this may not be the case. When we disembarked in New York City it was a mad-house as 3200 passengers are basically getting off the ship at the same time. A port authority personnel started pushing us again heading towards a bus. This time when we stopped to explain that I had arranged accessible transportation, I believed there was someone waiting in the long line of taxis ‚Äì and I definitely breathed a sigh of relief that we did not have to join it. My assumption is because as we drew nearer his vehicle, he approached me and asked my name. Of note, both times Princess Cruises did provide us with a voucher for payment. In Charlottetown, PEI we were scheduled on a lighthouse tour that was listed as wheelchair accessible. However, when we arrived at the bus this was not the case. In fact, we were told there was not a wheelchair accessible bus on the island. By this time, I was frustrated enough, so using another skill from my physio, and the railings on either side of the buses entranceway I walked on. At least this time I was able to sit in the front row seats. Our tour guide with most apologetic about the vehicle not being wheelchair accessible and the tour being listed as such. She noted they will have to be more specific about what they mean when they list as wheelchair accessible. If you are pre-booking, there maybe is not much you can do to ascertain it will be wheelchair accessible, but I would check the excursion desk on the ship once you are on board to clarify this point. These may have been some rough spots, but they certainly did not dampen the cruise ‚Äì I loved it all (and would recommend cruising to others.) I loved the ports, I loved the sea days when we were just on the ship, I loved the food, and I loved the people we met. Regarding the people we met, we made dinner reservations each evening sitting at a table with several other couples so we could get to know those cruising with us. I enjoyed this because when you went about on the ship or even in a port you might see someone you had met and there would be friendly exchanges. We became very friendly with a mother and her daughter who were traveling from Norfolk, England. I will also add that the staff are exceptional at helping in any way they can. When they saw us coming, they would offer their assistance. My friend often said, ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù but that was her choice. A few times my friend left me alone, and always an employee would approach me and ask if I needed help. They had personnel whose job was to take wheelchair people, and any other person needing assistance on and off the ship. I will take a few minutes to tell you a little bit about our cruise. As previously noted, we flew to Quebec City (from Calgary, Alberta) to board the beautiful Caribbean Princess. Our first stop was the next day when we stopped in Saguenay, Quebec. The next day we sailed down the Saint Lawrence seaway to the Atlantic Ocean stopping first at Charlottetown PEI. After leaving Charlottetown we again had a sea day but that was only because it was very stormy at sea, and we could not dock at Sydney, NS. We sailed on to Halifax for our next port. That evening we crossed into American waters and docked in the morning at Bar Harbor ME. Our final port was Boston MA. And now was the final day at sea before reaching New York City.

Hello! Long story short, I am at a conference at the Westin Hotel in Ottawa. 25% of the conference rooms are only accessible via stairs or a locked elevator that can only be operated by staff at the front desk. If this was communicated to my organization ahead of time, they did not let members know in advance. Moreover, the staff is not responding to elevator requests in a timely manner. Perhaps ‚Äútimely‚Äù is a flippant statement, but we are here for a work event, not for pleasure. Individuals in my group have missed meetings due to these delays. From my understanding of disability law in Canada, this is allowed, as long as it is technically possible to access the space. (I am from the US though, so I'm just reading it off my phone). That said, my friends and I are pissed - I can do stairs, but others in my group cannot. We have petitioned to have this elevator unlocked for the duration of the conference. But is there anything else we can do in the short term, or to encourage this to happen? Buzzwords? A Canadian access law I've overlooked? A secret handshake to do with the manager? A phone number I can call and file a complaint? From what I can tell, they have no safety reason for this elevator to be closed to the public. There are many responsible for this, and I will be contacting them as I can. Looking more for short term solutions. TL;DR - The only elevator to one of the floors requires staff assistance to use. Can I do anything about this?

I read a lot of the comments here and thought it would be good to post something helpful for you all to read. Every year, I take my very elderly father and physically disabled brother and his caretaker on a get away weekend to OC Maryland. Ocean City was always my fathers favorite travel destination since he was a kid and I thought for his birthday, it would be nice to get him away for the weekend. We always bumped it up to early May in hopes for a little bit warmer weather, but Maryland is a very unpredictable weather state. We had 90oF temps in the beginning of the week, but by the time we left on Friday they were predicting highs in lower 50‚Äôs. (Not very ideal beach weather!) But we went any how. The first weekend in May is their annual Spring Fest. They close the inlet parking lot and have several circus size tents with hundreds of vendors with crafts and goodies. So let me start by saying we stay at my Aunts condo in OC. It is not labeled as ADA accessible, but since we were very familiar with the layout, we knew what to bring and what was needed. The condo has an elevator, but the location of the condo door is installed (in my opinion) on the wrong side so you have to go past the door and some how back into the door. The railing is very close to the door swing- so no room to turn around. My brother always seems to make it work and can drive his chair better then I can steer a car! Anyhow, back to OC area. The boardwalk Spring fest is extremely wheelchair friendly since it takes place on the pavement. There were scooters, walkers, wheelchair, transport chairs of very type there. Despite the cold temperatures, it was pleasant inside the tent area. We spent several hours there browsing and shopping. The next day we walked the boardwalk. The boardwalk, well, as you can imagine, made from boards‚Ä¶ so it was completely manageable for the walker and the electric wheelchair (although very bumpy and we had to keep adjusting his phone that he keeps on his lap) . There were several souvenir shops that we not accessible at all because they either had a step or two to get up or they had so much merchandise that going in would have taken out several displays and then there were the ones that appeared wide isles until you got deeper into the shop only to find we were trapped by displays that had breakable merchandise on it and isles that were too narrow to go any farther. Again, luckily for my brother, he is the king of ‚Äúreverse‚Äù and managed to get unstuck without taking out any displays! We also visited Rohobeth in Delaware on this trip and found the same issues. **Side note, the municipal parking lots in OC, MD don‚Äôt care if you have a handicap tag on it or not, they make you pay no matter what in OC. Rohobeth was free parking until May 14th We did enjoy several new restaurants this visit. In the past we found a lot of the restaurants with Picnic style tables (no wheelchair tables available) and not friendly for a 80+ year old to climb in to enjoy his meal. This year, we hit 100% on restaurants, so much so that I wan to give them a shout out. First night we ate at ‚ÄúCoin‚Äôs‚Äù. This was a local favorite that has been open for a long time in OC Maryland located near the boardwalk. They had tables and booths and a few hi tops. The tables were spaced nicely apart that we did not feel like we were blocking any of the staff or patrons. We actually hit it during Happy hour and we all had more food then we were able to eat. The second night we tried a newly renovated place (that took over an old favorite in OC - so it was an older building as well) This place was called Route 66 diner. The modifications were perfect. We sat in a very spacious area and had a wonderful waiter named Ace. He made our dining experience really nice. Although this restaurant does not allow substitutions, the amount of food and flavor was exceptional. The food came out hot and was a pleasure to eat after a very cold rainy day on the boardwalk. So if you have food restrictions (like I do) then be aware this may not be the best place for you. The last day we tried a restaurant that we passed many times in the past, but never stopped. This was the Cottage Cafe. They always looked busy, so we figured it was a good sign. Again, we were pleased to find a restaurant that was not picnic style tables. This place was probably the fanciest place we ate and the menu ranged in price all over the board from reasonable to extremely expensive. But out of the 3 restaurants the bill here was the cheapest! I enjoyed a beautiful crab cake and my brother had a crab pizza. My dad ate his gigantic fish sandwich and our caretaker had the special meatloaf and proclaimed it was the best meatloaf he ever ate. Now the weather kept us from going on the beach (which was fine by me, there is so much to do during the day that just viewing the beach from the boardwalk was good for me.) But if you were to come down during life guard season (memorial day to Labor day) They have free access to wheelchair sand chairs. You just need to leave someones drivers license while you have the chair. You can keep the chair with you while on the beach, but if someone comes and needs it as well, they will come find you on the beach and ask you to transfer so that some one else can use it to come down. Sometimes this causes an issue with trying to locate it when you need it to go back. They ask you to stay on the street that you used the chair from. This is not an issue for us because the wheelchair beach access is only one block from my aunts condo. They have tried some of those new mats that go over the sand at OC, but I believe they failed because the sand is very fine there and blows across the mats and covers them in no time. Know also that the water is extremely rough there and that even experienced swimmers can easily get into trouble quickly (my daughter, who is an excellent swimmer got pulled out in a rip tide one summer right before my eyes- very scary to witness and luckily her cousin was close enough and grabbed her out of the rip to grab her and pull her to safety). Overall, we enjoyed our off season trip to Ocean City Maryland and recommend it with some planning.

My wife and I are in the process of planning a trip to San Diego, CA, from Raleigh, NC, to visit our daughter and her husband in San Diego. Additionally, we are planning a side trip to visit a couple of National Parks, Kings Canyon and Sequoia, which we have not visited before. Planning a trip, especially those requiring air travel and visiting new places always causes some anxiety, because when traveling with special needs you are never quite sure of what you might find. My wife has secondary progressive multiple sclerosis and is no longer able to do any of the activities of daily living without assistance. She is also wheelchair bound. Especially since Covid19 it has become more difficult to arrange accessible travel. Traveling with a lot of medical equipment by air is also stressful. Making reservations in advance and checking them repeatedly is essential, both for transportation and lodging. When booking airline tickets I always ask for accessible seating and make sure we get it. It is not acceptable to be put in a seat where you cannot move and people have to climb over you to get to the restroom. Getting a wheelchair accessible room with a roll-in shower is also absolutely necessary for us. I typically make sure I have a written guarantee that the room is reserved for us and that it has all the features we need. If I have any doubt I request photos of the room and shower. Unfortunately, even with this level of preparation we have arrived at hotels (e.g., TownePlace Suites San Diego Airport/Liberty Station) and been told that the guaranteed room is not available. This trip we are going to a different hotel and hope to have a better experience. Visiting the National Parks can be extremely rewarding but here again one has to make sure that the lodging you are getting will meet your needs. On this trip we need to stay an hour‚Äôs drive outside the park to get the necessary accommodation. When visiting the parks it is a good idea to go to the park website and check on accessible activities and if necessary to call and talk with the rangers to find out about accessible activities and facilities (family accessible restrooms and accessible guided tours). Again the more preparation you do the better the experience is likely to be. Many of the National Parks now offer wheelchair accessible trails and activities. While visiting our daughter and husband in San Diego, unfortunately, we need to stay in a hotel, because their house is small and not adequately accessible for us to be there overnight. However, since we travel to see her at least annually, we have left some equipment and other items with them to lighten the load of things we have to fly with. When we arrive in San Diego we rent a car (usually a SUV or Minivan) large enough to accommodate the wheelchair, the two of us, and additional baggage. Fortunately I am able to transfer my wife from her wheelchair to a passenger seat in most SUVs or minivans. Calling ahead to restaurants, entertainment, and other places of interest is also a good idea. We like to go to museums and I usually call ahead to make sure they have an accessible restroom available. Sometimes this requires our using a staff restroom because the general restrooms are not family accessible and my wife needs assistance in the restroom. It is a good idea to go over all of your special needs and check that they can be accommodated at the places you are interested in visiting.

Hi all! Planning my first of a few trips this year. Full time manual wheelchair user, para @ L4-5 and extensively traveled. Background for understanding, and while I would love for the world to be fully accessible to me, the reality is, it never will be. Especially when you love history, and cringe at newness. üòÅ Instead of planning specific trips, I tend to go for the least expensive airplane ticket, wherever that might lead to, and plan from there. So my first trip as disjointed as it sounds, landing in Milan, Italy, overnight train trip to Marseilles, France because I've always wanted to see it. Back to Milan, short flight to Bari. Stay for a few nights, take the ferry to Dubrovnik, flight to Plovdiv for the history and to stay with friends, then to Ljubljana, flight to Zagreb and train through Austria and Northern Italy, then back to Milan. I work full-time in healthcare and despite how stressful my work is, I love the vacation time. ‚ù§Ô∏è All of this is fluid, I do already have a flex ticket for the ferry and flights into and out of Milan three-ish+ weeks apart. Are there ANY can't miss spots, accessible hotels that aren't worldwide chains, in that region that I just shouldn't miss. Challengingly accessible included. I'll find a stranger, hot, hunky dude, donkey, horse, atv vehicle or climbing gear to get me there if needed. üôÇ Thank you!

I got to Nashville in a ‚Äúdither‚Äù but the hotel I stayed at made things so much better. First my luggage was lost on the airline. The front desk had T shirts for sale, and they rummaged around in boxes until they found my size. Then they found me free toiletries. I stayed 3 days at SpringHill Suites on Athens way. The accessible room I stayed in had a lot going for it. The cab I had reserved for my business meeting the next day did not show up. The desk helped me look up another company.It was not all perfect but every time I ran into a problem the staff were willing to assist. The beds were the right height for my wheelchair. If I had needed a lift, it would have fit under the bed. The bathroom with the exception of the shower was easily accessible. The shower was in a tub, but the tub height did allow me to slide from my chair to the edge of the tub where I could use the handheld shower and bathe. The downside, the coffee table in front of the couch made it difficult to maneuver but the staff moved it for me. The free breakfast was so-so but there were scrambled eggs and sausage. The pool was closed for remodel, but they did have a wheelchair lift. This is not a luxury hotel, but I was certainly treated as well as I have been in luxury hotels.

Is there anything out of the ordinary that needs to happen in order to declare/document it? My other concern is for my chair. I"ll be bringing my super-old backup/travel chair. It cost $8000 20 years ago but probably isn‚Äôt worth $100 today‚Ä¶ except for to me it is‚Ä¶ the fact that it‚Äôs still a chair light enough for me to lift into my car on my own makes it VERY valuable to me. I don‚Äôt even know how I would go about replacing it if it were lost or damaged beyond repair. And a new wheelchair light enough for m to be able to load into my car by myself would likely still run several thousand dollars today. Any tips for making sure this is somehow covered? I‚Äôm kind of getting the feeling I‚Äôll be screwed if something happens to this backup chair just because of it depreciated value ‚Äúon paper‚Äù. I‚Äôm at a bit of a loss here. Any other provisions beyond what common sense dictates (medical, trip interruption, etc, etc) that I should be looking for?

Last week we flew from Milan to Madrid. We used Air Europa. It is a more budget airline but it has business class seating. Most budget airlines don‚Äôt. Checking in was pretty easy. The attendant asked the normal questions about battery size and could we remove them for the flight. It was not the long drawn out process we normally go through. I do walk the few steps from the door to my seat in front. My husband folded the chair, removed the batteries, and readied the chair for pick up. I made it very clear I needed the chair at the door to disembark. Wonders never cease. Our plane stopped on the tarmac and stairs were wheeled to it to disembark. The flight attendant gestured for me to just wait. I was getting antsy but had no choice but to wait. The staff was very patient. They had a truck with a lift on it drive up to the plane and my chair was on it. Another lady was there and had an airport chair waiting. They strapped us in and drove us to the entrance and lowered us down. Perfect. Another person met us at the door and took us to the baggage claim and then to the taxi stand. There are other ways to get into the city but with the chair and luggage we opted for the fixed price taxi. It cost $33 Euros and worth every penny. We stayed at the Toc Hostal near Placa Del Sol. They had double rooms as well as bunk rooms. It is in the very heart of everything. We saw the New Year at the Sol with the rest of Spain. I will warn that while the staff at the Toc Hostal were very helpful their definition of wheelchair accessible is a bit looser than mine. The sidewalk in front is very narrow. They laid down ramps for me to get in and out but I always had to walk a few steps to get inside. The staff always ran over to make sure I was in safely. They said they would talk to the owner about fixing the ramp. We didn‚Äôt use the buses as we found the places we wanted to see were walkable. Yes there are some cobblestones. But the beauty of the architecture and the warmth of the people outweighed any down sides. It was January but we found eating outside was possible and did it often. Since a lot of the older places have a step or many to enter this helped us. We visited the Prado Museum. It was a great art gallery. It was crowded and I mostly saw butts all day not artwork. It was frustrating. We went to a smaller museum the Lazaro Galdiano Museum on Carrer de Serrano. It was a hike but worth it. They had good accessibility. No tour groups standing in front of the artwork. An elevator for other floors was small but did it‚Äôs job. They also have lots of other goods to see, furniture, housewares, jewelry, armor, swords, etc. We took the subway to the Atocha station from placa del Sol early in the morning. We walked it the day before and found the route was very steep. The metro took us right to the station and was easy to use. Alas Madrid is over and the train (Iryo) whisked us off to Barcelona in under 3 hours. Our first train trip that was actually on time. There were no wheelchair seating in first class but we were told you can buy (H seats=wheelchair seating) online in 2nd class.

So we have left Nashville for Asheville so I I thought I would send a few updates. First, Hilton Garden Inn in Nashville. The room was great, big enough to move around in my power chair in both the bedroom and bathroom. Pull down seat in the accessible shower. The accessible rooms are also the first room as you get off the elevator, not the usual long hall trek. Despite the location, we did not hear people chatting as they waited for the elevator. So kudos on the sound proofing too. I have already posted about how high the bed, towel racks, amenities were. Upon checking out, Greg at the front desk shared that a guest who stayed in the accessible room one floor above me complained the bed was too low! So, should you be staying at this hotel and need the lower bed, ask for 416, higher bed, 316. I know it is confusing, shouldn‚Äôt higher bed be on the higher floor? Other tidbits. Do not go anywhere in Nashville on a Tuesday. No concerts at the Ryman on Tuesday. The General Jackson cruise on the Cumberland River is only offered at mid-day, no evening dinner cruise. No music in most off the off-Broadway locations. We were also unable to tour the gardens at the Opryland Gaylord. There is some major construction going on, and we were unable to gain access to the garden areas. Do go to Nashville on the first Wednesday of the month, many museums are free. We went to the National Museum of African American Music was terrific! There is a nice big chairlift from the entrance to museum level. The staff was young, helpful and friendly. There is an unmarked family bathroom between the men‚Äôs and ladies‚Äô rooms that is nice and large. Most of all the museum was well thought out, educational and lots of fun. In various halls dealing with different types of music and their history you can download music from various artists that will be directed to your email account so fast it will be waiting for you when you get back to the hotel.

It appears that Hilton Garden Inn no longer includes a complimentary breakfast with their room rates. Especially surprising because that is what we were offered when we booked our rooms. Moving on, we have spent the last two days getting to know Nashville. Here are things that we learned. 1) You absolutely need to wear earplugs when you walk along Broadway Street, where many of the country bars are located. The bands have their sound system amped way up so that people on the street will be lured in to buy beer by the bucket. If there is no room to go inside, you may still listen out on the sidewalk with your bucket. Each place seems to compete to see which has the loudest sound system. Many of the cars, tour buses, trolleys, pedal bars, and other vehicles have sound systems that are equally loud. 2) Many of the Grey Line Tours are wheelchair-friendly, so long as there is enough room on the bus. We took the one-hour city tour just to get the lay of the land. The double-decker bus had a portable ramp. I was not able to go up to the top deck, but I was just as happy in the air conditioning on the first level and heard the tour leader just fine. Other tours use smaller buses and you do need to reserve in advance. 3) Printers Alley, which is quite near the convention center and Broadway, offers much quieter bars/restaurants that feature blues and jazz. Getting a recommendation on which place to go to is a little harder. 4) Opryland, the Cumberland River cruises, and the Gaylord Opryland are a 20-minute drive from Nashville. We will explore there later this week. 5) The architecture of Nashville is really interesting from the historic buildings of the 1800s to the ‚ÄúBatman building.‚Äù It is really the ATT headquarters. I did not see an architectural tour of the city, but it would be fun. More later this week.

So, after a few wheelchair problems - the motor died on my chair, Scootaround did not have a chair to rent, Clouds of Love delivered a chair two hours late, left it in the driveway, and did not bother to adjust it. The chair stopped working this morning and required phone calls with two different techs to get it started. We still have to push various buttons and send a little prayer to heaven, but so far it is working. We left about 4:30 pm yesterday and, after enduring torrential rains, arrived at the Hampton Inn in Charleston, WV, a little after midnight. What a great accessible room. There was plenty of room to move around in both the bedroom and bathroom. There was a fold-down chair in the roll-in shower, and drawers that pulled out from the bathroom counter, allowing you to place your toiletries on a lower level. Had the toiletries, which are attached to the walls, been at a level a person in a wheelchair could reach, everything would have been perfect. Here we are at day 2, after a really nice drive to Louisville, KY. We are at the Embassy Suites East, near my family. Let us just say that the Hampton Inn has a few things to teach its sister hotel. There is one phone in the two-room suite. It is on a corner table near the wall. It is impossible to reach in a wheelchair. The phone jack on the wall by the desk does not work. We settled for a long cord that may trip anyone trying to get to the sofa. The bathroom and roll-in shower are not as large as it was at the Hampton Inn. The bed is much too high to transfer to, though people who need a Hoyer lift will be happy. Requests for a shower chair, a solution to the phone problem, and folks to remove the box springs or the bed frame took way too long for a staff response. We are waiting for the family to arrive so we can have dinner together. More tomorrow.

My family went to Ocean Shores Washington Saturday. I have very severe osteoarthritis in my left hip and moderate osteoarthritis in my right hip so I have great difficulty walking without help. I use walking sticks, a walker and a wheelchair depending on how far I am walking and how much room I have to maneuver. I took my sticks to the beach as my Strong Arm has a wide base but my sister found out the City of Ocean Shores has beach wheelchairs available, preferably with a reservation. My sister was able to get it for an hour and a half before the next people had a reservation. It worked really well.

There are other posts about both subjects but I couldn‚Äôt figure out how to post. Here is recent information, from March/April 2024 Traveled on 1-95 south from NC to Port Canaveral, FL for a cruise. Stayed in Avid hotel (part of IHG hotel group) in Savannah on Gateway Dr near airport. Good bed and Hoyer accessible. May be that Avid hotels and IHG hotel group have more rooms with open bed frames. I had to call 10 hotels in Savannah to find one and this is only because one of the agents researched it for me. Hotel had roll in shower and tub room arrangements. Not important for us since my wife does not use shower or toilet. Also had decent Grab and Go breakfast. Easy access from highway. I always confirm by calling the hotel, which is what Patch does if you book a room through her. In Cocoa Beach, FL, which is the closest to Port Canaveral, we had similar success at the Holiday Inn Express (also IHG hotel group). They also have open bed frames. Actually, only 1 room on the 1st floor was ADA and was taken. Plus the elevator was broken. So Ryan, front desk clerk, who uses crutches and has a neuromuscular issue and understands accessibility, actually modified a room for us on the first floor. They took out one bed entirely and moved the remaining bed from a closed pedestal to an open frame for us. Wow! Plus the included breakfast was decent. Bed height is not so much an issue for us since my wife‚Äôs Permobil chair has an elevation function. We cruised on Royal Caribbean‚Äôs Wonder of the Seas. It is a very large ship and that can be an issue for some. But it also has very accessible common areas. We booked through Debra Kerper, via Patch‚Äôs recommendation and she helped us obtain a junior ADA suite. It was huge and had built in ramps for the veranda, a roll in shower and a queen bed. Very functional and spacious. We also took the Hoyer on board. No issues getting on, but leaving was trouble, due to regulations. We had 3 different porters. One from room to gangway, one from the ship to the terminal, one from the terminal to the parking lot. Tips came in handy, but we were able to keep all our luggage and the Hoyer lift with us. Port Canaveral parking is free for modified vans and FL disabled veterans license plates, but not for regular hang tags. Hope this is helpful for someone.

My husband is a c 5/6 quadriplegic, and he uses an Invacare TDX power wheelchair. We traveled on Norwegian Bliss on a cruise to Alaska. We had a few issues with the cruise ship. First, we were given a room that we quite far from the elevators which meant we had to drive down long, narrow hallways to get to our room. The problem was that the cleaning carts were in the hallways almost constantly. He was not able to go anywhere by himself. Secondly, the trying to get from floor to floor was an issue because he can‚Äôt navigate quickly enough to beat the crowds to the elevators. Finally, we booked a tour to see Mendenhall Glacier through the cruise line. He made sure that they knew he had a power wheelchair and even sent the dimensions of his chair to make sure that they could accommodate us. When we arrived, they had no accessible transportation ready for us. So disappointed thus far with our experience. This is only day 2 of the cruise.

I wake up every day in dread of what cruel deed will be enacted by our government. The latest I've become aware of is this new rule that would turn back years of work to make federal buildings accessible. Please do comment. We only have until JUNE 15TH!! The federal Department of Energy (DOE) has issued a "direct final rule" that will eliminate a long-standing requirement of Section 504 requiring new buildings constructed with federal funds to be accessible to people with disabilities. The Department now calls this rule ‚Äúunnecessary‚Äù and burdensome.‚Äù Removing this rule would: Eliminate enforceable accessibility standards for new federally funded buildings. Allow renovations that leave out ramps, elevators, accessible restrooms, and more. Undermine the civil rights protections of Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. According to www.Regulations.gov , the final rule will be effective on July 15 of this year unless significant comments opposing the change are received by this coming Sunday, June 15. Click both links below and leave a public comment on each (your comments can be the same). Docket #1 - Go to DOE-HQ-2025-0015 and click "Comment": https://bit.ly/4kuX2R2 Docket #2 - Go to DOE-HQ-2025-0024 and click ‚ÄúComment‚Äù : https://bit.ly/4mGKgjY Your comments do not need to be long: You can simply say you oppose the elimination or weakening of the long-standing requirement of Section 504 which requires new buildings constructed with federal funds to be accessible to people with disabilities. You can also share why you oppose the proposal. Please share widely in your networks.And please comment ASAP! THANK YOU!!

My name is Judy and my husband Joe has been quadriplegic for 3¬Ω years and uses a power wheelchair. He suffered an epidural hematoma three weeks after he had cervical disk surgery, which damaged his spinal cord from C2 down. He lives at home with us and, needless to say, it has been an adjustment for our whole family. My husband is keeping upbeat and is making the best of the situation, for which I admire him! We try to stay as active as possible, going out to lunch, dinner, shows, and seeing friends, and now we have decided to take the cruise to Alaska that we have been talking about for many years. We are planning the trip for our whole family in the summer of 2025. We have three adult children and a future daughter-in-law (who will be married to our son next year), and we have two grandchildren, ages 7 and 12. It has been so helpful to read everyone‚Äôs posts about cruises. I have learned so much just from reading the information you all have posted, so thank you! I look forward to being part of this community.

accessibleGO is teaming up with one of the global leaders in professional autism & neurodiversity training and certification, The International Board of Credentialing and Continuing Education Standards (IBCCES), to host a live digital Q&A Tuesday, February 13th at 7pm ET.The event is for anyone in our community who has autism or a caregiver for someone who does. It will take place in our community forum, and it's absolutely FREE to attend. Just RSVP!IBCCES has certified 14 hotels in the United States thus far, and we've partnered to include these properties on accessibleGO.com. During this live event, we'll discuss what the IBCCES certification is, what it means for the hotels that have been certified and how our community can benefit.Our hosts will be accessibleGO's Cofounder and CTO, Jeff Schlanger, and IBCCES' President, Meredith Tekin.Meredith brings a wealth of experience cultivated over years of dedicated service in healthcare, marketing, professional development and the nonprofit sector. Her commitment to making a positive impact on the lives of neurodivergent individuals and those with disabilities led her to join IBCCES, where she plays a pivotal role in advancing its mission to support and empower professionals in healthcare, education, hospitality and tourism, public safety, and corporate sectors.Beyond her executive role, she is a passionate advocate who has shared the need and impacts of IBCCES‚Äô work on a global stage at numerous industry conferences and summits. Meredith‚Äôs commitment to fostering positive change aims at creating environments where everyone can thrive, enhancing accessibility and the quality of life for all community members.

My daughter and her fiancee are planning a trip to Atlanta Georgia in September. She is in a large power wheelchair. Unable to use arms or legs. They need an (inexpensive) hotel that is accessible. Any ideas?

For the past few years we have taken our adult children and grandsons (ages 11, 12 and 13) on NCL Caribbean cruises. This offered them all of the activities to keep them active and provided me with a ‚Äúscooter accessible‚Äù ambulatory experience. We avoided the large island all-inclusive as most are vast properties (I will never see the kids); I will have challenges navigating the distances from the room to one of the pools or restaurants. I have looked into one s with golf carts or mini-bus services but all fail on consumer ratings; fighting for beach chairs, mediocre food options. My below the knee prosthetic doesn‚Äôt lend itself to walking on beaches. And I want to have a 4-5 star resort. So my question: Do you know from personal experience an all-inclusive that can accommodate my mobility challenges? Offers activities for the teens? Is an upscale resort with consistent good reviews? I have cursorily looked at TripAdvisor and Travel & Leisure. It is an easy search if it were just my wife and I. But add in the adult children and grandsons kids and the challenge is significant. I will even entertain an extraordinary travel advisor if you know one with a proven track record. Thank you in advance.

Topsail North Carolina has rental beach front homes with elevator access that you can rent from real estate companies. Most have wooden walkways with steps that go out to the beach. Stores in town are handicap accessible. . Cheapest time to go is off season

For those who love a day among the plants and flowers, along with the butterflies this is a must. A tram that is scooter and w c accessible will drop you off at key points around the gardens. Butterfly house is seasonal. Boat ride is accessible by steps if you are able and is so worth it. . Rose garden is breath taking. Hard to say anything bad about this garden at all. Almost all areas are accessible including cafeteria. Really good food

We are a family of 3. Hubby and I are in our 70s and our adult son lives with us. Son has multiple disabilities related to childhood brain cancer. He is now 34 and uses a power chair. I have arthritis and back problems, and use a mobility scooter to cover any distance over 100 feet. Our son was able to walk until 5 years ago, so life has changed a bit since then. We used to enjoy camping, fishing, etc. but have had to modify our activities.

We‚Äôre using the code from this post on our trip and already we‚Äôre going to have help as soon as we get to the airport. I‚Äôm excited to see how it goes now some airlines call it different names so please get specific and let them know that someone is traveling with these disabilities. I‚Äôm a Blind mom with a child on the spectrum and she has IDD which stands for intellectually delayed disabilities my child functions between a three and a four-year-old level. Just an FYI In 2008, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) introduced a new code, ‚ÄúDPNA‚Äù, which stands for ‚Äúdisabled passenger with intellectual or developmental disability needing assistance‚Äù. You can use this code to book flights for passengers with autism, down syndrome, and so on hopefully this helps anyone out there who travels

I really need your ideas from your travels. My husband and I are starting to plan a trip to Europe in 2024. During the winter. We have a cruise from Miami to Southampton UK November 2nd. We return by cruise on February 2nd. That leaves us 11 weeks to vagabond around Europe. If you have been to Europe and have wonderful places, hotels, apartments or activities that someone in a wheelchair can do let me know. We are not afraid of the cold. And I have snow cleats for my chair. This is the biggest adventure of our lives and we are on a tight budget. We can go north, south, or east. We will probably be doing most of our transit via train. We may consider a car for short amounts of time to hit great but remote places. While we have traveled in Europe a lot, we have not done a lot since the chair permanent. What places have you gone to? What sites did you like best? Are there places that you would never go back to and why. We know we want to see the best Christmas market. Poland interests us. We didn‚Äôt get any time in Copenhagen but even in the summer people were saying it is best at Christmas. We did spend Christmas in Munich one year and my husband loved it. Any feedback is welcome.

My husband and I would really like to resume travel now that we are mostly post-Covid. In preparation for resuming travel, we bought a MAJESTIC IQ-7000 Remote Controlled Electric Wheelchair with the automatic folding option last June, and while it‚Äôs a really comfortable ride for my husband, I‚Äôm the one who has to get it in and out of the back of our SUV. And since it weighs 57 lbs. without the battery, I can‚Äôt lift it by myself. After trying several different options ‚Äì trailer with ramp (too heavy for me to maneuver), then ramps (again, too heavy for me to maneuver), then I spent $1,100 for a Go-Lite Portable Mini Lift, but it is still cumbersome and difficult to get the collapsed wheelchair onto it because when the lift is fully collapsed, it is still 9 inches off the ground. My husband is unable to help me so it‚Äôs all up to me. I‚Äôm 72 and not very strong. So we made the decision recently to try to sell the wheelchair & lift and buy a lightweight scooter that comes apart into 4-5 sections with the heaviest section being no more than 30-34 lbs. That much I can lift by myself. We‚Äôve identified a few models that fit the bill, but we must sell the wheelchair and lift, and try to get maximum dollar to put towards the scooter. I‚Äôve looked at Facebook Marketplace, but I doubt we‚Äôll get anything close to what they are worth. Is there not a good aftermarket for these items? I just don‚Äôt know where to turn. I‚Äôd love some advice from you knowledgeable folks on this forum.

My husband is looking at replacing his mobility scooter (it‚Äôs a Golden that comes apart but is very heavy) with a foldable wheelchair. We‚Äôve been looking at the MagShock Fold and Go chair or the Airhawk. Anyone have suggestions on which is better? We are planning a trip to the UK for the summer of 2023 and would like to be able to take it with us. Thank you!

I have been asked to be an advisor on this site. I am honored. But now I have to talk about myself, not so easy. I broke my back and neck on 1999. It took them a year to finally find the breaks. I had metal put into my neck to keep my head on in 2002 and again with upgrades in 2016. It mean I can‚Äôt swivel my head much. They did this surgery only because my spinal column was closing. Due to a genetic issue I am veery prone to blood clots. So Docs will only do surgery if something is life threatening. I did vey well and traveled a lot while I could. The past 5 years things have worsened. I refuse to let it stop us from traveling. I travel with a Fold&Go motorized wheelchair. Last year we took our 16 year old grandson to Europe for 3 weeks. We have taken cruises to the Baltics and to Alaska. This year we are taking a cruise to UK. We then are going to be vagabonds for almost months. We will cruise back to the US in Feb 2025. We are very budget minded travelers. I welcome any and all questions. Travel is part of my DNA.

We are almost done our two week road trip from PA to Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. We are having an amazing vacation. Today we will be going to two special towns that inspired to famous people, Walt Disney's Marceline and Mark Twain's Hannibal both in Missouri. Both towns have interesting museums. We also get to see the Mississippi River which is always cool. We are Betsy and Chet and our oldest son, Alex. For 33 years we thought Alex, had nonverbal autism, intellectual disability, ADHD, and Pica but recent genetic testing told us that Alex also has Phelan McDermid Syndrome. Our videos, Goal 1: Joyful Life are based on our family's journey and strategies we use to improve the quality of our life through meaningful leisure experiences. It is our hope to reach our number one goal of having a joyful life and to help others reach that goal too. We are hoping that our videos will encourage everyone to get out and have fun. If you want to join us on more adventures please subscribe. We will be making a video on Catoctin Wildlife Preserve in Maryland, USA soon. In June we will be going to Japan for three weeks and renting a camper van from Japan Campers. Here‚Äôs the link:

We are Hilton people. Love the Doublrtrees. This one was very disappointing and their customer service was horrible! Supposedly a suite Room with the bed and TV. No towels the next day either. Day staff absolutely miserable and uncaring. Hotel manager snippy, defensive and uncaring. Claims the pictures on the website shows the room. Not exactly. Only stay here if you have absolutely no other choice!
