Looking for a pet friendly three bedroom hotel or Airbnb in Orlando Kissimmee area with roll in shower that I can stay in for a few months over the winter. Any suggestions?

London was amazing I am sure. I spent all but a couple of hours in my hotel room. My husband found me a new wheelchair in Birmingham. He took a train ride up there and they treated him well. ETECH Mobility met him, showed him what they had, threw in a couple of free upgrades at less then half the cost of my old chair. It has twice the power, has never run out after hours of wandering the cities. If mine ever breaks again I‚Äôm going to go back there and get another. We stayed in the Z Hotel Covent Garden. A reasonably priced hotel in the heart of the city. We have booked to spend our last couple of nights there in January. Small room but great bathroom. Our best train experience so far has been on the Eurostar from London to Brussels and then on another Eurostar train to Cologne. It was organized, with someone to lead me to where I had to go, go me on the lift to the train, met me in Brussels and got me on the next train. seamless. If you want to use the Eurostar call them and book early. It saves a good chuck of change.

I am going to Rome Italy in October of this year. I am looking for a very handicap hotel in Rome I will have a wheel chair so also need a shower that has access. Please advise if anyone has a hotel they used and was satisfied with also need access to restaurant and lounge Thanks in advance Fred

Krakow, Poland has been on our list of places to visit for a long time. I researched the heck out of it for over a year. The historic center is fairly small and easy to manage. We have been to Gdansk before and found the Polish people to be very nice and happy. So off we went with high expectations. Krakow is beautiful. It is more reasonably priced than many European cities. Now to the reality for wheelchair bound travelers‚Ä¶ Krakow is not set up for wheelchairs. Despite all the research and assurances we found it impossible. When we needed something in a store my husband had to go in and buy it while I sat out in the cold waiting. Almost every store, restaurant, and museum had steps going inside of it. We went up the steep hill to the castle as I was assured it was wheelchair accessible. It might have been but the entire wc entrance was closed for construction. That evening we walked all over trying to find a place to eat dinner. We found 1. We ate dinner and then discussed our options. We stayed at the Campanile Hotel. It was very adequate. All except the absence of a curb cut in front of the hotel to reach it. But we could live with going the long way around every day. Clean, reasonably priced and accessible. They agreed to letting us out of our reservation for a one day charge. My husband ran to the train station to get tickets out the next day. He bought tickets to Vienna. So we pack back up and leave Krakow after three nights. At the train station we are informed it is impossible for me to get on the train with the tickets they sold us (mu husband knows to specify wheelchair access). I had to get out of the chair, climb 3 hard steps into the train, but we boarded. I can now also vouch for the crappy 2nd class seats on the Czech train. Luckily it was a direct train so no making a connection. I can recommend Krakow for the people and the beauty but I can not say it was okay for wheelchairs.

Hello, my name‚Äôs Julian Phillips and I‚Äôm a UK architect responsible for a brand new disabled friendly riad in the old town in Marrakech, a few minutes from the main square. Unusually for Marrakech, the riad‚Äôs accessible by taxi to within a few metres of the front door and internally there‚Äôs a lift with access to every floor, as well as level thresholds throughout, walk in showers and friendly, attentive staff. Marrakech‚Äôs old town, including the main square, is in fact entirely flat and without kerbs, so is surprisingly accessible. We can cater for individual travellers or groups of up to eight people, and we can also arrange tours as required. If this appeals to anyone, please reply and I‚Äôd be delighted to explain more.

From a member of our community: Before we go on our next cruise, I wanted to get some advice about cruise excursions. We normally go on Royal Caribbean or Norwegian. With Norwegian we've normally gone out of New York. The cruise ships have no idea at all what the accessibility is on excursions at their ports. The last cruise, we were at Bermuda. Nobody could tell us how far it was to walk to the beach, if we could go on the glass bottom boat with a scooter, if the boat had steps and if it had steps, a railing? Absolutely nobody from The Cruise line knew. My husband and I would like to enjoy some excursions but without knowing what we're dealing with beforehand, it's just not doable. I would love to go back to Bermuda. I was always a beachgoer but can no longer walk on the sand due to a neuromuscular disease. I didn't even know if I could get on a tram or walk to the beach which would be the highlight of my trip. So, I would like to know about Bermuda excursions but also about other cruise ships, mostly Norwegian and Royal Caribbean because they are most affordable for us. I am a Travel Agent who specializes in cruises. I have stayed in many Homewood Suites but this, by far, is the worst experience I have ever had. I have mobility issues and reserved an ADA accessible stateroom with roll in shower. Check in time was 3:00pm. We arrived at 4:30pm and our room was not ready. The wait was 30 minutes but knowing that on a Sunday the hotel is full with cruise passengers getting to the cruise port, we understood. We received our keys and then went to the elevator. I use two canes for walking and although I can walk I can only walk short distances. We went to the second floor heading to Room 227. We walked and walked and walked. My back was screaming at me and I had to stop to give it a rest. When we reached our room I could not believe the absolutely ridiculous lay out. This was a studio suite. It was quite large and could easily accommodate a wheelchair or scooter. There was a love seat with a coffee table that faced the bed from one end of the room but no TV. The TV was on a wall facing the bed. Therefore, I could not sit in a comfortable sofa but moved a hard chair over to the bed area to watch TV. There was no room at the bed end to place a comfortable chair. We discovered an elevator closer to the room (the room was at the rear of this large building). When we down to the first floor from that elevator the door outside had a curb. Therefore, someone in a wheelchair could not use that door. There was no ramp. I can only imagine the fear for a person in a wheelchair staying in this room in the event of a fire. When I spoke with the Manager she told me that the King Bed Accessible Suites were all at the back of the building and there were 3 or 4 on each floor. If you had a two Queen bed room, there were a couple closer to the main lobby. I would not stay there again nor would I ever consider booking a client with mobility issues into this hotel

U.S. Access Board Webinar: Accessible Transient Lodging | As the summer vacation season is well underway, traveling and lodging is essential to everyone, including people with disabilities. The next webinar in the U.S. Access Board's free monthly series will take place Thursday, July 6from 2:30 ‚Äì 4:00 p.m. (ET) and address requirements in the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Architectural Barriers Act (ABA) Standards for hotels, motels, and other types of transient lodging facilities. Presenters will discuss the required number and dispersion of compliant guest rooms and suites with mobility and communication features. Additionally, they will review accessibility requirements for guest accommodations, such as sleeping areas, bathrooms, kitchens and kitchenettes, storage, signage, fire alarms, and phones. Other common amenities, such as check-in counters, fitness centers, swimming pools and spas, bars and restaurants, and conference rooms, will also be covered. For more information or to register, visit Great Lakes ADA Center‚Äôs Accessible Transient Lodging webinar webpage. All webinars include video remote interpreting (VRI) and real-time captioning. Questions can be submitted in advance of the session or can be posed during the live webinar. Webinar attendees can earn continuing education credits. The webinar series is hosted by the ADA National Network in cooperation with the Board. Archived copies of previous Board webinars are available on the site.

Some grips associated with travel with a severe walking impaired wife A. Book hotel stays directly with the facility to assure that room has the assists that are critical to you. Booking agencies lie about handicap facilities, and you have no recourse on arrival. B. Travel with a toilet booster seat. Standard toilet heights are too low for 6 foot frame to get up. Wife without leg muscles would need an emt team to get her off a standard seat. C. Why is it there is always a fully mobile female in the handicap stall talking on the cell phone when wife is waiting to get in. D. Keep a 4 inch ramp in your vehicle for scooter travel. For some reason normal people do not consider a 4 inch door sill is a problem. C. Gather the tour bus programs and use them to plan your trip independently with a rental car. Go at your own chosen speed

The following is a law in Maryland. ¬∑ MD - Annotated Code of Maryland ¬∑ BUSINESS REGULATION ¬∑ TITLE 15. LODGING ESTABLISHMENTS ¬∑ SUBTITLE 2. RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF INNKEEPERS ¬ß 15-208. Accessible rooms for individuals with disabilities -- Bed height. (a) In this section, "accessible room" means a room in a lodging establishment that is required to be in compliance with the transient lodging requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act. (b) Subject to subsection (c) of this section, each accessible room in a lodging establishment shall be furnished with a bed that: (1) measures at least 20 inches but not more than 23 inches high from the floor to the top of the mattress, whether or not the mattress is compressed; and (2) has at least a 7-inch vertical clearance under the bed for lift access. (c) (1) Beginning December 31, 2021, each lodging establishment shall furnish at least 25% of the lodging establishment's accessible rooms with a bed that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. (2) Beginning December 31, 2022, each lodging establishment shall furnish at least 50% of the lodging establishment's accessible rooms with a bed that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. (3) Beginning December 31, 2023, each lodging establishment shall furnish at least 75% of the lodging establishment's accessible rooms with a bed that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. (4) Beginning December 31, 2024, each accessible room in a lodging establishment shall be furnished with a bed that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. Please take it to a legislator in your state and see if you can get it passed.

I just wanted to introduce myself. My name is Jessie and I have been following Accessible Go for a few years now. I love to travel and always have! I became an amputee about 10 years ago. For a while I would say, ‚ÄúWhen mom gets better, we will travel again.‚Äù Unfortunately, I am still unable to use a prostheses so I chose to switch that narrative. I started traveling again and finding ways to make it work. The world is definitely not always super accessible but usually there is a way to get there. I am a mom to two teenagers, 13 and 15, who play a ton of sports and also have a love of travel like their mom. My daughter plays high level club softball so we travel around the country to go to different tournaments. I also love to go check out new places with them. This year was their first trip out of the country but it definitely won‚Äôt be our last. I have had the mindset of YOLO these past few years so we travel whenever we are able to. I also love to document our trips and advocate for places that are accessible or show things that may not be accessible for others. I was so excited to be asked to be an advisor for Accessiblego! I look forward to working with them more and being able to help others that also want to travel more places!

Hi, my husband, and I would live to travel more. But find it very difficult when motels, say they have handicap rooms. And their beds are all closed in around the bottom of the bed. The reason is my husband is a quad and uses a portable lift to transfer him into the bed. which requires open area under the bed so the lift can roll under the bed for the transfer. I always have to call the motels in the area of where we choose to stay and ask them this question, does your handicap room have a bed on legs? You will be surprised how many motels say no. So, for us we don‚Äôt get to choose a motel we would like to stay in, but a motel maybe of lesser quality as it is open underneath. Most of the handicap rooms we have stayed in have the handicap bathroom. but since my husband is a Quad he only uses the sink. Also would like to mention. I prefer no carpet in the rooms as it is difficult for his lift to roll on carpet. He is 6‚Äô1. 185 lb. If anyone every comes across a nice motel on the east coast that has beds on legs, please keep us in mind. I think this is a great website to refer to.

Marianne Bitner I am very excited to be one of your accessibleGo Forum Travel Experts. So as a means of introduction to all of you ‚Äúhere is my story.‚Äù I am a retired firefighter/paramedic that worked 39 years in a career I loved. But, this career started my disabilities, and I now suffer from serious mobility issues. Traveling has always been my go-to or happy place. My parents, brother and I always traveled. When I married and had my two children (Jason and Patricia) we always traveled too. I was always the planner for the trips and it‚Äôs my specialty. Additionally, I so enjoy meeting new people. If you ask my friends or family, they say I can talk to anyone from the President/CEO of a company to the janitor. I can sit quietly on a bench at the beach or airport waiting area just people watching. Many people with disabilities find traveling difficult and give up, but with planning and finding the right tour operators, ‚ÄúYou Can Still Travel Safely and have Fun.‚Äù You can do it solo, with friends/family or with a group. Let‚Äôs share our ideas, tricks, tips and travel adventures that we did with disabilities or plan to do.

Hi, my husband uses a power wheelchair (post polio/chronic pain). We are once again about to drive down to Berkeley, CA, for another visit to see our third grandchild. Ideally, we would love to be able to stay at an AirB&b but they are nigh to impossible to find for someone in a power wheelchair. You are all familiar with the usual problems‚Ä¶steps either to entryways or somewhere inside, bathrooms and/or bedrooms not large enough to accommodate a power wheelchair, showers too small, etc. And yet staying at a hotel becomes cost prohibitive after a few nights. Does anyone have additional ideas or know of any possibilities? We are planning to stay there around the second to third week in July, a total of about 10 days. We‚Äôll be driving down in our mobility van. Thanks for any suggestions. Rebecca B.

My hubby suffered an aortic dissection December 2018 and is considered a ‚Äú2%‚Äôer‚Äù for 98% of those afflicted with acute dissection don‚Äôt make it to the hospital much less through lengthy surgeries, hospital stays and comorbidities like his kidneys failing and brain damage from extended lack of bloodflow to both. He has a 5# lift/push/pull limitation for life - meaning, even when his mobility is lessened due to various situations like gout flares or venous insufficiency - he can‚Äôt use a cane, walker or manual wheelchair. He can‚Äôt drive, can‚Äôt climb stairs, can‚Äôt pull himself in/out of beds. So countless times we arrive somewhere to find a long stair passage we didn‚Äôt expect or dangerous bathtubs and - most recently at a resort in Pensacola, FL - the beds were so high neither of us could get in them. So the maintenance staff had the bright idea to remove the box springs while we were out to dinner. Hubby could sit on and collapse into the pillowtop mattress, and it was heartbreaking watching him try to figure out how to get out because the wood bedframe wouldn‚Äôt let him after he‚Äôd sunken into the mattress. Imagine our dismay as he‚Äôd taken his diuretic calling for multiple bathroom trips overnight, so urinal/catheter was our only option except for the times I hoisted him myself from behind, giving him a butt-boost while assuring his arms were crossed over his chest and he didn‚Äôt try to lift/pull his body weight out. Booking cruises is challenging for we‚Äôve learned we can‚Äôt book most river cruises for there‚Äôs no dedicated dock and they often raft up 2-5 in a row away from the dock so passengers have to step down/up into multiple boats to get ashore or back to your river cruiser. Ocean cruises that have excursions may tender into ports and even though we ask about it, we find we can‚Äôt get in/out or safely travel on the small tenders ashore. We‚Äôve figured out how to handle the mandatory muster sessions, etc. Depending on tides, the steep ramps are treacherous and trying to get staff to make the wheelchair lift accessible to someone who is not in a wheelchair is not easy. Booking flights we have to ensure we don‚Äôt load or unload on the tarmac with steep metal stairs/ramp, and we always use credit card-earned miles to fly Business or 1st Class for he can‚Äôt tolerate most of the coach seating situations. I want us to live til we die and create memories while we can. But planning/booking travel so he can get the most enjoyment out of it is very difficult‚Ä¶again - especially because his disabilities are mostly not visible. But add his cognitive deficits to his physical limitations and it can be exhausting. He loves the outdoors - hiking, etc, and I hope this site will help us in myriad ways. So I look forward to exploring this site!

From a member of our community: My husband is in a manual wheelchair and it is often hard to find a truly accessible place to stay when we travel. Alex‚Äôs airbnb rental was perfect from the roll under sink to the handheld showerheads in the roll-in shower and the tub (with grab bars). There is plenty of turning radius in the bathroom and living space. Although there was carpet, my husband said it was easy to roll over. The elevators were frequent and the location on the Strip was great. The hotel is connected to the Bellagio which has a free accessible tram to Park MGM. There is no tram through NY NY, but it does pick back up at Excalibur and goes down to Mandalay Bay. We saw Michael Jackson One performed by Cirque Du Soleil at the Mandalay Bay. We purchased accessible seats and they gave my husband the option to transfer into a rotating chair or to stay in his. They stored his wheelchair and brought it before the show ended. Since it was winter, we did not check out the pool, gym or spa. This is only a review for Alex‚Äôs rental. When I reviewed the hotel in general, it appears the standard bathroom layout had the toilet swapped with the roll in shower. https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/14733635?s=51

My wife and I leased a very large accessible van in Italy for 2 weeks in 2023, it fit me & my power wheelchair in the back and 7 other passengers. New Member Introduction I am happy to be a newbie in this community! My name is Georgette. I am a retired teacher of 32 years. My husband of 46 years retired in 2019. We built a new retirement home and moved to Delaware in January of 2020‚Ä¶right before the pandemic. My health issues are varied: polymyalgia rheumatica, lymphedema, lipodema, diabetes type 2, COPD, hypertension, and obesity. All of them contribute to my limited mobility. My biggest problem is trying to travel with my husband without putting too much on him. He is a very supportive care giver for me at home. We have gone on several cruises before the pandemic. However, my mobility has worsened since then. So when we took a Disney Cruise a few weeks before Christmas with my daughter, son-in-law and grandchildren, the reality of my ability to travel and enjoy it, really came into focus. We thought we had all of our bases covered: We contacted Disney‚Äôs disability service and planned for all we could think of); ordered a scooter to be at the dock; flew first class to Orlando the day before embarking; stayed in a handicapped room in the hotel in the airport (really great hotel), signed up for the Disney bus with lift to take us to the port. (We were told I could use the lift with a walker. But this was not true.) What were the challenges of our trip? Our first challenge was planning for the trip‚Ä¶ airplane, hotel, disability needs, etc. The second challenge was figuring out how to pack all the equipment that we needed to bring: 2 c-paps, portable walker, compression machine and compression boots. The third challenge was packing everything in the least amount of suitcases. What ruined our trip? The scooter we ordered had a malfunctioning battery. It seemed fine until we began going up the ramp to the ship. The scooter was always on yellow or red no matter how much we charged the battery! Needless to say, I was unable to attend most events on the ship and was unable to visit Nassau. When we did try to venture out, my husband tried using this huge wheelchair that hardly fit going through the hallways! He was exhausted from tending to my needs. I couldn‚Äôt get into bed without his help and I needed help in getting up from the couch in our room. The final straw was that a wheelchair assistant who didn‚Äôt want to take me in the airport ended up ramming my knee into a line pole in the TSA line! So, my husband is feeling we shouldn‚Äôt plan any more cruises. Thank you so much for reading this long post and allowing me to vent. I welcome any suggestions, support, and helpful feedback that you may have.

My husband is hemiplegic, in a wheelchair full-time. At home we‚Äôve started slide board transfers to and from bed, but he‚Äôs 220# to my 115# so when traveling, I feel safer with Hoyer lift. The bad: I always call hotels, describe Hoyer lifts, specifically say that a platform bed will NOT work. I need the legs of the lift under the bed. I ask the person to measure the height from the floor to make sure the wheels slide under. Two different people assured me the ADA room met my specification and both measured the space under the bed at 6‚Äù. We got there and EVERY SINGLE ROOM IN THE HOTEL HAS A PLATFORM BED. After escalating my complaint 3 times and hearing: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never had this request before! It‚Äôs a unique need.‚Äù We did get reasonable compensation. The good: Everything else about the room was perfect for us My husband‚Äôs chair has a lift feature and the bed top was between the lowest and highest settings so he was able to slide board down both getting in and out of bed. Key card allowed both manual and automatic open and the door opened fully for for a long time. Low and high peep hole Room for wheelchair to move around. End tables that I could move to a better position so they were out of way for slide board transfer. Little table that was perfect for holding nighttime urinals A big rolling table that was great for breakfast or working, easy to slide under or slide it over to us. Nice roll in shower with very stable drop down seat, grab bars, and wand. (Next time I‚Äôll ask if there‚Äôs a mirror image room so the grab bar is on right not left.) Roll under sink. I didn‚Äôt pay attention to whether the mirrors tilted enough. I use Hoyer to take him to toilet and there was plenty of room to do this AND close the door. Lots of open space in hotel breakfast area to maneuver. (But they are short staffed, so don‚Äôt eat there if you are in a hurry.) Great Sunday brunch at McGinty‚Äôs Pub and they went out of their way to find a table where leg rests didn‚Äôt bump a table post. Van accessible parking spot is right next to hotel entrance on 5th floor of garage. I didn‚Äôt need help (because I use the Hoyer as a dolly) but they said they would send someone out if I asked. Great location: farmers market, pedestrian only downtown area, library (with grandkids) all < 500‚Äô from hotel door.
Anyone been to Japan? We figure that be a great time to travel there as the accessible would be at its prime there to travel. Also been to Disney Tokyo also? Looking forward to your reply‚Äôs!!

On a recent stay in London, my wife and I wanted to visit friends in Cotswold (near Bath) but were shocked what the cost of hiring a driver/car to transport us. Our friends suggested we take the train (Great Western Rail) from Paddington Station to our destination, and it would be eminently affordable. It was. However, having traveled in both France and Italy by train (prior to my amputation) I thought it would be a nightmare. I did some online research before the trip and discovered that the British have instituted an incredible infrastructure to assist mobility challenged people to get from the curb on the street to one‚Äôs seat on the train seamlessly! How it worked: I made a reservation and purchased our train tickets (and selected our seats). Then I made an online reservation with their FREE TRAVEL ASSIST service. In their words: ‚ÄúPassenger Assist allows you to request an assistance booking in advance . Any train company can organize assistance for your entire journey, even if you are travelling on multiple services. Passenger Assist includes: offering a helping hand to navigate the station (even offering a golf cart and driver from the taxi stand outside) help getting on or off the train meeting you from your train and taking you to your next train or the exit arranging a ramp on or off your train assistance relating to a non-visible impairment carrying your bag(s) ‚Äì up to 3 items of luggage as per the National Rail Conditions of Travel ‚Äù We arrived by taxi and there was a glass enclosed Passenger Assist waiting area, clearly marked, right at the taxi drop off point, I use a rollator, and we had one bag. We entered, identified ourselves and checked in. Moments later a golf cart-like vehicle arrived (they call it a ‚Äúbuggy‚Äù) and they transported us up and down ramps, across the huge station, through special access gates right to our train car; helped me onto the train and to my seat; loaded our luggage; folded my rollator and POOF‚Ä¶done. When we arrived at Chippenham Station out in the countryside, we were met and off-loaded and assisted all the way to our friend‚Äôs vehicle in the car park. Same service returning! This is light years ahead of any country, including the U.S., in accessibility travel assistance.

From a community member: Some people like me only have use of one hand which means that in hotels and public bathrooms they need to have the bar on one side. This should be generally recognized as a serious access issue for some people. In my case I need the bar on the left side because my right hand does not work at all. I think that this should be a requirement for all establishments that provide the level of accessibility and that this need should be reflected in the ADA and in similar state codes. It is also a condition that I think should be included in the way you make accessibility recommendations.

In response to the posting about Hampton Inns (owned by the Hilton organization), my husband and I just came back from an extensive (16 day) road trip to San Francisco and LA, staying in 7 hotels. The two Hilton hotels (both Hilton Garden) were the most disappointing, in terms of their accessibility ‚Äúamenities.‚Äù My husband is in a power WC and requires two minimum items: a toilet he can transfer to and from and a firm bed. Neither of the Hilton hotels had a raised toilet. Although we had a seat extender with us, it would not fit because both toilets were also oval. So my husband had to go down to the disabled restroom in the lobbies, which happened to be round, with his boxed extender, in order to use the toilet. I doubt if we will stay at a Hilton hotel again. The other hotels were Holiday Inn Express, which met the requirements, and the Renaissance Inn at the LA Airport, which was superlative. One other issue, which is almost a requirement, is that there needs to be enough space on both sides of the bed so that my husband can easily transfer to and from the WC to the bed. Unfortunately, the second Holiday Inn Express (in Eugene, OR) did not provide that. So, to sum it up, yes, much more needs to be done re accessibility in hotels. We spent a lot of money for less than adequate service. I think only a public raising of awareness of this lack will lead to any improvement. Happy traveling, Rebecca Bell

Have you ever dreamed of going on a luxury safari with friends or family, but worried about accessibility? Stop dreaming‚Äîit‚Äôs all here at Ximuwu Safari Lodge! Flying with a power chair is probably one of the stressful events you will ever experience. I know because I have been doing it for over 25 years and it does not get any easier. But until they can send me up in a rocket to wherever I have to go, the airlines and I are stuck with each other. What else can I do? Stay home? On the other hand, with a root canal they put to sleep during the whole time, nobody cares about your shoes and you don‚Äôt have to worry about missing connecting root canals. Do‚Äôs and don‚Äôt of flying: Top rule: Don‚Äôt do it! Taking the train or bus is so much more relaxing when your chair is always with you. But, if you insist. When you check-in, tell them the combined weight of you and your chair and suggest that you wheel right up to the cabin door. Trust m`e, nobody wants to push 430 pounds through a busy airport. If you want someone to escort you to get you to the gate, ask. Personally, I find they just slow me down. At the gate, show the crew how to engage and disengage the brakes on both sides if applicable. Tell them to engage the brake the while in flight. Insist that your joystick and footrests be removed and taken on board. If not, tell them these parts are extremely fragile and tell them they WILL be damaged if not. If necessary, emphasize that this is a highly specialized piece of equipment and personalized to meet your unique needs. It cannot be rented and the local wheelchair dealer is likely closed or don‚Äôt stock the parts. Your vacation will over before it starts. DO TRY REMOVING THE PARTS AT HOME FIRST! There is no time for surprises just before your flight. Remove any ties keeping cords in place. It very hard to cut ties when the sharpest object the crew, including the pilot, has is a car key. If you need some, bring some spares. I have never had to resort to this, but if they refuse to cooperate, tell them you‚Äôre not getting on that plane and to take your luggage off the plane because it has essential items. See how fast they change their minds. If you have dry-cell batteries, there is no need to remove them. When the joystick is disconnected, there is no live circuit. Reinstalling the batteries can be problematic. I have a 100% survival rate when my batteries are left intact Make clear that your chair shall not be put on its side when being loaded. If they ask why not, ask them what do you they think would happen is they flipped their car on its side. If your chair is damaged, go to Customer Service and file a damage claim. There is a central agency. Scootaround, that handles claims for over 30 airlines. I have never had a claim disputed. Remember: stay calm, speak with authority and always remember when it comes to the handling of your chair, you always have the last word Good Luck!Stephen

Hi everyone, It‚Äôs Pinky; one of your Forum Moderators. Welcome to my long awaited New Pinky‚Äôs Accessible Adventures Diary Series (P.A.A.D.); a new feature here on the Forum. Each week I will be focusing on a single day‚Äôs worth of accessible activities, lodging and travel from one of our exploratory trips to the Caribbean. It is my hope that through what we have learned, we can help others plan their own adventures. I am not your typical traveler when it comes to following ‚Äúthe rules‚Äù about what we‚Äôve been told we can do and not do when it comes to traveling in a wheelchair. When I first became disabled and decided to return to traveling, I was never satisfied with the fact that in the few places with official accessible excursions; we were typically remanded to boring bus or ferry tours, where all I could do was sit there and just watch this exotic land zip by me in blur of tropical colors. That wasn‚Äôt enough for me and I was sure there was more out there for us in the Caribbean to participate in; I just needed to do some of my own homework before arriving to ensure a fantasy vacation for everyone, including myself. But what good is just keeping all this information to myself, when I know there are others out there who have hesitated taking that trip to a Caribbean island because of the same fear of boredom? Although I spend an extended amount of time in St. Maarten/St. Martin, every year, I just got back from another Dutch Caribbean vacation that blew me away and I had to start with that island (we will get back to St. Maarten/St. Martin next trip review). Accessible Curacao Overhead Curacao Beach Day 1 I wasn‚Äôt sure at first if it was going to be important to share with you the flying portion of this trip, as I usually have a very smooth trip when I fly directly from Newark to St. Maarten; however this time I had to fly through Miami on a different airline and based on what happened; I needed to share so you can prepare yourself for this possibility. In case you didn‚Äôt know already, most flights to the Caribbean go out of Miami or the New York City Area; so if you plan to fly from anywhere else in the country, be prepared for a stop along the way. It pains me to have to speak negatively about the Miami Airport because I grew up there and it was my favorite airport as a child; but if you have flown there in the last decade, then you know how overcrowded and understaffed it has become for the size crowd flying through there. This isn‚Äôt meant to scare you, but you need to be prepared, especially if your a chair user or traveling with anyone with disabilities. Miami International AirportTypically you set up with your airline any specialized specific needs you may have for traveling and then they arrange with a 3rd-party company in each of the airports you are traveling through to provide those requested services. Now if you have checked your wheelchair for the flights, be prepared that they may just take it to the next plane for you and provide you with inter-airport wheelchair transportation instead. This is the one airport I am going to tell you ‚ÄúNOT‚Äù to do it that way. Instead, tell the gate agent at your original departure check-in that you would like your chair brought to you in Miami and you re-check it in for your next flight. Otherwise you will have a nightmare experience with the 3rd party wheelchair company in the Miami Airport and could risk missing your connecting flight‚Ä¶trust me on this one (too long a story to explain). Plus, on your way home you will want your own chair as you will have to first go through customs, immigration and re-check in with ticketing and TSA before being able to get on your connecting flight(s) home (the whole time at the mercy of being pushed around in that horrific airport transfer chair). Once on the connecting flight to your island; just kick back and relax because they always seem to take great care of you on the islands in the airports. JetBlue now has Lie-Flat Seating for Mint class to Caribbean if neededAs you can tell, my Miami Airport portion didn‚Äôt go well; but once we were in the Air, everything else went smoothly for the flight and in a few hours we were landing on this beautiful island that was being held completely hostage by transparent tropical blue waters around the entire outer edges. The Curacao airport was modern and clean and was so smooth for traveling through. We rented a normal car from Hertz at the Airport, but I did discover there is a rental car company on the island with Accessible vehicles to rent (Emma Rentals); who will either meet you at the airport with the vehicle or bring it to your hotel for you. Make sure to get good directions too before leaving the airport, or you will get lost trying to find your way around; unless you‚Äôre good with Dutch street signs. Arrivals in Curacao‚Ä¶so lovely. Dolphin Suites and Wellness Hotel When I first heard there was a fully-accessible hotel in Curacao, I was a big doubter; because who‚Äôs ever heard of something like that? However the same amazing team who developed the Curacao Dolphin Therapy and Research center on the island (See Day #2 of Curacao), also designed a hotel that addressed the needs of travelers with disabilities (of all types) and their families. Instead of thinking of it as an Hotel with Accessible rooms, think of more of a hotel that just happens to think-out ahead of time, how to best suit the needs of travelers with ALL levels of abilities; and offer them a hotel like no-other in the world. We pulled into the parking lot of the Dolphin Suites and Wellness Hotel late on Sunday evening and were just ready to collapse from the trip, but when you first roll into the lobby of the Dolphin hotel; you instantly feel this overwhelming sense of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm home‚Äù wash over you and feel the serotonin start flowing as you realize everything this hotel was designed with you mind and not some missed oversight. Hotel EntranceThe front office manager gave us a quick tour of the ground and first floor where we could find the two pools (1 with lift chair), island information and tour area, family BBQ dining (they will even pre-order your supplies), rental beach wheelchairs, the library and several lounge areas. There are ramps from the first to the second floor and the entire mid-rise hotel is serviced by an elevator. We were asked if we needed help with our luggage to our room, but my spouse likes to show off how strong he is when we travel by being our luggage wrangler; so we carried our own luggage up to our 2-bedroom suite with an ocean view on the 3rd floor. Lobby Front DeskYou almost take it for granted and don‚Äôt notice when first wheeling into the giant suite that everything is set up for your wheelchair to access. (Not like some hotels in the U.S. who call their rooms accessible, but basically give us a few extra feet around the bed or wider bathroom doors for our wheelchairs). You can‚Äôt even call it a hotel room because it felt more like a private apartment, with almost a full kitchen(which they will also pre-stock prior to arriving for you with food and groceries), large living room and a huge balcony with gorgeous ocean views. Seriously, I was ready to move in. My spouse had to stop me from literally making laps through all the different connecting rooms in our suite because I‚Äôm not used to having the entire home accessible to me. The hotel also has studio suites available (to cut down on people making laps); we just only had the 2-bedroom suite available when we went to make our reservations. 2-Bedroom Suite Living/KitchenThe suite had a master bedroom with a queen size bed and 2nd-bedroom with 2 twin size beds that would easily accommodate a full-size adult too. In case you need a lift or any other additional equipment during your stay, the hotel has a list of medical assistive devices to help make your trip easier and keep you from having to shlep all your gear from home. **(As a reminder: U.S. airlines do not charge you for bringing any additional luggage with medical equipment; check with each airline for their rules). Our master bedroom had the same incredible ocean view as the balcony, and it was hard to want to close the curtains till the sun was set for the night. I‚Äôm not one to endorse beds most of the time, since usually after a week a hotel mattress can be like lying a bed of nails to me; but this cloud of butter they picked out for a bed was one of the most comfortable I have ever found in any level of hotel. Master BedroomAnd that bathroom‚Ä¶OMGODDESS! They hit the Trifecta with the bathroom designs: A sink I can roll under; a toilet I can safely transfer to; and a roll-in shower I can easily bathe in and not freeze to death from. (Yes‚Ä¶ I spent way too much time hanging in my bathroom this visit; just because I was so grateful I could). My only caveat and it‚Äôs just to prepare my U.S. travelers, is that to alert you the bathroom has standard European round, flat and narrow toilet seats; which is a little different then ones you may be used to. Not impossible to get used to, just didn‚Äôt want you to be in shock when discovering it. Also, I know you will think me tacky for saying this, but if you have gotten spoiled from the cotton like surface of U.S. toilet paper? Then stick a couple rolls of your favorite Charmin in your suitcase. All I want to do is keep you from ruining your vacation from a bottom destroyed by sand paper(‚Ä¶ Just sayin). Accessible BathroomBack down by the pool in the front of the hotel is a Wellness Spa with massages, masks, mani‚Äôs, petti‚Äôs and more for ALL the customers of the hotel (there is a menu of services on the hotel website). Surrounding the delicious pool edges are plenty of comfy pool lounges and chairs to swallow you up for the day and the pool lift chair is easy to access with the help of someone from the front desk who is just a few feet away. They have these great, big, fuzzy, blue beach towels to loan you for using on-site or anywhere you may be heading on the island (as many as you can get wet and sandy). The second pool is behind the hotel and has a much quieter and calmer feeling (I nicknamed it the grown-up pool because I never saw any of the kids in that pool; but not a rule). That‚Äôs also where the BBQ area is, so it makes a great area to spend the afternoon and just have a hotel staycation for a day. When you are ready to make some plans to finally leave the hotel (you won‚Äôt want to, but you should), come back by the front office and they will help you book some activities and help you figure out how to get there and back. That‚Äôs assuming you aren‚Äôt like me and book your activities 6+ months in advance after exhaustive searches or didn‚Äôt just book from all my travel advice? Front Pool and Spa Rear Pool BBQ Area next to Rear PoolTo wrap it up, I have never experienced anything like I did staying at the Dolphin Suites. You don‚Äôt realize until you need it, what a dream it is to finally stay in a hotel that actually thought about ‚ÄúYou‚Äù when designing the hotel and having to check out at the end of the week almost broke my heart. Thankfully the hotel general manager pointed out that the two buildings being built next door are part of the expansion plans for the hotel and my spouse promised me a return trip to the island to check them out when finished. Although when you hear about the rest of my week in Curacao, you‚Äôll see it takes very little to convince anyone to return to the island after the fabulous week we had. Overhead Photo of Hotel, Mambo Beach, the Curacao Dolphin Therapy and Research Center and AquariumLast but certainly not least, I wanted to take a moment to applaud the entire team working at the hotel for delivering us 5-star service and making us feel so welcome; as if they knew us for years from the moment we rolled into the hotel (actually for months sooner as they had to put up with all my enquiry emails). Sometimes it‚Äôs the people that make all the difference for travelers with disabilities when we stay somewhere; especially when they understand all our special needs and not make us feel awkward for having to ask for help. It literally took me 2 hours to have my emotional goodbye with the hotel team (and that NEVER happens when I stay anywhere). Dreaming of my next stay with the Dolphin Suites‚Ä¶hopefully when I come back for the two-week therapy program for people with disabilities at the Curacao Dolphin Therapy and Research Center someday. Coming Next Monday: Day 2‚Ä¶Speaking of Dolphin Therapy, come back next week to learn about Day 2 in Curacao, where I got to try out the 1-day Therapy Program at the Curacao Dolphin Therapy and Research Center; and spend the afternoon at the Cabana Beach Club in the Accessible VIP section. Come learn how that day has changed my life FOREVER!

Can I just rant about my hometown (San Diego) Airport for a minute. Many airports have construction going on which is a minor inconvenience to the traveling public, but when your construction creates a MAJOR inconvenience to your disabled public it should be of note.When I say I walked a mile to the ride share/rental car shuttles, WITH luggage and a rollator, it was a mile from the airport. No shuttle to, hardly any direction (just followed the crowd), through uneven pavement, etc. It was an inconvenience to all.So if you're flying into San Diego International airport, I don't know how long the construction will last, but prepare yourself.

I just want to share that my husband and I went to see a show at The Straz theater in Tampa. My husband and I both use scooters. Our experience was very good. The theater has an open plaza where there is valet parking. We were able to buy balcony seats because there are elevators to the balcony, unlike other theaters we have been to in the past. We had reservations for the buffet, but I viewed it and it was not accessible. Tables too close together and no place to rest plates on the line. We had coffee and paninis at the little cafe on the plaza, Steam Heat Cafe, which suited our needs. The sight lines and sound from the balcony were very good.

My name is Danielle, and I am a disabled content creator. My channels are called Daniellevates because the content is all about elevating ideas about disability and rare disease. Full-length vlogs feature accessibility reviews from my adventures in Boston and beyond. Short form content will consist of series such as Breaking the 4th Wall of Disability, Daniellevates Investigates, Accessible Design in the Wild, and more! Since birth, I have had an extremely rare technically undiagnosed neuromuscular disease. The highlighted event is Lady Gaga‚Äôs Chromatica Ball Concert at America‚Äôs oldest baseball stadium ‚Äì Fenway Park! Some highlights from the concert are shown, as well as our review after the show and a view from the accessible seats in the LOGE section of Fenway Park. Watch the full video here. I give my review of Fenway Park as a concert venue, and I also reiterate the need to plan ahead and to utilize the accessible seats if you need them because Fenway Park was not originally built with accessibility in mind. The seats are very narrow and there are many stairs. However, the accessible seats are great and the staff is very helpful! The atmosphere at Fenway cannot be beat on a summer night. We planned to hang out in the city the day after the concert, so we stayed at the Four Points by Sheraton in Newton, MA which is about a 20 minute drive from Fenway Park. It was a super nice hotel! Since we only stayed one night, we just booked a regular room, so you will see a tour of that. There are many reasons why people seek accessible rooms. Some people need particular emergency alarms if they are Deaf or Hard of Hearing, for example. Always think ahead of what you need and don‚Äôt settle for less even if it is "just one night.‚Äù I made my ‚Äúone night‚Äù exception this time because my main reason for an accessible room is the shower, and I knew that I would not be there long enough for that. This vlog is a perfect example of the mishaps that can happen if you don‚Äôt plan ahead for an outdoor event. The weather is unpredictable for these events, so most of the time people are so focused on whether it is going to rain or not that they forget another big factor: the heat. While we dressed appropriately (for the weather and a Lady Gaga concert ‚Äì someone asked us if we were going to the show in the elevator at the hotel), we didn‚Äôt really focus on hydration and it was a hot night. I felt those effects after the show! For outdoor events, an obvious inconvenience is the post-show traffic. Everyone is leaving at the same time and trying to leave the same place. This chaos is why it is important to know your exits and to plan your intended exit. We ended up going out a different way than we came in, and we got stuck in a huge crowd. Not only was it dangerous since my balance isn‚Äôt good and I was fatigued after the concert, but there was no way that an Uber could get to our area. To make matters worse, my bad stomach added a little drama to the evening! If you have a bad stomach like me, it is important to know where your bathrooms are and to not get stuck in an area without one. If I had planned ahead to exit the most accessible way to the main road, this extra suspense could have been avoided. Also, if you have a bad stomach and find yourself using random bathrooms, this vlog might give you a relatable chuckle when I talk about how I was walked in on not once, not twice, but THREE TIMES. We actually got these tickets in early 2020, and the concert got postponed twice, so I knew this would be a night to remember. Well now I remember it for all kinds of reasons! However, I know these reasons taught me some valuable lessons for future adventures and I hope that they serve you well! Watch the full video here. Key Takeaways: ‚Ä¢ If you need accessible seating for your health and safety, don't overthink it. Utilize these seats! ‚Ä¢ Make a list weeks before the show of what equipment and supplies that you will need. Call the venue ahead of time to see their bag size limitations, and if needed ask what can be done for all of your supplies to be able to be taken into the venue. ‚Ä¢ Research the best exit before the show. Typically venues have phone numbers or emails for accessibility questions. While there is typically staff around the accessible sections during the event, it is always best to plan ahead. ‚Ä¢ Even if you don‚Äôt have a bad stomach, knowing where the bathrooms are is just great advice. If you can‚Äôt relate to this piece of advice, well, I am very jealous! ‚Ä¢ Plan ahead for all types of weather: hot, cold, rain, sun, etc. Make a hydration plan, and stick to it! ‚Ä¢ In the accessible section, some people may stand or some may sit. Do what is best for you and remember that everyone, no matter who you are, can dance! ‚Ä¢ If there is a theme of any sort, dress the part. You will thank me when you see your pictures.

I have very severe osteoarthritis in my left hip and moderate in my right one. My wife has had back issues, DJD causing hip and back pain. I use 2 walking sticks, a walker or a wheelchair depending on how much pain I am in or how far we have to travel. My wife uses on cane or my walker. I used my wheelchair in all airports and my wife used an airport wheelchair in every airport. One of my sisters came with us, She also has some pain but is much more mobile than my wife and I. We also paid for the trips for 2 nephews and one of their wives so they could manage luggage, push my wheelchair and help us get into high vans. We flew Iceland Air so we could spend a little time in Reykjavik after visiting France. Iceland Air was fairly accommodating. at first they wanted to check my wheelchair through to Paris and have me use an airport wheelchair on ur 1 hour layover in Reykjavik but I was adamant about using my wheelchair. The staff helped us get to our next flight as did the kids. If I don‚Äôt have a short window between fights I like to get off the airplane last as I use my sticks to walk and am extremely slow. The kids were helpful at getting our carry on luggage down from the overheads and carrying them of the plane. We had a long wait at the Charles de Gaul airport on the way to Reykjavik but we were very early. At the aircraft the Iceland Air staff was very helpful but we weren‚Äôt asked to board long before other passengers, just a little time so I hung people up walking so slowly. I was allowed to use the first class toilet as my seat was toward the front of economy. I will write more about our trip, the accommodations in Paris, Marseille, Vincennes and Reykjavik.

My name is George and I‚Äôm married to the best woman in the world my wife Brenda she is not only my wife but she is also my nurse because she is actually an RN. I was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis in 2008 while serving in the Army. I didn‚Äôt want to except it because it ended my military career. It has now been 14 years since I was diagnosed. I have been getting a little better and worse at the same time, but without her by my side I would be worse. The last time I was actually able to travel was in 2013 when I could walk we went to Jamaica for our honeymoon a couple of years after that I lost my ability to walk. I am now using a scooter, power chair, manual wheelchair and a walker I guess you can say I have it all for mobility but what I want most is to walk again.

Good morning everybody, it‚Äôs Karen from Phoenix, Az and I am hoping you all may have some guidance, knowledge, opinions, anything to help me on my new dilemma. Every 5 years I usually get a new mobility scooter. Medicare covers them at 80% every 5 years, and by then I usually need a new one pretty badly. The last two scooters I have got have been Pride Victory 10‚Äôs, mainly because I didn‚Äôt have much of a choice. When you weigh 400 plus pounds, there are not many choices of DME Medicare will cover even at 80% for you. So I got 2 of the same scooters. They are well made, I don‚Äôt usually have a problem with it unless you are trying to fit it into a smaller space. It was a BIG scooter, for a BIG girl, and it is to heavy for me to break apart and put in the back of a vehicle if I want to go out with friends for the day etc. Oh! I also do not have a vehicle of my own, so getting places with my big scooter has been a problem. Here it is time again to change out my big scooter, and this year I am a little bit more excited about it because I am hoping I have more choices that Medicare will cover. I now weigh 298 lbs and still working on dropping more! My goal is to start getting out more, travel more, and have much more of a life than I have had for many years. I‚Äôm single 59 yrs old, and I need to have something that works much better for me that I can manage on my own. I see alot of people are getting ‚ÄúFolding wheelchairs‚Äù now days. Are any of them covered at 80% by Medicare? I really want something I can pick up and load in a vehicle at the spur of the moment and go if I need to. I‚Äôve never had anything but a scooter, and don‚Äôt even know if I would like a wheelchair but I‚Äôm thinking I want something different??? Something to live life a bit easier with now. Also would the foldable chairs work for everyday use or are they really just for travel? Do I need something else AND the foldable chair too? I‚Äôm on disability which makes money really tight at all times, so I have to plan carefully. Your input would sure be appreciated, any suggestions?? Thank you. Have a great day! Karen üôÇ

Departing from clothes briefly, at home I keep a big baby wipe package handy in the bath & for travel & outings I use travel packs to ‚Äúwash‚Äù my hands. It keeps me from getting germs on me, my chair, my walker or cane, & half the bath if I went for the sink, assuming I had something within reach. in or out of the bath they provide cheap cleaning for meals before & after; fast cleaning door handles, phones, or pens etc; & a quick cleanse of my chair to keep some of its dirt out of the house; then dispose hygienically. A bottle of hand sanitizer can also work, tho not as handy for even an emergency shower substitute.

Hello. My name is Dawn and I am new here. Last year was a bad year for me. I had to have 3 spinal surgeries. The 1st was on April 1st for removal of a mass. The FAA is seeking comments from the public on the minimum size dimensions of airline seats required for safety. Specifically, they ask if the current regulations have, or could demonstrably affect the safety of air passengers by delaying the group egress time of an emergency evacuation. They did not include disabled people, or people over 60 in their study. To comment, go to Federal Register :: Request for Comments in Minimum Seat Dimensions Necessary for Safety of Air Passengers (Emergency Evacuation) Be sure to read the request carefully, and when you‚Äôre ready to comment, click the green Submit a Formal Comment button at the top right of the screen. Make sure you identify yourself as a disabled person, and stick to the topic. The comment period ends November 1, 2022.

We have started to notice that hotel rooms that are accessible (ie. have a roll in shower) have beds that are on a metal, solid bases. My son has dmd and requires us to use a Hoyer lift when we travel. In the past, we would be able to use the lift with ease because the legs of the lift would fit under the bed. Now, with the solid box frame, the lift's legs can no longer get under these beds. Argh!!! Our work around is to bring bed risers. I will lift the frame and rest it onto the risers. I got the risers from Amazon. Anyhow, just another hurdle to be cleared.

I am an RBKA and have requested hcp assessible roos with a roll-in shower with a bench or seat. All have provide that but were lacking in other features: grab bars, or the bench was at the back or the stall and the controls for the shower were in front, or the floor was not non-slip (almost slipped and fell), no towel bar to put dry towels or a seat to sit on when I exit the shower. I have only found one hotel that had everything I needed. Can this organization reach out to Hotel chains and/or individual hotels, BNBs and recommend standards for various levels of assessable rooms. it might take input from members to get close to an agreement what would be in those standards.

So we are going to Buffalo from Washington for a science fiction convention. We like to break up road trips so we don‚Äôt have to drive more than 5-6 hours. They called the cops on us. My son and I were traveling from Toulouse to Bordeaux on August 15th 2024 around 10 am. My son is in a wheelchair which I mentioned online at the time of booking. The site explained that we were automatically upgraded to first class and assistance will be available to help us to get to the platform. It was not clear, as we found out later that we had to contact the Reduced Mobility Assistance service directly to book their support once we got to the train station. Perhaps, we should not have inferred that since we were automatically flagged as being handicapped that the rest of the process would naturally follow suit. When we got to the train station in Toulouse, I went to the disability office where a man said he couldn‚Äôt find our reservation. I explained to him that I had a person in a wheelchair and several pieces of luggage. I asked him what I should do. I explained that I was carrying three suitcases and three bags in addition to having to take care of my son. Being dual national my French is flawless so there was nothing lost in translation. That man coldly stared at me and said ‚ÄúDo whatever you want, sir‚Äù indicating that he was washing his hands off the entire thing. My jaw dropped. He and his buddies were sitting idly in that office, just chit-chatting and looking at me. All of them had heard the conversation I just had with that man but none offered ANY assistance. I stormed out of the room before we parted with choice words. He told me: ‚Äúto go f‚Ä¶my mother‚Äù in English. I took my son‚Äôs 3 suitcases, including a large one, and 3 bags ON MY OWN while people watched me struggle to get to the platform. I was able to find the elevator and we made it to the platform. My back and my shoulders were killing me. There was no way I could have done that in several trips as that would have meant leaving the rest of my luggage unattended. Lo and behold the car that was assigned to us has no ramp but 3 steep steps. Contrary to what we were told, it was not a first-class car but a regular-class car with no ramp to help a wheelchair in. My son could not stand so I ran in a panic seeking help as I was concerned that the train would leave without us. I saw a big man and I called on him, saying (in French) ‚ÄúPlease, please ‚Äú. He glanced at me and then went back to chatting with his friend. I turned around and asked him again to come pointing at my son. ‚ÄúMonsieur, s‚Äôil vous plait‚Äù. My son was sitting next to the track and I was concerned. He finally moved at a leisurely pace and told me ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt come if you don‚Äôt tell me what this is about‚Äù. I pointed at my son in the wheelchair and said ‚ÄúI need help‚Äù. Then I ran to my son‚Äôs side. He took a look at us and said ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt tell me what you want from me‚Äù and walked away. Next to my son was our luggage for which we would have appreciated some help and my son was facing steep stairs. That clearly was not self-explanatory, nor my ‚Äòhelp, help‚Äô or even my ‚Äús‚Äôil vous plait‚Äù. How can someone who sees someone else in a wheelchair needing help walk away needing help walk away is beyond me. I hauled our stuff Pell mell inside the train and carefully helped my son by holding him walk up the steps. He is 20 years old and although light, I am a man in my 60s. I saw that man standing a few cars away chatting with passengers and I admit I lost it ‚ÄúI yelled if there‚Äôs an accident it‚Äôll be your fault, a** hole‚Äù. My son made it inside lying on the floor when finally that man came. Not to help but to yell enraged at me pushing his face into mine. ‚ÄúDo you think I am your dog?‚Äù He brayed, pretending that the real issue was the fact that I said ‚Äòplease‚Äù while pointing at my son. That was not enough information for him to come to our rescue. . As a matter of fact, i have too much respect for dogs to have mistaken one of them with a man who was probably one of the most despicable people I ever had to deal with. I am not the kind to back down and my face remained to his the whole time. He threatened to call the cops to have us ejected from the train. I replied, ‚Äòby all means, I would like to talk to them too‚Äù. The cops did indeed show up as well as the first guy from the disabled office. One thing to know about the French is that they never let you finish your sentence, so a giant brouhaha ensued. I just stared calmly and looked at the head cop in the eyes. He finally was able to bring some quiet and explained to me that that man was not authorized to provide help to people in a wheelchair. I replied that we could talk protocol but we can also talk decency and humanity. How is a father supposed to react in the situation I found myself in? Wheelchair, person, baggage on a platform and with a train about to depart any minute and a man who does not even offer to help with the luggage, content to let a disabled passenger on a platform? A man who can see a person in a wheelchair in need and chooses to walk away. Callous and cynical do not begin to describe it. They finally let us go and the female conductor offered to provide us with help at our arrival. 4 people in total were on the platform at our destination but only 2 of them including the lady helped with the luggage. I told my French friends about this incident and their answer was telling:‚Äù We can‚Äôt even say that we are surprised ‚Äú.

My name is Jeannette. My husband of 64 years had polio when he was 15 & is parlized in his right leg. So as he has grown older he has lost his ability to walk or stand for very long. I used to be able to take the scooter apart & put it in a van or car but now I‚Äôm not able to do that. Also hotels & resorts say they are handicapped assessable but many have no roll in shower, toilets not tall enough no handrails or either not in the right place. One other thing is furniture that is so low if he moves from the scooter to a chair he has a hard time pushing himself up to get back on the scooter. A recliner would be nice. Thank you for listening

Here‚Äôs a recent comment from one of our members. Do you have any thoughts? People like me need to know which side the bars are on in the bathroom because we can only use one hand. The ADA should deal with this, but does not, but that does not mean that your travel website shouldn‚Äôt deal with this issue. The other related issue is that if you need help in the bathroom and a person with you is of the opposite sex. One of the two of you needs to go into the bathroom for the opposite sex, which should not be required. A way to fix this would be to have the standard be that all facilities should have separate family and handicap bathroom facilities. I am trying to get the Access Board to deal with these two issues, but even if they don‚Äôt, you should.

My wife and I cruised from Rotterdam to Iceland this past June (2023). I‚Äôm posting here a video of our process of traveling from our home in the Cleveland, Ohio area to Rotterdam. Brenda uses a wheelchair, so we tried to plan everything in advance. We shipped our largest bags ahead using a service called Luggage Forward. I used the big backpack you‚Äôll see for my own carry-on luggage. We reserved an accessible room - and got a random upgrade to an even bigger accessible room. It worked out pretty well, all told - hope some of you find this video interesting and informative.

Hi, my name is Elaine. I have had 5 strokes, 4 knee surgeries, & have been diagnosed with PTSD. I have Stage 4 osteoarthritis. To look at me, you would not know anything was wrong with me, but there is. When I travel, I can‚Äôt sit in the middle of the aisle of the plane. I also have slurred speech & my balance is off, because of my strokes. People stare at me, assuming I am drunk.

This episode starts in Kanazawa, Japan. We started the day in Kanazawa and drove to Kyoto by way of Lake Biwa. We saw temples and torii gates, ate great food at the market as well as went to the Samurai and Ninja Museum. (Season 2 Episode 6). If you would like me to post the links to the others let me know. For my 60th birthday year, Chet and I took my dream trip Japan. We journeyed as far north as Nikko National Park and as far south as Nagasaki. We saw ancient temples and shrines, wild monkeys, amazing forests, and interesting museums. We ate at 7 11, Family Mart and Lawson convenience stores, restaurants, and local markets. We dipped our toes in the Japan Sea, climbed sand dunes, and even rode a camel. We traveled in a Mini Wink camper van from Japan Campers for three weeks, driving up and down crazy mountain roads, driving through rice paddies, and in the city traffic of Toyoko and Osaka. We camped at Michi No Eki roadside stops and other stops recommended by the Japan Campers app. We hope you will join us on this trip of a lifetime. We had a blast, and I hope you will enjoy joining us through this video series. We also lightly discuss accessibility that we see in our journey. We are Betsy and Chet, and our oldest son, Alex. For 33 years, we thought Alex, had nonverbal autism, intellectual disability, ADHD, but a few years ago we found out that he has Phelan McDermid. Alex goes on many trips with us, but this time the plane trip is too far. There are many reasons we make these videos. One reason we make these videos because I love watching travel videos. I love to dream about my next vacation so I'm challenging myself to learn to make my own. I hope we can help others dream about their vacations. Another reason we make these videos is to share the world with Alex and others who are unable to make a journey to Japan, and for those with disabilities whose comfort may be increased by knowing a little bit more about accessibility. We also have no idea what Alex understands receptively, so videos are a way to visually communicate where we went for three weeks. He likes to use his eye gaze communication device to watch his vacation videos, so now in a way he can see Japan with us. Our videos, Goal 1: Joyful Life are based on our family's journey and strategies we use to improve the quality of our life through meaningful leisure experiences. It is our hope to reach our number one goal of having a joyful life and to help others reach that goal too. We are hoping that our videos will encourage everyone to get out and have fun.

Hello, I am a parent of a Quad that is 25 years old. I have a complete Sure Hands lift system in my home that assist him and I only know of a few places ( none of which I want to go to) that have this system. I have resorted to building a vacation home on the Little Tennessee River or North Carolina on a lake as an AirBNB with a lift fully assessable - including space for wheel chair and elevator with Sure Hands lift. I am sure I am not the only one looking for this but I can not find it. Comment and let me know if you would be interested in something like this in these areas - I am looking into where you could drive to sites like Nashville and Ashville in North Carolina but be one the lake with views.

Continuing the discussion from Most impressive hotel chains for accessibility?: Hyatt Regency downtown Atlanta, GA excellent wheelchair accessible room. Roll in shower, comfortable beds that are very easy to get in and out of. Hotel staff very friendly and accommodating. 5 star.

My wife and I recently stayed in an ADA suite at this Holiday Inn and found the room to be very accessible, a roll in shower although narrow was sufficient, had a decent bed height that was on a bed frame so that it can accommodate a Hoyer lift. The big problem with this suite however was that there were railroad tracks about 30 feet from our bedroom window. Amtrak and the commuter shuttle traveled on these tracks all times of the evening, into the night and early morning. You have to be a sound sleeper or have quality earplugs to utilize this room comfortably. Just be advised, that this room provides the access you will need, although it comes with a steep price in terms of dollars and restful nights sleep for us like sleepers. Bring your earplugs in your wallet as you'll need it. Another benefit of this room was that it was two blocks from the Aerospace Museum and close enough to wheel everywhere, at least in a power wheelchair.

Many hotels have closed/solid bed frames nowadays. I use a Hoyer lift on wheels, so I need an open bed frame. I travel with a portable bed frame in my van. It is put together without any screws, bolts, or pins. It holds twin, full, or queen size bed and fits into a relatively small box. Of course, help is needed (hotel staff, my wife, family/friends) with switching them out each way. Hotel staff are pretty supportive. Especially, if you alert them ahead of time. Check out one here: Walmart.com Spa Sensations by Zinus 7" Low Profile Adjustable Steel Bed Frame, No Tools... Free 2-day shipping. Buy Spa Sensations by Zinus 7" Low Profile Adjustable Steel Bed Frame, No Tools Assembly, fits Twin - Queen at Walmart.com

I just wanted to share a recent stay experience. This was the best accessible room experience I have ever had. The hotel was TRU by Hilton in the city of Garner, North Carolina, which is just outside of Raleigh. I am not sure if all of their hotels follow the same design. This was a relatively new building. There was ample room to navigate in the room, between the two queen size beds, and in the bathroom. There was plenty of grab bars and low hooks for hanging things. The shower was roll in with an optional hand held shower attachment of which the height could be adjusted. There was also a seat in the shower, which could fold up or down. The height of the beds was spot on. I am not a chair user, but I have a bariatric size walker and face similar navigational challenges and the super high beds are a major problem for both myself and my 4‚Äô11‚Äùdaughter. The only drawbacks I experienced was the entry door to the room is very heavy, making it difficult to get through without someone to hold it open. There is a mini fridge but no in room coffee maker or microwave. Both are available in the lobby 24-7. The other thing is that we were on the fifth floor. I am sort of OK with that as I feel like the odds of an emergency situation are relatively low. It does seem like hotels would put all of the mobility accessible rooms on the first floor though. :woman_shrugging:t2: overall, I was extremely pleased with my stay, and I will definitely be choosing this chain in my future travels if it is an option.

Hi there! Emily here from accessibleGO. I wanted to share something that I have found so so helpful over the past few years. For some background, I am an ambulatory wheelchair user, where I can walk on my knees to get around, due to my knees being permanently bent, and I use a wheelchair in public/long distances. I‚Äôve had custom power and manual wheelchairs my entire life. Right before COVID hit, I was gearing up for more independent travel and needed a wheelchair to fit that need. I found that there are many standard wheelchairs that are now made that are meant for travel and to be FAA compliant (pre-approved for planes). The one I have weighs 50lbs, folds up to be the size of a suitcase, and has removable batteries. The price of these range from $1500 - $3500, and likely would not be covered by insurance - I didn‚Äôt even try for mine. This has revolutionized my ability to travel. Since it is a secondary chair for me, I‚Äôm not afraid to get it a little beat up, LOL. In my 2.5 years of owning it, I‚Äôve taken it on countless flights, thrown in many many Ubers, and been all over the country with it. It allows me to Uber, and to Uber alone too. I usually just ask the Uber driver to lift it in for me, and they usually have no problem doing so. If they are having trouble, we find a friendly nearby stranger to help us out. Battery lasts me well over a day‚Äôs usage. On a normal week, I charge it about once a week. It doesn‚Äôt fit me quite right as it‚Äôs a standard chair, but I don‚Äôt mind. My friends know how to operate it easily as well. If you can afford it and are looking for a travel chair, something that can get a little more beat up and can easily go on planes, I 1000% recommend. Also, this isn‚Äôt paid or sponsored or anything, just my personal experience. ü§© Link to the one I have, but you can find a ton of options if you search for ‚ÄúFAA Approved Wheelchairs‚Äù All the best!!

So we are home from our 2-week tour of the great Southeast. We stayed exclusively in Hilton products - Hampton Inn, Embassy Suites, and 2 different Hilton Garden Inns. Of the four, I would have to say that the Hampton Inn (Charleston, West Virginia) the most budget-friendly of the hotels, which offered a free breakfast, the best accessible room, with a low bed, reachable amenities, a roll-in shower, separate shower chair and who honored our request for a feather-free room with extra pillows. The Embassy Suites Louisville Downtown East also offered a complimentary breakfast and a manager‚Äôs welcome event on weekdays, featuring free beer, wine, and salty snacks. Upon request, a maintenance team removed the bed frame so it was easy to transfer from my wheelchair. The bathroom fixtures and amenities were much too high, even in the shower. The Hilton Garden Inn Nashville Convention Center had accessible rooms with regular beds (too high for me with nothing to be done about it) and apparently the same accessible room on a higher floor that had a lower bed about which the guest complained. Neither of us was offered the chance to switch rooms to be more comfortable. Nice roll-in shower with a pull-down bench, but the amenities were again too high. Hilton Honors members could have a $10 a day meal credit for up to 2 people. (Odd as there were 3 of us in 2 rooms.). None of the housekeepers, busboys, or maintenance people spoke English. Also, no safe in the room, and the safe deposit boxes were too small for a computer. A bonus - the hotel was within walking distance of most museums and attractions except for those in the Opryland area. The Hilton Garden Inn in Asheville, NC, was very similar to its sister hotel in Nashville, but the staff was much nicer about accessibility issues. The safe deposit boxes were even smaller and could not contain my travel jewelry box. Front desk staff were nice about directing us to events usually staged only for locals (the Shindig Bluegrass Concert). Most attractions in downtown were not very far from the hotel, but you did need to drive or take the courtesy shuttle, which was NOT wheelchair accessible. Lastly, the wheelchairs. The first wheelchair ordered from Clouds of Goods never worked right until it stopped working at all. Cloud of Goods did not respond to 3 phone calls and 2 emails, noting the various problems with the chair, except to send me a marketing email. The owner of the franchise that provided the chair was especially rude and refused to call a technician to repair the chair, even though it was still under warranty. He promised to refund the rental fee, but when I got home, there was a charge to my credit card, but no credit. I am disputing the charge, however. We rented a second chair from Scootaround in Asheville. Separate delivery and pickup fees were $95. My hubby picked up the chair himself, but no one showed him how to fold the chair or lift the arms to transfer. The chair that was provided was too small for my generously sized bottom. When I called to see if an HD model might be available to rent, I was told I would need to be 100 pounds heavier to receive that kind of chair i.e. this was the only chair this company rented. So, we made do. Even with the good restaurants in Asheville, I did not think I could gain 100 pounds in that shor a period of time. Our favorite sites were my family in Louisville, the African American Museum of Music in Nashville, the Western North Carolina Wildlife Center outside of Asheville, and, of course, all the Buccee‚Äôs we stopped at along the way.
