My name is Danielle, and I am a disabled content creator. Since birth, I have had an extremely rare technically undiagnosed neuromuscular disease. My channels are called Daniellevates because the content is all about elevating ideas about disability and rare disease. Full-length vlogs feature accessibility reviews from my adventures in Boston, Walt Disney World, NYC, and beyond. Short form content will consist of series such as Breaking the 4th Wall of Disability, Daniellevates Investigates, Accessible Design in the Wild, and more! Have you ever been to a Museum of Science? If not ‚Äì I highly recommend it! While the vlog highlighted is all about Boston‚Äôs Museum of Science, visiting a museum like this is a recommendation that I give when people are looking for a place that both kids and adults will enjoy when visiting a city. Boston‚Äôs Museum of Science takes the #1 spot, but they also list 23 other Museums of Science on this list . While I can‚Äôt vouch for the general awesomeness or accessibility of other museums of science like I can Boston‚Äôs, they are just a location idea to keep in mind if you are looking for an activity that all ages could enjoy. If you are interested in learning more about Boston‚Äôs Museum of Science, continue reading below and consider watching my vlog showcasing it. The Museum of Science is very accessible, and there is really something for everyone. Every time I go, there seems to be great new exhibits in addition to the old favorites like visiting the animals. The Live Animal Care Center is home to approximately 120 animals, representing more than 50 species. The AI exhibit is very timely, and it was interesting to see the Boston Dynamics robots up close! I am so used to seeing them on the news every few months with the new (and sometimes alarming) skills that they have learned, so it was super interesting to see them in person! I love the new Arctic Adventure exhibit . It is super interactive which is something that I appreciate for many reasons. One: I love immersive experiences. Two: for people with varying types of disabilities, having options that involve the different senses makes the exhibit more inclusive. The vlog heavily features The Prince Experience , which is a show under a dome screen that is a musical experience that fuses music with engaging visuals set to a Prince‚Äôs Purple Rain soundtrack. These shows happen in the Charles Hayden Planetarium. We unknowingly attended the show on the 7th Anniversary of Prince‚Äôs passing. While I couldn‚Äôt film the music due to copyright restrictions, this was an almost meditative experience with the audio and visuals. I definitely recommend it if the visuals won‚Äôt bother you, because there are some ‚Äútrippy‚Äù aspects to it. They cycle through the shows, so as of the writing of this blog (October 2023), the Prince Experience isn‚Äôt there but in its place are the experiences of David Bowie, Lady Gaga, and TheDivas (think Whitney Houston and Celine Dion). The auditorium also has other types of shows, and here are a few examples: Big Bird‚Äôs Adventure, Monthly Sky Charts, and God, Science, and Our Search for Meaning. They also have 4-D shows including Sea Lion, Octonauts: Amazon Adventure, and Tiny Giants. While I didn‚Äôt watch a 4-D show during this vlog, I have in the past and I think that they are worth it! Additionally, they also have live presentations. If you are interested in any of these shows, make sure that you research ahead of time and potentially buy your tickets early. Someshows, like the Prince Experience, are an additional cost. One awesome bonus that the vlog doesn‚Äôt feature is that Boston Duck Tours depart from in front of the Museum of Science entrance. A Boston Duck Tour is one of the best ways to tour Boston. By riding on one of the Duck Boats that traverses the city by both land and water, you will visit many unique neighborhoods before splashing into the Charles River for an incredible view of the Boston and Cambridge skylines. These Duck Boats are wheelchair accessible! (If you book online you MUST call the company to tell them that you are a wheelchair user since they pull 3 extra seats to fit the wheelchair. If you book in person, make sure to tell the Guest Service Representative that you are a wheelchairuser). For those who are not wheelchair users but have other mobility needs, they will set up the wheelchair lift to assist you if you are unable to climb stairs. Whether you are interested in math, engineering, physics, medicine, zoology, astronomy, ecology, archeology, technology‚Ä¶. (you get the picture)‚Ä¶. there will be something for you at this museum. The interactive hands-on exhibits are sure to keep children young and old entertained. On Accessibility ‚Ä¢ The Museum of Science is equipped with an assistive listening system. This system amplifies the presentations of the Museum‚Äôs stages and theaters. Visitors can borrow a receiver and headset, or neck loop, at the Information Desk in the lobby. The Museum of Science is also an AIRA access site. ‚Ä¢ Visitors who are blind or low-vision can download the AIRA app free of charge onto a smart phone. The AIRA app uses the phone‚Äôs camera to take in the user‚Äôs surroundings, and a live AIRA agent will describe the environment, including reading of exhibit labels and instructions. This service is free of charge at the Museum. ‚Ä¢ The museum offers interpreters and sighted guides, but requests for these should be made at least two weeks prior to your visit. ‚Ä¢ The Museum has 10 adult-sized manual wheelchairs, 2 pediatric wheelchairs, 2 bariatric wheelchairs, 7 strollers, and 5 electric scooters (you have to be 18+ to operate the electric scooter) that guests may borrow for free. They are available on a first-come, first-served basis. I borrowed one of their scooters which made the visit easier since I didn‚Äôt have to transport mine in the car. ‚Ä¢ The Museum even offers assistance with pre-visit planning, including information and suggestions tailored to an individual‚Äôs needs - including sensory needs. They note that quieter times to visit are Saturday and Sunday mornings and weekday afternoons (during the school year). ‚Ä¢ The museum has multiple accessible and family bathrooms. It also has Sensory-Friendly Restrooms that don‚Äôt have hand dryers or auto flush mechanisms. You can check out their website for more information. ‚Ä¢ They have an Accessibility Coordinator on staff to assist visitors with questions regarding accessibility. I really can‚Äôt think of one reason not to visit Boston‚Äôs Museum of Science if you have the opportunity!
Can someone suggest a trusted excursion company which accommodates scooters? Thank, Ellen

Saw the Rockettes show yesterday. The good: Theater is stunning and show was beautiful and a must see. The staff is friendly and as helpful they can be. The bad: getting through an unorganized crowd in the lobby using a walker was unbearable. The lines for women‚Äôs bathroom are very long after the time spent waiting for the crowded elevators. I bought a semi-ambulatory seat in the orchestra and it was a regular seat‚Ä¶nothing different about it. I am thankful that my family was with me in order to help me navigate the entire experience

I am very pleased with Holiday Inn express in King George, Va. Finally a hotel that placed us in a handicap room on the first floor! Would definitely stay here again!

Afternoon from Boston, where it‚Äôs 68 outside, coming fall next month is the real time to enjoy history with your family, live, narrated by a professional entertainer with a real Boston accent. Our tours begin at your local 617 area establishment with a wheelchair, four other people. We will make your drive entertaining and exciting, memorable, and historic sights for some close-up stops. We work 365 days, with most tours lasting two hours. Our fleet will meet all Federal & State laws for the guests‚Äô safety. Imagine every major city giving tours can now be a market for special guests who require two hours of outdoor tours in their wheelchairs. This idea started long ago, in 1980. EMTA life included assisting these great people. In 2015, becoming a tour driver/ entertainer, guest loading became a major issue for many. I worked for two of the largest providers of historic tours since. They wish these people would have their tour system, designed for wheelchairs, be accepted. Now you have my idea. Anyone interested?

We moved to The Villages Florida. I love my house. Not enough public bathrooms on the squares where they have nightly entertainment, let alone companion bathroom, as examples. Thank you in advance.

Is Southwest Airlines Vacations (SWV) violating the ADA?I tried booking an advertised trip online on SWV, however they do not have functionality for accessible rooms on their website. So I called. They made a reservation but told me they could only request an ADA room that is on an ‚Äúif available at check in‚Äù basis. After flying in, going to the hotel I could then find out if an accessible room is available? I talked to SWV again and to the hotel. Both said they could not ensure the reservation is for a handicapped ADA room. By the way, if I was booking directly with the hotel, I could reserve a guaranteed ADA room. So it‚Äôs not the hotel. It‚Äôs SWV‚Äôs system and policies. So an abled person can reserve a hotel room in a SWV package that meets their needs and a disabled person cannot. Is this an ADA violation?

I just spent 10 miserable days at a hotel that laughs in the face of ADA. Unless you come through the garage there is no accessible entrance to the hotel. That‚Äôs right. Either a circular moving door or two doors with no push button entrance or doorman. The hotel‚Äôs own staff say they have complained to upper management about it. Upper management has either not heard about ADA or just doesn‚Äôt care about people with disabilities who travel. Or mothers with strollers, or, well you get it. There was one accessible bathroom stall on a floor with ‚Äúthe largest ballroom in Connecticut‚Äù and it was out of order for most of my stay. Despite the printed ‚Äúout of order‚Äù sign on the door, hotel management was unaware that the bathroom was out of service. Really? Of the two women‚Äôs bathrooms on the lobby floor, one (near the registration desk) does not have an accessible stall and the one, across a very large lobby, has a heavy door so I never did make it in to check. Entering the hotel room requires two hands, one for the key (yes, key) and one for the handle. So which one can propel my wheelchair? They don‚Äôt care. The hotel room was so dense with furniture, there was nowhere to turn around. There was no space for me to turn to access the sink (not in the bathroom). The roll-in shower was so small that one could not roll in! The shower chair (which required 3 phone calls to get) did not adjust for height and took up almost the entire shower. The showerhead was so high it was unreachable and, if I could reach it, there was no way to fix it to a lower space. The result was the showerhead would just shoot water everywhere but on me. The really sad thing is that this is a corporate Hilton. They really should know better. They just don‚Äôt care.

Hello AccessibleGo Members, My name is Colleen Stalwick and I am a Design Researcher with Teague. Teague is a design and innovation consultancy based in Seattle that partners with aviation and the travel industry to design products and experiences. We're currently conducting two paid research studies. One study with persons with reduced mobility and another study with people who have been diagnosed or identify with a neurodivergence (ADHD, Autism, sensory processing disorder, and/or a learning disorder). The goal is to understand the common pain points and challenges faced throughout the flying journey and use this information to identify opportunities to create more accessible flying experiences. Research Activities & Sign-up If selected, you have the opportunity to participate in one or more paid research activities over the next 12 months. Research activities could include in-home interviews, virtual interviews, virtual and/or in-person design workshops, and full-scale mockup reviews. Compensation per activity ranges from $50 to $600. In order to participate, you must meet the following criteria: Be at least 18 years old Have moderate to severe reduction or limitation for one or more of the following functions: walking or climbing stairs, manual dexterity, reaching, balance, lifting, cardiovascular function requiring oxygen. OR Diagnosed or identify with having ADHD, Autism, sensory processing disorder, and/or a learning disorder OR Are a Support Person to someone who is moderately to severely autistic. If interested and to learn more, please fill out the appropriate sign up surveys below. The information provided will allow us to determine which research activities you would be a good fit for in this study. NOTE: if you already signed up in the Spring for this study, please do not sign up again. We have your information may be in contact with you if you meet the criteria we are seeking. If you are Neurodivergent or a Support Persons of someone with autism, fill out this sign up survey . If you have Reduced Mobility, fill out this sign up survey. Thank you in advance for helping us shape a more accessible future of flight! About Teague: Teague is a design consultancy based in Seattle, WA. It designs new products, services, and experiences that help create a better future for all. www.teague.com

Hi everyone my name is Larry Burch I became disabled in 2009. I had a motorcycle accident where I lost both of my legs. This situation brought me closer to God and has taught me how to trust him in every area of my life. I know longer take life for granted and I appreciate every blessing I receive. I‚Äôm a single father raising my 4 year old son & 3 year old daughter.

Time is marching on. We get closer and closer to our big journey. So far we have hotels booked for all but the last 2 weeks. Today was the day to see if train tickets are on sale yet. I googled ‚Äúwheelchair accessible Eurostar tickets‚Äù. I was able to reserve our tickets from London to Cologne Germany. Wheelchair space for me near the accessible bathroom and a companion seat for my husband. You pay 2nd class fare price but are seated in first class. That lovely place that serves food and wine at your seat. Total cost in US was $140 for both of us. Most of the countries do not make buying accessible seating available over the internet. Yea for the UK!

Greetings, my unmet friends! I figured this was the place to get the honest scoop when it came to Amtrak travel. My Beloved and I rode from Richmond, VA to Newark, NJ (EWR) last year and despite being assured by a disability services employee that we'd have assistance with our luggage, uh guess again. HUGE NOPE. The Newark airport wasn't even staffed. I have wicked RA and OA and my Beloved suffers from advanced emphysema and hoisting luggage made an otherwise wonderful journey painfully crappy (although I must say the conductors were great and helped the best they could). We'd been told there'd be red caps available (at the unmanned station; so not true. (Fortunately, we returned out of Manhattan and what a difference!). . Having not learned our lessons, we'll be leaving out of Newport News. VA to catch a cruise from Port Canaveral, FL in a few months and want to give train travel another try. I no longer trust Amtrak customer service, so can anyone tell me which might be the closest station to Port Canaveral with red cap assistance? Help me Obi-Wan Kenobes, you're my only hope! üôÇ

I‚Äôm finding it interesting as a travel agent, that has a service dog and rollator, how many hotels claim ‚Äúroll in shower‚Äù, but have missing grab bars or bad threshold bump/sizing or you just can‚Äôt get into the shower. It is a disgrace‚Ä¶.I have even had problems with wheelchairs fitting in room/around beds. PLEASE report these. To unload a group of rollators/wheelchairs and then get to the ADA room, which does not support an ADA situation is exhausting and frustrating. Is there a better place to report this than just hotel management? Thank you, Becky: Exhausted in FL

I have flown through 4 airports now and had never had to remove the batteries from my wheelchair because I would show them my document that says the chair is FAA and TSA approved. I flew my first leg on Alaska airlines from Philadelphia to Seattle and didn't have a problem, but when I was boarding the same airline from Seattle to Anchorage, they would not allow the batteries to stay with the chair. I was upset, but they were very professional in the way they handled it and even removed and replaced the batteries themselves.

We have not left yet, and have already hit a snag. I was having some trouble with my chair yesterday. It sounded like kids‚Äô bikes that had playing cards attached to the spokes. It was also hard to maneuver. I called my repair guy, and he said it sounded like one of the two motors on my power wheelchair has died. My dealer said it might be some time before he can get my wheelchair repaired. I called ScootAround, the Canadian-based rental company. In the past, I used them at conventions and cruises. If they can get me a chair today, we will leave a bit later than expected, but follow the same route. I will update you as soon as I hear.

Well we decided to sneak in a quick trip from Michigan to Richmond, Virginia for a weekend. To say it was eventful is downplaying it. We left home Friday morning and drove the slow roads to eastern Ohio. I didn‚Äôt prebook our hotel so had to take that second floor accessible room I hate. We took off Saturday and were looking forward to the twisty, winding roads through the mountains. We get into the middle of nowhere and our truck started to make the worst sounds. There was nothing we could do there so we made our way to the first larger town. Staunton, VA. After many calls to repair places we limped across town. The Firestone place was open. Thanks for small miracles. They said they could get the parts the next day and could do it. Our whole wheel and hub were falling off! No taxis, no ubers, no offers of a ride. I went in to use the potty before the trek. On leaving the building I hit the forward switch and ran right off the sidewalk. Face first, flat out on the asphalt. ALWAYS LOOK BEFORE YOU GO! Three customers came and peeled me off the driveway. Then the fun begins. We have to cross this highway, go through a grassy field, back across and then straight up the side of the major road to get to the hotel. Boy was I glad for my power chair. To make a long story longer. I cracked my ribs, bruised all over, and look like I came out on the losing side of a brawl. But the truck took 4 days to get fixed so I did get rest. I am officially sick of pizza. But met some nice people. Just got home so back to bed.

The price was slightly lower than getting an XL to put the electric scooter into the back and no need. The WAV has a ramp and my husband just drove in and out. Haven‚Äôt seen this option before and not sure if it is available everywhere but wonderful.

Hello! My name is Emily, and I‚Äôm a hard-of-hearing and chronically ill nerd that does access coordination for my professional organization. What do I mean? I mean that I scream ‚ÄúHello board of directors, can we get the accessibility information for this conference venue‚Äù into the void and no one emails me back. I‚Äôve thus taken it upon myself to gather and make access info packets about our conference locations for the past few years. This year‚Äôs conference is at The Westin Ottawa, and I have yet to hear back from the hotel with any answers besides ‚Äúyes we are accessible‚Äù (and heaven knows we all know that may or may not mean anything). Has anyone here stayed at or know anything about the Westin‚Äôs accessibility? One of my biggest concerns is if there are accessible food options in or within a quick walk/roll of the venue. I‚Äôve been to multiple conferences where I just‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt eat because I physically couldn‚Äôt get to a restaurant due to pain. Because I‚Äôm gathering information for not just me, I don‚Äôt have specific requests of the hotel, I‚Äôm just trying to figure out what the baseline is so people can call and ask for their requests (or use a service like this!). Any information would be appreciated, as would any ideas of other resources I should contact! I‚Äôve put some of the questions I‚Äôd like to answer in my packet below! - What accessibility measures has the venue hotel taken? How have they implemented ACA standards? Has the staff had disability training? - Can the venue accommodate special requests for guests staying at the venue? - Is there luggage assistance available for guests staying in the hotel? - Is the Westin service dog friendly? Are there service dog relief areas? If so, where? - Is there a special process to reserve an accessible room? What kinds of accessible rooms are available? - Is the front door accessible, or is there a separate accessible door? - Has the venue had any kind of disability awareness training? - What is the walking terrain around the venue like? - Where is the closest accessible parking to the door guests should enter? - Will accessible doors be unlocked from both directions for the entire conference? Will they be locked at certain hours? - How far is it between conference rooms and guest rooms? Are there elevators on the obvious route between these locations? If conference rooms are spread out, what is the furthest one might need to move between sessions? - Is there braille signage throughout the building?

Hello, I want to report that Paris has a reliable ramp equipped taxi service. The 2024 Paris Paralympics gave the city a goal of adding reliable taxi service for those who need or want to stay in their ‚ôø. Nearly a year later, it appears the service is still strongly in existence. First off G7 is the name of Paris' app based taxi service. The app works just like Uber or Lyft. But in Paris it's called G7, and they are professional taxi drivers, not part time gig workers. When using the service, enter your address information. select NOW or LATER buttons from the menu, and after that you will see the (attached) screen. Choose G7 Access from near the bottom of the list. Et voil√†! What you'll get is smallish black delivery van with a rear entry ramp. The four times I've used the service, the driver knows exactly what to do to load you safely and politely. Away you go. The only imperfection is sometimes the waiting time for a ramp taxi is 30 minutes more than an ordinary sedan. Outside of rush hour, I don't see an additional wait. But at rush hour, it is a possibility. I see these ‚ôø taxis all over town, all the time. So I believe the system is robust outside of the times I've used it myself. Praise Paris for this innovation! Lastly as a related postscript note, Paris has a very good bus system for getting around town if you don't want to roll. Yes the famous Metro is 80‚Ä∞ unaccessible. BUT the busses are great and easy to use. A ramp is deployed. You get on-board and away you go. There is no tedious tie down negotiations with the driver. They just don't bother to tie you down. I've only used the G7 ramp service to go to the airport at times or for a long cross town trip, with several bus transfers to an appointment.

Our train from Munich to Switzerland was of course not on time. We missed the connection in Zurich. But the person who met the train to help me disembark was wonderful. He put our bags in storage (for free), and we got to wander the town in the pouring rain. There was a nice Christmas market inside the station though so we got food and looked around. When we went to get our bags the helper even gave us free food tickets for the inconvenience. Our hotel said they were accessible on the phone. They were but barely. I wish designers understood that wheelchairs rarely turn sharp corners the same. The lift was big enough for me, chair and husband, barely. Sometimes you get what you pay for and we got a cheap place. We bought our Swiss Half Fare card when we got there as the trains are expensive. If you are going to be in Switzerland and using the lifts, trains or buses (almost all are wheelchair accessible) then check out the many passes available. My husband got to do his sledding run, even though it was on a shorter run as the longest in the world was closed for lack of snow. He came home smiling and ready to move there. That is until he got a nasty flu bug! We ended up stuck inn our hotel room for 4 days because of flu and a freak snowstorm. Merry Christmas. The towns do their best to clear sidewalks and such quickly but I tried going out for food once and just wandered from slush puddle to slush puddle. Luckily our hotel had a restaurant on the ground floor where we could get food. The town was very easy to navigate in my chair. All of the sidewalks were cut in to allow crossing the road anywhere. I loved that. Stores were mostly accessible. As usual there are places with a step in front but not many. The Swiss trains were a joy to ride. Easy to understand and the staff in the stations were very helpful. We appreciated that a lot of the trains didn‚Äôt need a lift to access. The WC cars have a ramp that folds out automatically when you open the door to bridge the gap. We will come back someday. It is a beautiful and friendly country.
ÔªøLet‚Äôs end the year with 5000 voices calling for accessible air travel for all! https://chng.it/xJrsqB67fn

ADA currently does not have requirements about which bars should be where in bathrooms that include necessary standards for people who have both disabilities related to standing and also disabilities related to their hands. There needs to be a bar on both sides of the toilet when there is only one toilet available whether needs to be one toilet room with bars on the right side and one with bars on the left side. In hotels this means that if there are two or more handicap rooms, one should be set up with the bar on the left side of the toilet and one with the bar on the right side of the toilet. The hotel rooms the bars on the toilet and in the shower should be set up the same. The same is true for restaurants. But in restaurants there is a separate issue. When you are of one sex and you go out with somebody of the opposite sex. Under the current standards. If you need help with the toilet. One of you is required to go into the bathroom the other sex. This means that the real standard should be that there are separate family rest rooms rather than the stalls in regular bathrooms because that's the only way to make it unnecessary for people of one sex not to be required to go to the bathroom of people of the opposite sex. That should be the ADA standard, rather than separate stalls in bathrooms for other people. To the extent that people on this form can contact the US Access Board to support this approach, please do so. Yours, Ross Dolloff

What if you woke up one day in a multiverse world where you still live where you do now, but there's no ADA. Would you start from 0 and if so, how do you prioritize stuff.

Over this last weekend I had one of the worst dining experiences I have ever had. First off I only saw 1 handicapped parking space in the parking lot as we approached The Peddler in Greenville, SC. It was poorly located so we avoided it. The walkway to the door was flagstone and many stones were uneven and some were loose and sliding around on top of others. The incline was horrific; you needed climbing gear. We were told mo Saturday reservations so we took a chance. Were told at arrival 15-20 minutes. Forty minutes passes and my son in law goes to hostess (our party of 3 is the only party in the waiting room). Hostess says next table is ours as soon as it is cleaned. A party of 6 enters the waiting room. One lady comments about the climb up the walkway and says she feels like she is at Disney. She turns and asks me how in the world did you do it with the walker. I told her my 2 companions, 1 in front, 2 in back. I told my daughter that I needed to use the restroom. She said she would hold door as it had a sign saying step down. Biy, they weren‚Äôt kidding; 3 very narrow, very shallow and very steep steps going down to restroom with only old timey screen for pulls to hold. Those had been screwed into the wall in 3 places. Two stalls were there but neither handicapped. There were no grab bars nor extra width. If course had I been in a wheelchair or power chair I could not have gotten to front door unless I was air lifted in. My daughter had my walker as it wouldn‚Äôt fit through doorway. Ig it was not my 3 wheeler I could not have maneuvered a walker amongst the furniture. I also noticed their pedestal sink wobbled as it was not attached. I slowly climbed back up the steps (3rd one was a doozy) and retrieved my wheels from my daughter. I noticed party of 6 was gone but we were not. Son in law goes to hostess and she was extremely rude to him and says ‚Äúwell they‚Äôre a party of 6‚Äù as if that explains why were eere skipped over. My daughter goes to hostess and woman hisses at her ‚ÄúI 've got you right here‚Äù. My daughter replied" no, you don‚Äôt because we‚Äôre leaving. At that point we had been there over an hour. My daughter pulled car as close as she dared to walkway while my son in law accompanied me down those same flagstones. It was just as scary going down. I don‚Äôt cars if their food is lined in gold it is not worth a broken limb. Ladies would not be safe to wear heels as not only would they risk breaking a heel they would also risk breaking one or more bones. I have been a guest in many fine restaurants created out of historic buildings but all have modified their buildings for handicapped accessibility. To me this a flagrant disregard for the safety of your customers.

Just a warning that VRBO and this host list this house as Wheelchair accessible. There is a ramp that goes up the side of the house into a bedroom. However, this ramp is far from ADA requirements. It is about 18 feet long and about 3 foot high which gives it a very steep slope. We had to push my husband in his power wheelchair up the ramp and hold back on the chair when he went down. Otherwise, he would have slid down the ramp. We stayed the week because of distance traveled and vacation time already booked, but mainly because we had four strong adult children with us who could help us up and down the ramp. Be aware and request dimensions and pictures for any rental that claims to be Handicap Accessible. Hi everyone! I am from St Louis, MO. I am 74 years young. I have had polio since I was 5 years old. I have a hard time walking anu kind of distance. So I use an ATTO scooter to get around. Still travelling a lot for now.

Just sayin' . . . I keep getting lots of print ads in my U.S. Mail for Vikng River cruises, and for other saltwater cruises they offer overseas. I have had several couples who are friends tell me how much they enjoyed seeing the Rhine or the Danube from a riverboat. Imagine my surprise when I checked out the deck plans and found no handicapped accessible staterooms. I was chatting with a lady who wouldn't believe me when I said that. She said surely that wasn't true in this current age. She thought I had overlooked them. She suggested that I call so I did. I was correct. On their river and saltwater cruises overseas there are ABSOLUTELY NO HANDICAPPED ACCESSIBLE STATEROOMS. Thei Viking rep suggested I check out cruises on the Mississippi River where they do have some handicapped accessible staterooms. And why you ask are these their only handicapped staterooms. It is because they are operating these Mississippi cruises within the U S. and they have to abide by the (ADA). the Americans with Disabilities Act, which requires accessibility for all possible passengers. In other words, the law requires them to make ther U.S. operating ships accessible to all. Once you leave the U.S. there is no comparable oversight law which requires accessibility. Because they have chosen to deny a large portion of today's traveling public, I choose to not do business with them in the U.S. I am also asking other disabled American travelers to not support the company in their U.S. cruises.

Friends - I am delighted to be part of this wonderful community. I am an above-the-knee amputee and a former conference manager who booked hundreds of thousands of hotel room nights per year. Things have changed a bit since I was a meeting planner, no more automatic upgrades to suites, or staying in nine different hotels in as many days in as many cities. I am flying less often, and driving many more places in our Chrysler Pacifica Braunability Van. We are leaving next week for a two-week road trip that includes an overnight in Charleston, WV; a family visit in Louisville, KY; attending a conference in Nashville, TN as a plus one; and finally pure tourism in Asheville, NC; then back home to Rockville, MD, just outside of Washington, D.C. I will be reporting in from each location and let you know about the hotels, the tourist spots, and accessibility everywhere for me and my pink power chair. Hope

Since May 25, 2024, I've been fully immersed in bringing my startup, WheelCraft Exclusive Concierge WAV Service selectly for wheelchair users, others with mobility issues and their families to life. They say you should dedicate at least 10 hours a day to your startup, but honestly, I've been living and breathing this project 24/7. Pitch draft after pitch draft, mock presentation after mock presentation I've refined and redefined WheelCraft. It's been a relentless cycle of writing, rewriting and revision. Voiceovers, the voiceover! I've considered every structure: should it be Articles of Incorporation? Articles of Organization? What‚Äôs the difference? Should I start in the state that I‚Äôm in or start in the state that I wanna be finished in? An LLC or Sole Proprietorship? The journey has been a roller coaster of decisions and learning. There are a few things that I am sure of throughout this entire endeavor and they are my mission, my purpose, intent and my logo. For all else as the stars come into alignment, so will the rest of the plan. For if it is written, it shall be done. The support from Arlan's All Access and Arlan's Academy has been an absolute dream and I cannot forget the invaluable insights from the Women of Mighty, Couresera‚Äôs course AI for Everybody. And YouTube University; where I spend my days, my nights, my weekends, my life! If I had known the value of it, maybe I would‚Äôve been there and not spent the hundreds of thousands of dollars in formal education. But as every bit of advice has been a stepping stone towards my vision, the knowledge is a bridge towards forever. Balancing all this while my daughter works like home doesn‚Äôt exist I am homeschooling her three amazing kids, aged 3, 7 and 9, which has been a wild ride, especially during the winter break. Educating them while nurturing a startup might sound of lunacy, but it's my reality. One highlight has been supporting the nine-year-old Sun Goddess adventures in her goal of becoming a published author. Watching her determination has been inspiring and reminds me daily why I'm doing all this. My ultimate dream? Leaving my descendants in a better place than I found them. While it may not have seemed evident until now, but I'm determined to create generational wealth and instill financial literacy in my grandchildren. I truly believe I've found my niche. An industry. This niche doesn't just benefit me‚Äîit benefits millions like me. We are differently mobile. We may not be on the same page as the upwardly mobile, but we seek the opportunity to be in the same book. The journey is far from over, but I am inspired and motivated to continue pushing forward. Here's to creating a future where fluid mobility is the ride we all strive for.

Howdy everyone, a little on me and folks on my end‚Ä¶name is Kyle, 53 yrs young, 30+ yr TBI & SCI survivor. Have an awesome wife Sharese of 6 yrs, and a 13 yrs young special needs daughter Ciara, a high functioning autistic also with sensory issues. So the good news is that we made it to Nashville, and knock on wood, the wheelchair has been cooperating today. The bad news is that I called Clouds of Care again last night where friendly customer service agents from another company said that they had received my complaint and were unsure why it had not been resolved. The agent - Marc - was going to look into it and call me back. Have you received a call? No? Me either. We are at the Hilton Garden Inn Nashville Downtown. Valet parking is $59 a day. The accessible room is beautiful, lots of room to move around the bathroom is very large with a nice roll in shower with a fold down chair. Here is the but. Everything is too high for a person in a wheelchair. There is a high and low bar in the closet. The bed is on a platform, so it might be good for those using a Hoyer lift but I need to edge on the bed backwards balancing on one leg, pivot and push off my and wheelchair wiggle back to the head of the bed. Amenities in the bathroom are also out of reach. Good thing I bring my own. We are plotting strategy for our first outing. More later.
I just got back it was incredible, I‚Äôll let you know when I post my blog. We used Accessible Travel Peru I so highly recommend. I will without a doubt be using them again!

The accessibleGO community forum is where travelers with accessible needs gather to make new friends while they share tips, recommendations, and resources. Every day there are great conversations, and each week we‚Äôll share some of our favorite highlights. Question: Hi everybody. Any advice on how to prepare/get ready for flying somewhere with a wheelchair? Any particular airlines you recommend or travel hacks you‚Äôve found? Any and all advice is appreciated. Thank you!!Cycleboy99 responds: 1) When you make your reservation/buy your ticket make sure you inform the airline that you will be traveling with your own wheelchair, if you are doing it online there is usually a place to request assistance and let them know about your needs.2) Make sure the airline fills out an inspection ticket and attached it to your wheelchair, that way if it is damaged in transit you have a way to make a claim with the airline.3) Let the agent at the check in desk and the agent at the gate know if you will need the aisle chair to get to your seat. Odds are you will if you can‚Äôt walk. Almost every large and medium sized airport has a contractor that supplies staff to do this, not the airline personnel themselves so there needs to be coordination between the airline and the assistance provider, especially since you will board first, which is always preferable. Nothing worse than sitting there waiting for the transfer people to come while all the other passengers are standing there waiting to board.4) You won‚Äôt be able to use the restroom most likely so plan your fluid intake accordingly and try to use the restroom just before you board. Most airlines start boarding 30 minutes prior to the listed departure time ( more than that for international flights). I usually try to use the restroom one hour before departure time. Also you are first on and last off so again, plan on not being avuto use a restroom till about 30 minutes after your scheduled arrival time (it usually takes about 20 minutes for everyone else to get off and for the assistance staff to get you off the plane and back in your chair.5) Tell the agents at the gate area that you want to ‚Äúgate check‚Äù your wheelchair and have it waiting for you at the door of the plane at the conclusion of the flight. If you have a connecting flight make sure you explicitly tell them you want your chair at the conclusion of each leg, otherwise it may end up being transferred from one plane to the other plane with the rest of the checked luggage.6) I fly Southwest a lot and find that their staff is always good to work with and have an excellent attitude and deal well with wheelchair users. Also with Southwest they have open seating and if you are able to transfer independently and are of average size you may not need to use the aisle chair as the first row of seats are easily accessible to a wheelchair and you can transfer directly.7) Enjoy the ride!!For other tips and advice, head to our community forum.Ôªø Ôªø What advice do you have for flying? | Manuel-F-O

Well our week in Barcelona is done. We are sad to be leaving. A week is not long enough. We stayed at the Orient Atrime on La Rambla, down closer to the port. It was wheelchair accessible but barely. When will those renovating old buildings learn to ask the disabled what is needed. One of the hardest parts is a narrow entry or hallway that has a 90 degree turn in it. I have left a few red scrapes of red paint on a few entries during this trip. Barcelona had 65 degree weather, sun, and was very accessible. Per usual many of the older shops and eateries had a step up to get in, but with the amount of choices we found others places to eat/shop. We found a great little restaurant close to our hotel. Guell Tapas, Carrer Nou de la Rambla 20. The paella was the best ever, the tapas were wonderful, the staff was great, and I could get inside. Once inside there is even a lift to get your chair down to the main dining room. It‚Äôs namesakes the Park Guell and Palau Guell were not. While I was able to get into Casa Mila. At Casa Mila they had me try to get my chair into the small lift before I bought a ticket. I just fit so went up. Very interesting. I noticed a weird click sound on the way down and we noticed I had lost a nut that held the front wheel on. So I sat in the sun on a warm bench and my husband found a hardware store nearby. My mechanic husband to the rescue again. All of the mass transit (buses, trains, trams and metro were accessible. We only used the train and the metro and it was easy. Next, a 2 day stop in Figures, Spain to see the Dali Museum. The train was easy out of Sants station. While we have been before we have never stayed overnight. We rented an NC Apartment 32. It was a great apartment. The manager never showed up to let us in. A neighbor called her and she let the neighbor let us in. It was a time wasting hassle. Next time I will cancel payment and get another room. The Dali Museum is awesome. But over the years they have moved things around and it was not accessible in most areas. If you have an art lover traveling with you do go.

If anyone is visiting near Detroit this holiday season I found a fun thing to do. I even test drove it for you. The Detroit Zoo WildLights has turned our zoo into a huge Christmas light venue. It has very well paved paths throughout the zoo. I even got bold and took my motorized wheelchair down the only path that was not paved. It was better then some cobblestone paved streets I‚Äôve traveled. There are food stalls, great hot cocoa (spiked for the hearty), and a nice souvenir shop. The best thing is it is a wonderful family activity. We got the tickets and parking online. There are plenty of accessible parking spaces. There are time slots to entry, to keep it from becoming overrun. They even have hand warming stations sprinkled around. We only took the walk and skipped the extras, like 4-D theater show, Merry-go-round, and something with penguins. If you have something happening in your town for those with challenges let us know. I know I am always looking for an excuse to try something new.

In our travels over the past 3 years we have stayed at many hotels. Our go to choice had been Hampton Inns, by Hilton. However, since I have had to use a walker, space around the bed was necessary, and a need to have a walk in shower with accessible grab bars, we have found that many Hampton Inns, are not Disabled friendly, they say they have ADA rooms available but when you get there the rooms are not ADA. Please see my reviews. HOWEVER THE HAMPTON INN, IN POACATELLO ID WAS BEYOND OUR EXPECATIONS: The Hampton Inn in Pocatello ID was wonderful the staff was courteous and very helpful. Their accessible room was just that and more. Plus the hotel lobby was huge and had tables to accommodate wheelchairs, and walkers between each table. This hotel is suitable for: Who are wheelchair user Who are blind or have low vision Who are deaf or hard of hearing With mobility disabilities Hotel's efforts to accommodate people with disabilities:

Post your story for a chance to be featured in Accessible Journeys magazine, or a garment from IZ Adaptive‚Äôs Game Changer collection! Based on the popularity of our last travel photo giveaway on the forum, we‚Äôve decided to host another one! This time we‚Äôre partnering with Accessible Journeys, a Travel & Lifestyle Magazine launched by TravelAbility and Melange Magazines, all about accessibility, inclusion and equality. The selected accessibleGO traveler will receive a full page feature (text and images) in their upcoming September issue. We‚Äôre also teaming up with fashion brand IZ Adaptive to give away an item of clothing from their Game Changer collection. The first place winner will be featured in Accessible Journeys and receive a $200 gift card to use at IZ Adaptive, the second prize winner will receive a $200 gift card to use at IZ Adaptive. This contest is all about finding who embodies the spirit of accessible travel ‚Äì in essence, who is living the accessibleGO ethos? We believe that anything is possible! To participate, share your personal story and what makes you unique in relation to your travels, plus why you should be the representative of the accessibleGO brand! Simply reply to this forum post before Wednesday, August 31st and you‚Äôll automatically be entered to win! This giveaway celebrates our accessibleGO community and supports travel for all abilities. It‚Äôs super easy to make a post on the Forum! You can do it right from your smartphone or your computer. Log in to the forum. Reply to this Forum thread. Add your story in at least 100 words to your post. Preview your post, make any tweaks, and press ‚ÄòReply‚Äô. That‚Äôs it! You‚Äôre entered to win. If you need to, save your post as a draft for later. Access your drafts by clicking on your profile icon in the upper-right corner. See the giveaway rules here. One entry per person per household (if multiple entries, only the first entry will be counted). Contest ends on August 31, 2022. 5 entrants will be determined by the accessibleGO staff, and Community Forum members will vote to select 2 winners. The first place winner will be featured in the upcoming edition of Accessible Journeys magazine and a $200 gift card to use at IZ Adaptive; the second prize winner will receive a $200 gift card to use at IZ Adaptive. About Accessible Journeys Magazine: Accessible Journeys amplify the voices of travelers with disabilities, sharing experiences to ensure that everyone can enjoy safe, comfortable travel in an atmosphere of empathy, trust and understanding. Travel without limits!

My wife and i recently traveled to Bermuda on enchantment of the Seas out of Baltimore . The boarding was easy and fast . Service on the ship was the best ever. Bringing your own scooter on allows you so much more freedom. Once we arrived in Bermuda and where of ship we found it difficult and unsafe at times to get around the dockyard area. The area by the fort aka history museum is lacking cut ins for wc and scooters for the sidewalk . However, the Italian restaurant will have the best gf pizza you will ever have in the mall. It is a bit expensive but so worth it. A free shuttle is available to take cruise guests around the dockyard with limited mobility. Collapsed walkers and wc. However they can not handle people on scooters. It runs from approximately 8 a m to 6 p m

September 18, New York - In response to an internationally circulating petition calling on major commercial aircraft manufacturers to make accessibility a priority, Airbus has issued a statement saying the company is currently reviewing ‚Äúseveral ideas‚Äù, which it will release details about at a latter date. The statement said these ideas relate to wheelchair accessibility. ‚ÄúComfort and safety for wheelchair passengers, as well as the risk of wheelchair damages during transport, are challenges we already discuss with airlines--particularly focusing on the feasibility of traveling in a personal wheelchair and/or stowage of the same,‚Äù read the statement. ‚ÄúWhile we do not have details to release at this time--there are several ideas under review.‚Äù The statement said Airbus was also ‚Äúfollowing a proactive approach to covering a broader range of disabilities and accessibility beyond wheelchair related topics‚Äù in consultation with its airline customers, as well as encouraging innovation with universities and start-ups. Petition organizer, Pekka Paavonpera, a paraplegic since a spinal cord incident at a Massachusetts hospital in 2019, said he had hoped Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury would have weighed in on the subject, but at least the company had responded to the petition. Last month Boeing Co CEO David Calhoun, issued a statement giving his commitment to the company exploring accessibility for its future produced commercial aircraft. Paavonpera said at present passengers who have mobility issues are lifted from their wheelchairs at the boarding gate, on and off aisle chairs and into and out of their seats. There have been many documented cases of passengers being injured during this process, and wheelchairs being damaged when loaded as luggage. ‚ÄúThis has gone on for decades and the time for action is now.‚Äù he said. The petition on-line link is https://chng.it/DpdHd7VMRZ . Paavonpera said the petition will continue collecting signatures so as to show Boeing and Airbus that there is a real need and an urgency for accessibility, and that both companies should introduce this before being required to do so through legislation. He said a timeline was needed from both companies as to when accessibility will be a standard feature on their new and refurbished aircraft. # Ends Photo shows Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury.

Hello, I‚Äôm Cathy. Thanks to back pain due to dissolving cartilege, I can no longer walk for distances or stand for long. I use an electric scooter when possible, and have a small travel wheelchair. At this point in life, we had hoped to do lots of travelling. That dream has fizzled. I never know when the pain will let up so I can do anything useful or keep me in an office chair all day staring at my computer. If God took me tomorrow, I‚Äôd be grateful to be painfree and allow my spouse to travel, hike, and do what he thought he‚Äôd be doing at 73. We took a cruise to Hawaii last year, and I failed to reserve a handicap room. We had a room with a substantial step up into the bathroom - the cruises I‚Äôd been on before did not have that. I had signed up for a pineapple plantation tour, but the operator did not even have a small portable step to get into the bus, let alone a wheelchair lift. Mostly I gazed at docks at the islands we visited. Most tours offer hikes, tours on foot. I always wanted to visit Germany and go to England and France. But the sidewalks don‚Äôt always have ramps and pavements are often cobblestone. Hotels with elevators and handicap accesible rooms are rare. Even a handicap accessible room is uncomfortable because I‚Äôm very short, and the toilets are too tall.

I went to las vegas for a wedding recently at a resort I had a difficult time getting from my hotel to wedding the elevators that I needed next to the bridges to cross the roads were either not working or there were people sitting or standing in front of the elevator doors doing drugs or looking like they were waiting for someone to get closer to rob them being alone it was quite scary there were multi police officers but they would look over there at the drugged and homeless people and not do anything its a free for all/anything goes town several times during my stay I had to go in the nearest hotel/casino and try to find the nearest elevator then figure out how to get back out to the bridge with the hotel/casinos being as large as they are this was not a easy task just thought I‚Äôd let folks what theyd be up against at minimum maybe download maps of the insides of hotels to your phone to help you find elevators when you cant use the ones outside at the bridges it was a difficult scary experience if I ever return I wont go unless I have enough extra funds to afford disability taxies/transportation which can get real expensive real quick

We finally made it to Prague on a cold winter night. The first fun was getting off the train. It was a Czech train. Clean, on time, and accessible. You could tell that they do not get many wheelchair travelers. When it was time to get off the train 2 men began trying to use the onboard lift/ Clearly they had never used it before. Directions were asked for, delivered, and struggled with. It took about 10 minutes to finally get me off the train. I was suspended in the air over the platform for way too long. But I stayed cheerful and that made it much better. Prague is a rare beauty of a city. It is easy to get around. If you wear dentures be sure to add extra glue though, as the cobblestones were everywhere. With any very old city you are going to have to try and stay upbeat. There will not always be curb cuts when you want them. We backtracked many times to find one. Good news is the river boat cruise we went on was wc accessible. Seeing a city from the water is always a great experience. We got lost often as the roads are every which way. One night we finally pulled out the google maps (we leave phones off to avoid data roaming charges). We had walked around a quarter of the city. It was great. The Prague Castle‚Ä¶we found a short cut‚Ä¶hahaha. It was a super steep, old cobblestone, route. Do not use it. Follow the streets the Tram #22 uses to go up the hill. Better yet, use tram 22. We stayed at the Atlantic Hotel near the main square. It was walkable to everywhere and reasonably priced in an area that is very expensive. The pricing is probably so good because it hasn‚Äôt been decorated since the 70‚Äôs. But it was spacious, clean, affordable. As with most elevators in Europe it was small. When taking our luggage up we had to do it in 2 trips. I may have left a few paint scrapping on the door as it tried to eat me every time I got on or off. We have a strong love hate relationship now. But a great hotel all around. As usual I went to the train station 2 days before leaving to get my bearings and instructions. The man at the desk smiled and said just show up 20 minutes early and all will be well. I did and it wasn‚Äôt. On the day of travel they reprimanded me for not getting clearance 48 hours before,. I am sad to say I lost it. I did not stay upbeat but became the grouchy tourist, very grouchy. They said we couldn‚Äôt go on that train. We ran for it anyways. We stood trying to talk to the attendant and he refused to listen and literally our train left us virtually on the platform. We returned to the info desk. I stayed outside because at this point I was ready to create an international incident. My husband was treated very differently. They got us on a train 3 hours later. It was fairly uneventful. My husband said to add that the Czech trains 2nd class seats are a horror. So off we go to Krakow, Poland. ***If you want a really great Czech meal at reasonable prices check out Lokal. It is close to the main square but not on it. There are 2 entrances and one was accessible.

When Mariam asked me to do some writeups, I wasn‚Äôt sure exactly what she wanted, but it turns out that what I wrote was pretty on-target. Looking at the other writeups in this thread, however, makes me think I should warn the reader: It‚Äôs kind of long. So I‚Äôll get to it without further ado except for the following bio. I‚Äôm getting to be an old fart. 66 last year, soon to be 67. I‚Äôve often thought about what it will be to age as a T3-4 paraplegic, and it looks like I‚Äôm going to find out. I‚Äôve aged well, though, and I still get around, which is what led me to AccessibleGo. And it looks like I like to talk and give advice. Being part of a community is also a good thing, especially as we age. I grew up in Jacksonville, FL, and started my first career there as a ballet dancer. Yes, I know that is a shocking story that you can‚Äôt write because it‚Äôs too tragic, but that‚Äôs what happened: When I was 30, at the height of my career, in 1988, I went rock climbing and fell and broke my back. I won‚Äôt go into the details of recovering from that kind of life-changing event‚Äîmany of us have had similar accidents. Through all that, however, I met the woman who is now my wife. We have grandchildren (step-grandchildren for me, but they‚Äôre too young to know what that means, and I act just like a ‚ÄúPapa,‚Äù so it makes little difference.) Recovering after the injury, I went back to school and became an English teacher. That‚Äôs where I finally discovered my best talent‚Äîwriting. Teaching is a difficult profession, but I found that it was a good fit for me since it kept me active and was intellectually stimulating. Now I write. Nothing that I ever expect to publish, mostly just stories for the grandkids. Through all those years, my wife and I traveled as much as possible because we knew that my future mobility was not guaranteed. Most of our travel has been in the US, but we‚Äôve gone to Paris and to Mexico. Paris is the home that I‚Äôd never been to before‚Äîit is my favorite place on earth. We have found that it‚Äôs possible to travel at deep discounts if you do things like get the frequent flyer credit cards (that wave finally petered out, and it‚Äôs getting harder for me to fly anyway) or the hotel points credit cards (we still use these and get lots of free nights). You run your entire budget through the card to accumulate as many points as possible. The trick, though, is to pay that card off every month. You‚Äôll be in trouble quickly if you don‚Äôt pay it off. We‚Äôre still traveling, especially now that we‚Äôre both retired, and we plan to keep doing it until we can‚Äôt. We‚Äôve set our lives up so that we can travel as much as possible. I surprise myself when I know an answer to someone‚Äôs question in the group, but there‚Äôs no reason why I should be, except that I didn‚Äôt realize I was getting an education during all that travel. So that‚Äôs me‚Äîstaying young as long as I can, traveling mostly by car, cashing in those hotel points. Now the main story (I have pictures, which I‚Äôll also post here in the Reply section): Mission Beach: An Accessible Paradise Good morning, beach lovers! It‚Äôs currently a sunny 58¬∞ in Mission Beach on this beautiful December day, and we‚Äôre headed for a balmy 71¬∞. Something‚Äôs brewing in the Pacific because the waves are running at 7-8 feet, glassy with fair form, stood up by a 5 MPH offshore breeze. Surf‚Äôs up! But be sure to wear your wetsuits, kiddies, because the water is a chilly 62¬∞. Obviously, not many of us are going to be venturing into the surf, but these were the conditions on my recent visit to Mission Beach in San Diego, CA. And let me tell you, waves like that are beautiful . Mission Beach is what we might call a barrier island or, more accurately, a peninsula, of Mission Bay. It sits very accessibly at the end of W. Mission Bay Dr., just down the street from Sea World. If you enter the community from that direction, you need only make a left at Mission Blvd. (They do that here‚Äîthere are a bunch of Torrey Pines streets, etc., in La Jolla). Mission Blvd. runs parallel to the beach, and it‚Äôs the last light before the ocean‚Äîyou can see the end of the road which, for no apparent reason, past Mission Blvd., is called Ventura Place. After your left turn, there‚Äôs a large parking lot a block away on the right, just past Belmont Park (an amusement park), with at least a dozen accessible spaces that are thoughtfully placed in various parts of the lot. The surface is rather uneven here, so you may want to park carefully. It won‚Äôt matter to wheelchairs with suspension, but my ultralight will wobble and can be unsteady during transfers. There‚Äôs another large parking lot across Mission Blvd., with more accessible parking, and there are spaces that I didn‚Äôt mention in the lot at the end of Ventura Pl., behind the apparently defunct lifeguard station (they recently finished building a new one at the south end of the beach, next to the jetty). Accessibility is pretty good here. Ramps abound (this is California, after all), and just about anywhere you want to go, except the beach, of course, is paved. Right where you want it, next to this parking lot, is a restroom with accessible stalls and two single-use accessible restrooms facing the beach. This, however, is also the worst part of Mission Beach. I have seen these restrooms virtually unusable because of the filth that people leave in their wake. The restrooms are cleaned daily, however, so if you get there after about 8 AM, they should be freshly cleaned, even though they may still be wet from the cleaning. Everything is made of stainless steel, so it‚Äôs eminently cleanable but not very hospitable. Not to worry, however‚Äîfor some reason, the single-use rooms don‚Äôt seem to get as trashed. Maybe they‚Äôre locked at night to keep people from sleeping there. They‚Äôre not pretty by any stretch‚Äîthink prison cell‚Äîbare concrete floor, one-piece steel toilet, white-enameled walls. But they beat the multi-use restrooms, and you can take your companion with you. (Pro tip: Draft, the restaurant right next to the restrooms, runs a breakfast window, and they will usually let you use their clean and well-equipped restroom if you ask.) Ocean Front Walk‚Äîthe boardwalk‚Äîruns 2.5 miles between the jetty, at the bay opening and the south end of the beach, to Crystal Pier, at the border of Pacific Beach, where it goes up the bluff into hillier terrain (I haven‚Äôt explored north of this spot because of the hills.) There‚Äôs also a public restroom near the pier, but no single-use rooms. There is a three-foot sea wall extending the entire length of this boardwalk because it‚Äôs at the level of the beach itself, and there are businesses and houses behind it, which need protection from storm surges. If you go from where we started at Belmont Park and walk south, you‚Äôll see picnic tables and barbecue grills to your left on the well-packed, grassy knolls that overlook the beach. Past this, there are houses and rentals all the way to the jetty, some of which are wheelchair accessible (here I must leave the research to the reader, since you know your level of need better than I do). There are houses and cheaper rentals behind these, all the way to the bay, on the other side of this spit of land. The boardwalk connects, near the jetty, to the boardwalk along the bay. In fact, this seems to be the land of paved walkways; they‚Äôre plentiful. On the way to the jetty, you‚Äôll see lots of sand on the wide beach, which has been reclaimed by pumping ocean floor sand onto the beach. It‚Äôs usually about 75 yards to the water, unless there‚Äôs been a storm and a lot of erosion, and you can usually see the waves from the boardwalk (in some sections, the sand is high enough to obstruct the view). You will also pass some volleyball nets, and at the end you‚Äôll see an area where there are many volleyball nets and usually many people practicing their beach volleyball skills. There is also a parking lot here, with 3 accessible spaces. The restroom here is accessible, but barely. You can‚Äôt close the stall door behind you, if it will close at all, because of the stall‚Äôs small depth. The door is a warped plywood board rustily hinged to a 2x4 bolted to the wall. In fact, I forgot to mention that the other restrooms‚Äô stalls are the same. Good enough, I guess, for surfers, who are going to go back out and get washed by the salt water, but I wouldn‚Äôt want to have to sit on one of these toilets, and they‚Äôre often clogged, at least before they get cleaned. The jetty has the best break on Mission Beach, so this is the place to hang out if you like to watch surfing. Sadly, however, you can‚Äôt always see the water from here because the bulldozers sometimes pile up the sand to protect the restrooms (there is no seawall here). There are no public restrooms between Belmont Park and these at the jetty. The new lifeguard station is just a few yards north of this restroom, so if you‚Äôre in trouble you may be able to get help there. If we jump back to Belmont Park were we began and head north, we‚Äôll immediately find Draft, which is as much a pub as a restaurant. Think sports bar‚Äîhuge TVs playing soccer, football, baseball‚Ä¶you get the picture. They have over 60 kinds of draft beer, and the food is decent. The thing to do here, if you‚Äôre not into sports, is to have lunch outside and watch the waves and people (the boardwalk is between the buildings and the seawall all along the beach). Draft does brunch on weekends, but don‚Äôt quote me on that‚Äîcall them first because they used to serve breakfast every day until they surprised me by stopping that without telling me, the little sneakers. Above that, we have Cannonball, a sushi restaurant with plexiglass walls facing the beach. These walls protect you from getting chilled by the ocean breeze, but they don‚Äôt obstruct the view. There‚Äôs a public elevator going up from the sidewalk, with transparent walls so you can be seen accessing one of the best views on the entire beach. A few steps north, there‚Äôs a taco shop and a wave simulator that are associated with an elevated (meaning above the level of the beach), feet-in-the-sand snack bar. Surrounding all this, at the amusement park, there are some clothing stores, a surfboard rental, an escape room, and the Giant Dipper, a Coney Island-style, wooden-track rollercoaster. I‚Äôve never tried to ride‚Äîthe last time I went on a wooden coaster, I nearly fell out. Continuing north, we find the aforementioned, disused lifeguard station‚Äîor at least I think it‚Äôs disused; it was fenced in; I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs for renovation or demolition. Google Maps has it labeled as ‚ÄúLifeguard Historical Landmark.‚Äù There‚Äôs an even nastier restroom in this building‚Äîbut again, they hose them down every morning. This is where they used to have beach wheelchairs‚Äîthey‚Äôre free to use. Obviously, you‚Äôll now need to call to see where to find these (619-980-1876). They had manual chairs that require a companion to push the chair, and their website at sandiego.gov says they have power and floating beach chairs as well, but I think the power chairs‚Äô availability may be subject to whether those chairs are in working condition. I once checked out one of those power chairs. Thing was cool‚Äîit had tracks. Got in it, drove it down to the water, was just starting to enjoy the fact that this was the first time I had ever ‚Äúwalked‚Äù on the beach with my wife‚Ä¶ And it promptly quit on me. After a few tries, I discovered that it would still go, but only backward. So I went backward all the way up the beach and back to the lifeguard station. Salt air, I guess. You‚Äôll find this information easiest if you call the number or do a Google search for ‚Äúbeach wheelchairs San Diego.‚Äù Next, continuing north, we come to Ventura Place, where we see Hamel‚Äôs, which used to be one of those scary rides with the cars that go through the building with the flashing lights and zombies that jump out at you, also with the requisite section of track that goes out onto a balcony and back inside‚Äîthe latter still exists. Today it‚Äôs a ‚Äúbeach entertainment shop,‚Äù which apparently means clothing store and surfboard and bike rental. But the stony facade still looks like the joy ride from years past, which is fun. Behind Hamel‚Äôs, along Ventura Pl., there are restaurants, bars, and beach supply stores. I‚Äôd like to mention Kojak‚Äôs here, a hole-in-the-wall that serves gyros. They made me a passable souvlaki, though it wasn‚Äôt beef the way I was introduced to it‚Äîrather, it was the shaved lamb that they put in gyros. (I‚Äôm really only mentioning this because I love souvlaki!) All the way down the block at Mission Blvd. and past the sidewalk bar and several other shops, is a taco shop with a walk-up (or roll-up in our case) window if you really want to get ‚Äúbeachy.‚Äù From here, it‚Äôs 1.5 miles to Crystal Pier on the boardwalk, so go to the yucky restroom before you start this trek because there are no restrooms unless you go inside one of the few wheelchair accessible restaurants, such as World Famous, or one of the hotels a half-block inland on Strandway, which is kind of an alley for parking access. (Is World Famous world famous? Who knows? But they serve seafood, and they have outdoor seating with shower curtains for wimps who want to dine ‚Äúalfresco‚Äù without bringing enough clothes to keep themselves warm!) Along the way, you‚Äôll see ice cream parlors, hot dog stands, and kitsch shops. If you get lucky, you‚Äôll even get to see the tall, scrawny guy who wears a g-string and a shark fin and nothing else, whooshing by on his roller skates. Many if not most of these businesses are not wheelchair accessible. There is a step up into almost all of them. There‚Äôs a beer joint along the way with a big deck that has a ramp up to get you there. That deck is about house-high, though, so be prepared. Near the Crystal pier, after you‚Äôve passed lots of houses, shops, and beach motels, you‚Äôll come across the Baja Beach Cafe, another restaurant with outdoor seating and no roof (so no shower curtains). They serve what you‚Äôd expect: short-order fare with a Mexican flavor, plus margaritas. Near the end of our journey, you‚Äôll reach Crystal Pier. There are cottages for rent right on the pier at Crystal Pier Hotel and Cottages. A quick phone call to their office revealed that they have two accessible cottages. You can park your vehicle right on the pier next to your cottage. There are studios, one-, and two-bedroom cottages. They have a two-night minimum stay in the winter and a three-night minimum in the summer. Four-night minimum on major holidays. You can also stroll to the end of the pier without being a guest at the cottages. Up the hill and past the restrooms is the much more modern Tower 23 hotel for those who don‚Äôt have time for, or are not into, the 1930s flavor of the Cottages. They have ADA-accessible rooms. All rooms have a balcony (or patio in the case of first-floor rooms) with an ocean view. Caveat: ‚ÄúOcean view‚Äù in hotel parlance means you can see the ocean from your room‚Äînot that you are looking straight out at the ocean‚Äîyou‚Äôll have to ask for oceanfront if you want to look directly out onto the ocean. The hotel is U-shaped, so some of these rooms look out onto the pool, and you can see the ocean in the background or on your left or right. This hotel is going to be more pricey than the Cottages. There are several more hotels farther up the hill, but I have to stop somewhere, so I‚Äôm not going mention them. A quick search in Google Maps will reveal them. By the time you‚Äôve reached this point (you‚Äôre now in Pacific Beach), if you‚Äôve done the entire circuit, you will have gone about 1.5 miles. It may be lunchtime. What to eat? Depends on what you want, of course, and there are even a few restaurants inland on Mission Blvd. My choice would be the Baja Beach Cafe because I love to eat outdoors. Keep in mind, though, that it‚Äôs a mile-and-a half back to your car, so you may want to try not to drink too many margaritas with lunch. Going back to your car, you‚Äôll probably want to backtrack instead of seeing what‚Äôs on Mission Blvd. My experience has been that there‚Äôs not much there but houses, nothing very touristy, and that the driveways are steeply sloped toward the street. The sidewalks are in need of repair, too, so you‚Äôll find lots of cracks and crevices. But if you want to feel like you‚Äôre in a beach city, this street will definitely do the job. There‚Äôs a Ralph‚Äôs grocery along the way, along with a CVS Pharmacy. You‚Äôll also pass the Catamaran Resort Hotel, a four-star hotel with ocean and bay views from the upper floors. They have a small dock on the bay, where you can rent a sailboat or catamaran. (This is also possible at the Bahia resort, farther inland.) Who knows? You may find some hole-in-the-wall that I don‚Äôt know about‚ÄîI‚Äôm not a local there, I‚Äôve just visited many times‚Äî that boardwalk is one of my favorite rolls. Once you‚Äôre back to your car, it‚Äôs not far to the freeways. I should also mention here the Hyatt Regency Mission Bay, where we‚Äôve stayed many times. This hotel is also upscale. They have ocean and bay view rooms. The view from either side is excellent, but the ocean side can be noisy because that‚Äôs also where the pool and wedding venues are‚Äîyou want the upper floors if you can get them. They also have ADA-accessible rooms, but we have never rented one since we prefer the mild hardship that comes with a higher floor and an ocean view. (I have an able-bodied wife, as you may have surmised‚Äîtheir beds are sky-high!). Their on-site restaurant, the Red Marlin, seems to be currently in a state of flux‚Äîthey‚Äôve changed management, and the last time I visited, they only had a buffet breakfast instead of the buffet and full-service. I hate trying to navigate a buffet from my wheelchair while balancing a plate of food on my lap‚Äînot to mention the freshness of buffet food. They‚Äôre closed for lunch, but there is a short-order restaurant, Pelican‚Äôs on the Bay, poolside. Room service is more like having take-out delivered. Dinner at the Red Marlin is good but pricey. You can, however, sit outside on their patio by the fire (they have propane heaters, too) or inside looking out at the marina or the bay through their large picture windows. Across W. Mission Bay Dr., right next to another marina, at the Dana on Mission Bay (this is an old motel that‚Äôs received a glow-up, and there is a new building, too) is a nice little place called Firefly. Most of their tables are outdoors on an artificial turf surface near (but not beside) their pool. You can also roll there from the Hyatt, along another of the plentiful paved walkways in the area, without crossing W. Mission Bay Dr. You‚Äôll go under the bridge, along the bay, and see the sailboats and the other boats. Speaking of the walkways, this area is worth some Street View research in Google Maps. The walkways are in the app‚Äîyou can travel them virtually! Most of the entire Bay in this area is ringed with walkways. When we were a little younger, my wife and I spent entire days walking along these walkways and never retracing our path. If you want to spend time outdoors at the ocean, you can‚Äôt go wrong at Mission Beach. It‚Äôs not 100% wheelchair accessible, but where does that exist? There‚Äôs plenty to do, plenty to see, and plenty of sun, but it doesn‚Äôt get excessively hot. There are fishing and whale watching tours that leave from the marina by the Hyatt. It goes without saying that there are also plenty of hotels nearby, and tons of stuff to do in San Diego, from the San Diego Zoo (a world-class zoo) to the Old Globe Theater. There‚Äôs also the Gaslight District and Seaport Village. And if you need public transportation, that‚Äôs available, too. We have taken the trolley from the Hyatt to downtown with little trouble. My impression is that all of the public transportation is wheelchair accessible‚Äîit‚Äôs California, after all. So what are you waiting for? Get on the phone and work it out!

From a community member: Even though I can‚Äôt talk verbally. I have a communication device to communicate with people. I have a metro lift. So I travel around by myself in my hometown. I have a question, if I want to travel to another state. Can I bring my power wheelchair on an airplane?

Continuously rated one of the best zoo‚Äôs in the world on trip advisor

Does anyone else have an issue when using curb cuts at shopping centers, business offices, etc., while in a chair, scooter or using a walker?I have a very uncomfortable reaction when the curb cuts have the insets with the raised bumps. Some insets are red, some yellow and I have seen blue. I was told those were to assist sight impaired people to navigate the curb cuts. I have absolutely no issue with providing that assistance; however, when that inset covers the entire width of the curb cut thereby forcing me to roll over it that causes me much discomfort. It literally jars my teeth and I have all of my own with no cavities and no fillings. I find it so jarring that I sometimes avoid the cuts if I am using my walker and just ‚Äújump‚Äù the curb. Of course I can‚Äôt do that when using my power chair.Is this an issue for anyone else?I wish they would divide the width and leave half blank and smooth.
This article is from a ‚Äúlost luggage‚Äù point of view when a wheelchair goes missing. But for many of us, it could be a horror story.

In a couple of days we will be halfway done with our retirement vacation. It has been an amazing trip and scary trip. Since I don‚Äôt get online much during the trip I‚Äôll jot a few highlights. Miami was more expensive than I thought it would be. But we did finally find the train from the airport into the city. It worked very well. Use the Metro line. You take a people mover to the end of the terminal and then have to choose which line to take. It was a struggle to get information but we persisted and found it. The Citizen M in Miami has a very good accessible room. We have stayed in this brand before and it is very consistent. We walked over the bridge to the cruise port which was not bad. At the cruise port they seem to have lost all concept of wheelchair accessibility. On the return trip we will use a bus or taxi.

My hands are partially paralyzed and I have always struggled with swipe card room keys. Travel with a 4 inch length of string tied in a loop large enough to put one or two fingers through. When you get your key tape the string to it at a place where you would hold the card when using it.Before inserting the key into the slot pass your finger through the loop so you can pull the key from the lock.
