We recently had a staycation here in Tucson my wife booked thru another website for BD celebration and getaway for Jun 28,29th: La Posada Lodge & Casitas, Ascend Hotel Collection 520-887-4800 5900 N Oracle Rd, Tucson, AZ 85704 Booked 3 rooms with one as WC Accessible one. On check-in we received Rm #'s C-1, C-2 C-12. At check-in I asked which was the accessible one and was told we did not have the accessible room that we requested and there were no others available. He gave us the C-12 saying it was a bigger room so I could move around in it and had a walk-in shower. Room size was very good for WC use except could not get in the bathroom area due to narrow doorway. The walk-in shower wasn't. It had about a 5" step up and no handrails or seat. Toilet was usual contractor toilet with a low seat. Used a chair to be able to get up and down safely. The walkway to the room was heavily obstructed by bush. Attache is 2 pics of the walkway with one showing me deep into the vegetation to get to and from the room. 1 Pic of the door. It had a door stop that constantly fell down necessitating us to have to reach down to lift only to fall again. We taped it up several times only to have it come untapped to due to hard door closing and was also very hard to enter due to very heavy tension on door closer. As for C-1 AC didn't' work properly. Promised guy never showed the first night. Next day it as about 2 in the afternoon before they sent someone, so we cancelled that room and part of our party went home for the night. We requested and did have that room removed from our bill. With the current temps running near 110` lately the AC in the C units struggled to keep the rooms comfortable. Overall, very nice place to stay and would be getting great reviews except for our issues. They TVs were out through out and staff kept saying it was due to weather. The monsoons past few days are occurring in the evening so I'm sure there were other issues they did not tell anyone about, Great breakfast provided. Pool and hot tub are accessible, slow on the towel refills on the deck. A good amount of shaded tables and lounges. In the SO AZ sun, that comes in handy. Front desk courteous and friendly as well as other staff we ran into during our stay. I'll be sending this there to their point of contact. 3 Palms Tucson North Foothills 3-Star Hotel7411 N ORACLE RD, Tucson, AZ, Arizona Currently remodeling an DONOT have accessible room.

$2000. There ones lower but they are not in good shape. Her son would $1500 provided someone truly needs it. Her Van is a 2016 Chrysler Town & Country Mobility van with a fold out side door that works very well and has hand controls. this van also has a device on the floor so you can pull your chair up lock yourself in and drive from your chair or you can get out of your chair and transfer to the normal seat in the van. The payoff for this van is at $24,000. She bought it for $27,000. It has approximately 33,000 miles that I remember from 3 to 4 weeks ago. That's when I borrowed it and it drove fine. I don't use hand controls though. Her son will need to go North for a week or two, but he is going to need to make some decisions on what to do with both. If you are truly interested, please let me know. Scott

From a community member: I have been doing a lot of research about accessibility in travelling and have not found a way to take my daughter on the trips that she wants. My daughter has severe arthrogryposis affecting all of her joints below the neck. She cannot use her arms or her legs. Her legs are fixed straight, both knees and ankles are fixed in place. Her wheelchair has an extension that supports her legs in front of her. The sides of the extension open up to allow her legs to spread to the sides when she is not moving. Her hips are adducted outward and her shoulders are abducted inward; part of the arthrogryposis. If her legs are contained straight for long periods of time her knees can become sprained due to the push outward from the hips. Her elbows, wrists and finger joints are also fixed. She cannot use her arms or her hands. She is prone to fractures is she falls or bumped hard. We did travel when she was younger and I could carry her onto a plane and sit her in the bulkhead seat. As she is grown now we travel in our accessible Sienna and bring her Hoyer and commode with us. The difficulty is when she wants to travel further. She dreams of going to Europe. She want to see Amsterdam, Wales and England. She also wants to travel to Los Angeles, California. She now weighs over 200 pounds and I can no longer lift or carry her. I cannot even do a lateral transfer. Can you think of any way we could safely travel?

Finding a budget friendly hotel in central London was not easy. I settled on the Z Hotel Covent Garden as it was in the heart of it all. If you are into theatre it is very convenient. It is located among tons of great shopping, world class (free) museums, subway (tube) lines, and great restaurants. There are other Z Hotel locations in the city. As you can tell the location is it‚Äôs #1 best feature. The 2nd would be the staff. We arrived with a broken wheelchair, 3 suitcases and a tearful old lady. The staff went out of their way to be helpful. They made calls to help us find repairs and replacement services. They got our room ready much earlier than their 3 pm norm. But then we have the rooms. Remember that huge rooms are an American thing not European. But for wheelchair users space is a need, not a want. I can say that we fit, but barely. The bed was tucked into an alcove, so one person was wedged into the wall and had to climb over to get a middle of the night pee. Of course that wakes up the sleeping person too. A lift can be used in the room. There is an electric kettle and coffees and teas were stocked well. A great feature was the bathroom. It had a grab bar on the left side, tp on the right at a good height, roll under sink, roll in shower with a seat in the shower. It was spacious. They have a cafe on the main floor. But the Pasta Brown restaurant just next door was better. Unfortunately, there is a step to get up to get into Pasta Brown. All told it is a good enough place if you can get through the quirks. We already booked it for our return trip.

Miami International Airport will begin installing wheelchair lifts on its jet bridges next week, in a move aimed at improving accessibility for passengers with reduced mobility. The first phase of the rollout will cover 41 gates across all three terminals. The new technology will streamline the boarding process for travelers who use wheelchairs and is part of a broader $9 billion modernization plan called Future-Ready MIA. ‚ÄúThese upgrades are about building an airport that works for everyone,‚Äù said Miami-Dade Mayor Daniella Levine Cava, who called the initiative a reflection of the region‚Äôs values of inclusion and innovation. Beyond the lifts, the airport plans to replace 94 of its 126 jet bridges by 2028. Renovations will also upgrade more than 200 public restrooms and over 600 conveyances like elevators and escalators. American Airlines, MIA‚Äôs largest operator, supports the improvements, which are expected to ease congestion at one of the nation‚Äôs busiest hubs. Though some facilities will temporarily close during construction, airport officials say the end result will be a more efficient, inclusive experience for the 55 million passengers Miami serves each year. See less

# UNITED STATES V. UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC. Hi everyone, Pinky üßö again. I wanted to share with you some goof news I just discovered while on the Department of Justice‚Äôs website. If anyone has had issues with Uber and/or have been charged for the extra time needed to board the accessible vehicles; it looks like our day of reckoning is coming, as the DOJ comes to our defense finally. (Now if someone could just explain to me why Uber killed its Accessible vehicle programs in ALL but a couple of cities in the U.S.? Love to get everyone‚Äôs feedback on the case or if you have had any issues with Uber, Lyft, or any of the transportation apps? Thanks everyone; I look forward to reading your posts,-Pinky üßö Https://www.justice.gov/crt/case/united-states-v-uber-technologies-inc Overview: On November 10, 2021, the United States filed a complaint under Title III of the ADA challenging Uber‚Äôs practice of charging ‚Äúwait time‚Äù fees to passengers who, because of disability, take longer than two minutes to get in their Uber car. Passengers with disabilities may need additional time to enter a car for various reasons. A passenger may, for example, use a wheelchair or walker that needs to be broken down and stored in the car. Or a passenger who is blind may need additional time to safely walk from the pickup location to the car itself. If you believe you have been a victim of disability discrimination by Uber because you, or someone you were traveling with, were charged wait time fees, please contact the Justice Department at 833-591-0425 (toll-free), 202-305-6786, or send an email to Uber.Fee@usdoj.gov. On February 4, 2022, the United States filed a response to Uber‚Äôs Motion to Dismiss the Complaint, arguing that, contrary to Uber‚Äôs arguments, Uber is a covered transportation company under Title III of the ADA and that the United States‚Äô Complaint plausibly alleges that Uber violates Title III of the ADA and its implementing regulations by charging discriminatory wait time fees to people with disabilities who, because of disability, need more than two minutes to board an Uber vehicle. On July 18, 2022, the Department of Justice announced that it entered a multi-million-dollar settlement agreement with Uber Technologies, Inc. to resolve a the lawsuit. Under the agreement, Uber will offer millions of dollars in compensation to over 65,000 Uber riders who were charged the discriminatory fees due to a disability. Uber will also waive wait time fees for all Uber riders who certify that they (or someone they frequently travel with) need more time to get in an Uber because of a disability, and will ensure that refunds are easily available for anyone who is charged a wait time fee because of disability. Press Release

Hello Everyone! I am an Area Director of Sales over many hotels throughout Texas. My Management Company also has many other hotels throughout the US. We are in the process of evaluating how we can better serve the accessible community at our hotels. Two hotels we are specifically targeting are in Houston, TX. These hotels are located in the heart of the Medical Center District. We are exploring the option of adding hospital beds or recliners to some of our rooms. Would this be an addition that would benefit a large population of travelers with accessible needs? Are there any other accommodation needs that you would like to see more of in hotels, specifically those hotels located near medical facilities? Thank you everyone! We hope to make meaningful changes to make your travel more comfortable and less stressful.

Even when I ask for one on the reservation, they rarely have one available, so I had to buy my own, but I‚Äôve never taken one on a flight. Has anyone else done this? Thanks.

Hey accessibleGO Community! Summer is almost here, and we're so excited to hear about all the incredible trips you're planning! We know that travel can come with its own set of challenges, and we want to celebrate the strength, creativity and adventurous spirit of our community. ‚Ä¶Where are you heading this summer? Are you dreaming of a relaxing accessible beach getaway? Planning an awesome road trip with your adapted vehicle? Or perhaps exploring a new city with accessible transit options? We want to hear about it all ‚Äì big or small! Sharing your experiences here helps inspire and empower others in our community. üéâ Announcing Our Summer Travel Contest! üéâ To celebrate your journeys, we're launching a summer travel contest exclusively for our accessibleGO community! Here‚Äôs how you can join the fun: Share Your Plans: Post your accessible summer travel plans right here in this thread by June 15th ! Tell us where you're going, what accessibility features you'll be using and any tips or recommendations you have for accessible travel. Include a Photo: Got a picture from a previous accessible trip or a map with your accessible routes? We‚Äôd love to see it! Add it to your post. Here‚Äôs How to Win: We'll randomly select one participant to win a $100 gift card and be featured in our next monthly newsletter! We can't wait to read about your adventures! Your stories matter, and by sharing, you‚Äôre helping to build a more knowledgeable, inclusive and connected accessibleGO community. Happy Accessible Travels! The accessibleGO Team P.S. here are some tips for posting: Make it personal: Share your excitement and why the trip is meaningful to you. Cruise post There are so many different accessibility needs, so I will describe our situation and where this cruise met our needs or failed. My husband had a hemorrhagic stroke 2.5 years ago and is hemiplegic - no ability to use left side, and the left side of each eye is blind. He is in a power wheelchair full-time. We are 73. I am active and mobile and his care partner. At home he transfers chair/bed by standing at a tension bar. On the road, either with slide board or Hoyer lift. For toileting, always Hoyer lift. For this trip I brought our Hoyer lift and an extra manual wheelchair that I push. I‚Äôm sorry about the extreme detail, but different people will want to know different info. The Room: We took the same trip a year ago and had room 9922. This year we had room 14878. Both are ADA rooms and have the same perfect layout. Large bathroom - I could easily use the Hoyer lift to take my husband to the toilet or shower. The toilet had a left wall grab bar, and a right fold down (very strong) grab bar. The shower has a seat that lowers from the wall, extremely strong and sturdy. The grab bar was on the left which doesn‚Äôt work for my husband, but the water control bar was directly in front and mounted safely enough to use for support. There was also a vertical grab bar on the left and my husband‚Äôs arm was long enough to reach. I don‚Äôt know if there are any rooms that are mirror images so we‚Äôd get right bars. The room itself is large enough to maneuver around. A Hoyer lift will fit under the bed, but look first so you can reposition the life jackets stored there. To use the slide board in a way that he can help, he needs always to move right, so in the morning, I need to back the wheelchair all the way to the wall. (He sleeps on the left). That required moving the bed 8‚Äù from its normal position to make room and I was able to do that on my own. The end tables are easy to move so after he‚Äôs in bed, I put one next to his arm and put a towel (to prevent slippage) and urinals on top so he can use them at night. There‚Äôs a desk with room to roll under. There was a hair dryer under the desk that reached to the bed to help with morning cleaning. There was plenty of storage. I kept the Hoyer in the shower, and the folded extra wheelchair in the closet, and the power chair next to the desk where it could charge and be out of the way if I needed to get up at night. These rooms have aft balconies, which are large and have no threshold entries. Imagine the tapering shape of the ship - the 9th deck balcony is enormous; the 14th is normal sized. Also 9th is quieter. There was often outdoor music and dancing 10-midnight on the 15th deck which we could hear. Ship activities: We are not typical cruisers. We like to sit or stroll outdoors, read, and relax. I did the ropes course which was scary but fun, and last year I went on the aqua slide. We don‚Äôt do games, casino, etc, so get that info from someone else. Meals: The buffet: Some seats are helpfully labeled as handicap. There is no difference, but they are located near broad hallways making it easy to get in and out. We took advantage of this. It‚Äôs too hectic for a person in a wheelchair to use the buffet, so I had to do all the choosing and serving, but the selection was very broad so we typically went there for breakfast and lunch. At ‚Äúrush hour‚Äù servers will bring you drinks so that makes things easier. The dining rooms: When we entered I mentioned the wheelchair and the waiters tried for easy in/easy out seating. Moving around: Because of my husband‚Äôs limited vision, he drives very, very slowly which means people cross in front and back which is safe but doesn‚Äôt feel it to him. He has sensory issues, so the constant people/noise/music made it harder. There are plenty of elevators and people were always patient about him getting in and out and turning. There are plenty of accessible bathrooms and they are large enough for turning around. Excursions: DO NOT TAKE THE NCL WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE TOUR OF THE ISLAND!!! It was SO bad and expensive and I‚Äôm still angry that they won‚Äôt compensate me for any of the cost. The mini-bus had a reasonable rear elevator entry, but because of the number of people, instead of lift and drive forward into place in the back, the driver manually moved the wheelchair all the way to the right, and a scooter all the way to the left. This could not be done by driving either vehicle, because the last row of the bus was too close. This was dangerous and risked harming the chair. It meant if my husband wanted to get out at any of the stops it would take 10-15 minutes each way, so of course he never left the bus. There were many people with accessibility needs, no place to put equipment and no time built into the trip for extra in/out help. So we ran late, and when we got to the final stop, St. George‚Äôs, where I thought we‚Äôd get out and eat lunch at a pub, there was only 25 minutes left, so I ran to a grocery and we ate in the bus. AND, the lift was not secured tightly and banged the whole drive so conversation was impossible. There was not enough of interest IMHO on the drive, so I‚Äôd recommend taking the free ferry to St. George‚Äôs, which is accessible. The excursion I planned: My husband is an avid birder and there is a very rare bird, the Bermuda Petrel, that nests on Nonsuch Island, and spends the rest of its life at sea. Longtail Tours - Lynn Thorne - longtail.tours@gmail.com . Lynn arranged for an accessible taxi to take us to Tucker Town Wharf, a charter boat to take us to Nonsuch Island, where Jeremy Madeiros, principle scientist, dept of Environment and Natural Resources, brought 3 chicks to the boat that we could hold while he weighed, measured, and banded them. An incredible experience that went perfectly smoothly. The taxi was Paradise Transit Ltd, Alton Trott, trottalton@gmail.com . 441-705-9198. Rear lift, easy in/out, lovely, helpful guy. The charter boat was Castaway Charters Chase Sleeter 441-505-0855 We planned for a 2-hour period at high tide when the dock and the boat would be level. I used the manual wheelchair so the extra weight was 30 pounds not 250. Chase was wonderful - confident getting the chair on and off and securing. The experience was unbelievable. I recommend all these people if you have accessibility needs and do your own planning. That‚Äôs all. Hope this helps someone. Feel free to ask me questions.

Hard to believe, but I‚Äôm looking for a New England ski lodge that also has ADA accessible rooms. Most of my travel is done with a friend who uses a mobility scooter. She has always wanted to stay at a lodge where she can watch people ski and sit by the fire. Does anyone know of such a place?

I feel I should share my experience with NCL. I saved for years to take my son and his wife on a cruise for their 20th anniversary this year. I chose a cruise to Alaska from Seattle, May7-14. I will be 75 this year, so decided to treat myself and go along. I'm disabled due to 2 strokes, so paid for a friend to accompany me. I booked n ADA room for me and a regular room close by for my son. Another friend wanted to join us, and the NCL agent said it was no problem to add a a third person.When we boarded, we were switched to a regular room, way down the hall from my son.We immediately contacted guest services. Never found out till we were home the reason they moved us. Apparently the ADA room doesn't accommodate 3 people. So the staff took it upon themselves to move us to a regular room. Anyone being disabled will know I couldn't step up into the bathroom on the ship. Had to go 2 or 3 decks away to find a public bathroom. Not easy in the middle of the night!It would have been a disaster if we hadn't decided to go ahead and make the best of it and have a good time. I won't go into all the details here, but feel free to email me if you want more info.We all wrote letters to the VP of guest services. We were offered an onboard credit of $100 on our next cruise to be used within a year. What an insult after all we went through. I'm not familiar with other cruise lines, but definitely can't recommend Norwegian. Although the food was excellent and room staff were very friendly and helpful. Too bad that's the only good things I can say. Oh well, better luck next time. If there is a next time üòú. Won't be with Norwegian! LOL. Thanks for letting me rant.

In my search for a totally accessible room for my daughter‚Äôs trip to Atlanta, I got some great advice I would love to share here. I needed to find a bed that a hoyer lift could go under and a roll in shower. I was not finding one and spending forever trying to explain a hoyer lift to front desk people. A wonderful worker who accidentally answered the phone gave me the best advice. She said to call in the morning and ask for Housekeeping. They actually have been in all the rooms and can answer all my questions!! Jean

I suggest people with disabilities not stay in the Fairfield Brookhollow in Houston. We reserved a mobility accessible room. We checked in and verified with the clerk that room was mobility accessible. We needed to rest and didn‚Äôt notice it didn‚Äôt even have grab bars in the bathroom. I couldn‚Äôt shower but made the toilet situation work. The next morning I asked why we were put in that non-ADA room. The clerk said it was hearing accessible. That‚Äôs not what we reserved and the room did not have a flashing light doorbell so they lied about that too. The next business day I called to speak with manager and was sent to voicemail. I left the folio number and the problem, asking for a return call. No call, no apology, no explanation. Marriott‚Äôs approach to accessibility seems abhorrent.

Tip #1, never hold off going to a doctor if something does not feel right,, April 2021 i thought i pulled a muscle in my calf,, i finally could not ignore it and went to the doctor 5 weeks later to find out i had a blocked artery in my thigh, after a few months of trying to ‚Äúfix it‚Äù the pain was too much and i told them to cut it off,, i ended up being a below the right knee amputee in Aug 2021, fell a few times and busted it wide open, got a bone infection spent months in the hospital etc., fast forward to feb 2023, had a mild stroke that weakened my left leg, said to myself heck with this got a passport and went to Colombia by myself, first time out of the USA, nothing like traveling to brighten your day,, i also went to texas for a few weeks and am planning to go spend the winter in Colombia because 60 Alaskan winters is enough, the cost is cheap (live like a king for less than $2k/month) and they are the friendliest people i have ever met ,,,do not let fear hold you back from traveling, go enjoy life, go see the world..

Hi everyone! It‚Äôs Pinky üßö , one of your Forum Moderators here at AccessibleGo. I‚Äôm not one to be a big product pusher, but I was reading a copy of NewMobility (free magazine from United Spinal) in the car today and saw something that made my eyes pop out. Now I know you are all going to tell me I am the last one on the planet to know about these, but there has to be at least 1 or 2 others who haven‚Äôt, right? Lets just pretend there is and I promise try and stay more on top of the cool gear releases. Have you by chance heard of the Go-Anywhere Chairs? üí∫ They make some of the coolest shower and commode chairs that I think are Fabulous! Especially the Go-Anywhere Commode, Shower 'n Tub Chair that would help you convert any bathtub when you travel to being accessible (ok‚Ä¶ minus the missing support bars and wide doorways), But if you happen to only need to solve the shower and commode part when traveling, you really should check this out. Plus it even has a great little suitcase you can get to fold it into for travel; and don‚Äôt forget that almost all airlines will fly any of your needed medical/accessibility luggage for FREE. (check ahead because some airline ask you to inform them ahead of time of how many bags you will check and some just wait till you arrive at airport.) If you check out the webpage, you will notice they make several different designs based on what your needs might be; but it looks like they all will fold up into that same size travel bag üíº , which is amazing. Now I know the prices may look a little scary, but they do provide some links to ways to help with funding if your insurance does not cover it. However, they are a Canadian üá®üá¶ company and not all of the funding suggestions will be applicable if you don‚Äôt live there (but they don‚Äôt all say you have to be Canadian to apply either). There are lots of programs you can find online in the United States and other countries to help as well. If your insurance covers ‚ÄúDurable Medical Goods‚Äù, just make sure your doctor writes you a prescription that specifically lists the brand and model name of the chair you want on it; and that you specifically need that exact chair, no replacements. Then you usually submit the script to your insurance companies‚Äô durable goods office and they try and find a vendor they already use (3rd party), to order the chair for you. If they can‚Äôt find one their vendors who can buy it, they may tell you to just purchase and submit receipt for reimbursement. It sounds like a tedious process, but usually they have a time limit to try and find; so have faith. Follow up with them if its been a couple of weeks; they may have just forgotten to call you back. üì≤ Thank you everyone for listening to my pitch for the chairs üôè , I promise I won‚Äôt do this very often unless I see something that I truly believe would making travel easier for everyone. You know me, I just want everyone to get out and see the world; even if it takes a bit of extra effort to travel. Please‚Ä¶if anyone has any of the chairs from this company, share with us on the forum what you think and how/if they made your travel any easier?Or if you also know of good travel shower-commode chairs, tell us all what worked best for you? Keep on traveling everyone; It‚Äôs our world too! ‚ôø üåé Pinky üòò

Hi everyone, Wanted you guys to be the first to know some fun news: NEXT WEEK we will be hosting a live Q&A between accessibleGO & Paralympic athlete + world traveler Andrew Kurka. This Q&A will be entirely online and easily accessible through your computer or phone. It will last about 45 mins. We have heard from a lot of you that you love adventures and travel (that‚Äôs what brings us all here!), and there is probably nobody who knows both things better than Andrew Kurka! He‚Äôs traveled all over the world and competed in the Paralympics, winning 13 medals in international competitions and currently ranked the #1 sit skier in the world. At the end of the day, though, even with all he‚Äôs accomplished, Andrew is just somebody who loves to travel and does so with accessibility needs - just like so many of the rest of us in this forum. Please join us for what‚Äôs sure to be an amazing, insightful, and ultra-helpful conversation with the wonderful Andrew Kurka. WHAT: Online Q&A on Adventure & Accessibility with Andrew Kurka DATE: Thu, Jul 27 2023 TIME: 04:00 PM PST / 07:00 PM EST RSVP here: https://community.accessiblego.com/c/community-calendar/andrew-kurka-live You can read more about Andrew on the accessibleGO blog or by watching the video he made with us here .

From our experience, handicap hotel rooms are anything but. Bathroom Sink counter is at chin level when in a wheelchair, toilet seats are too low. Need to have bars on both sides that can be brought down from wall behind if needed to adjust or stand and transfer, my sister took pictures of bathrooms in Mexico that have the.. The bar on the wall next to the toilet is too high when the toilet is low. Shower wand is positioned so high very hard to reach w/o falling out of the shower chair. Beds are too high to get into. My husband has to lift me up into the bed. we take my own grab bar that fits under the mattress which allows me to actually move in the bed some. There are so many unaccessible things for a disabled person that are supposed to help but don‚Äôt, which I could go on & on about different things. I would love to be on a committee that designs ADA rooms & restrooms for hotels, restaurants etc.

After several years of being bound to a mechanical(mech.) wheelchair(wc), we finally had the means to drive to NYC. We were excited to finally make it to NYC. I use to live in NYC before having to use a mech. wc, pre-2001. I am familiar with the area. We had no experience staying, asking or knowing what exactly is a mobility accessible room. I started looking for hotels in the beginning of this year for an April trip. After months researching, searching, booking, and reserving, I learned that:-a room‚Äôs square footage is important in my case but in NYC, unless you have the means, the square footage can be limited.-not every accessible room is really accessible. That is difficult to know but the square footage can be a guideline.-third party apps. & hotel chains‚Äô 1 800 customer service #s for an accessible room can be dicey. Its best to communicate with the property.-it‚Äôs almost impossible to find any type of parking for an accessible van.-there is a disconnection for the room needed between hotel chains, properties & third party apps. When problems arise, it can become a frustrating, headache, a kind of pass the hot potato between those three. After months of searching, researching, & reserving for an accessible mobility room, we found the perfect place. For the room we needed, the price, the customer service from the property, we stayed in Hilton Brooklyn in downtown Brooklyn with close to 500 square feet of hotel room.The excellent customer service, a shout out to Isabela, & the square footage is what sold us.The bathroom was spotless & I was able to move around the room with my chair easily.Bartender was friendly and received great customer service.We had breakfast there. I was impressed at the quality of the meal.The room is quiet. You cant hear the traffic or the next room. It‚Äôs easy to get to some of the best beer in NYC.The hotel is walking distance to Juniors, DUMBO, & other must go places.The city‚Äôs bus drivers are friendly, and accommodate nicely. It‚Äôs easy to get the ferry & head to other boroughs. The subways are not useful for mechanical wheelchair users. If you do your homework before going, you can get discounted mass transportation & free rides for your PCA. If you go the extra mile, if need be, you can apply for a NYC visitor‚Äôs parking permit which can be very beneficial. Managing the chair‚Äôs charge is important. I learned to carry mine & charge it. Good Luck! JG

Worst Experience COPA AIRLINES Que pena he viajado en varias aerol√≠neas incluso en la misma COPA ha existido comprensi√≥n y empat√≠a para las discapacidades Pero en este vuelo 137 de M√©xico a Panam√° piloteado por el capitan : Ernesto Macoleta quien desconoce la ley La jefe de cabina Stephani P√©rez y el jefe de piso Cristian Salinas se confabularon de puro capricho a no dejarme subir mi scooter que se hace maleta a poner en el closet Pese a mostrar la ley de las regulaciones federales 382.67 en donde se obliga a la aereolinea a dar las facilidades para llevar mi modo de movilidad arriba Hago esta denuncia para que ning√∫n otra persona con discapacidad sufra este trato. El desconocer la ley no les exime de realizar lo correcto El tramo Panam√° Quito otra historia excelente atenci√≥n y mi scooter vino en el closet sin problema. Fue MALA FE de estos tres Malos funcionarios sin CONCIENCIA SOCIAL los que me da√±aron parte del viaje Ojal√° llegue este post a las autoridades de COPA QUE PENA ESTO, EL MUNDO DA VUELTAS Google translate: What a shame. I've flown on several airlines, even COPA itself, and there has been understanding and empathy for people with disabilities. But on this flight 137 from Mexico to Panama, piloted by Captain Ernesto Macoleta, who ignores the law. Cabin Chief Stephani P√©rez and Floor Chief Cristian Salinas colluded on a whim to not let me board my scooter, which I pack into a suitcase and put in the closet. Despite showing the law, Federal Regulations 382.67 require the airline to provide the facilities to bring my mobility device on board. I'm making this complaint so that no other person with a disability suffers this treatment. Ignorance of the law does not excuse them from doing the right thing. The Panama-Quito leg was another story: excellent service, and my scooter came in the closet without any problem. It was BAD FAITH on the part of these three corrupt officials with no social conscience who ruined part of my trip. I hope this post reaches the COPA authorities. HOW SHAME THIS IS, THE WORLD IS SPINNING.

Question from community member Laurel: My husband is paraplegic, and cannot stand. His dream is to swim with the sharks‚Ä¶I know! His dream, not mine!! There has to be a way‚Ä¶someplace that has a shark cage with a bottom?

I would like to report on the Ayres Hotel at Seal Beach in the Los Angeles area. The accessible room is simply awesome. Firstly, to get into the room you have an automatic door opener which is amazing, and I haven‚Äôt seen another hotel that has this The room is large and in one incident I stayed in a wheelchair accessible room however you could hardly get the wheelchair between the beds it was so tight. In this room I had lots of room between the beds for me to move about. They have an extremely nice bathroom which is very large and featured an exceptionally good shower and shower bench to sit on while showering. I also really liked the way they had a raised toilet seat because they just had these little risers‚Äô underneath that raise the seat that wasn't big and bulky for raising the whole thing. They had a nice breakfast room for breakfast with hot and cold food. The chef was there to prepare hot food. You could sit inside or in an outdoor courtyard. I did not make use of it on my visit, but they do have an outdoor pool which has an apparatus that will lower you into the pool as well as the outdoor hot tub. The staff were extremely friendly and kind and helpful to me in my wheelchair. All in all we had a very good three days in Los Angeles.

My wife and I just got back from an eight day Utah adventure (a full post on the whole trip to follow) where we toured the ‚ÄúBig Five‚Äù national parks (Zion, Bryce Canyon, Capitol Reef, Arches and Canyonlands). The cool little town of Moab is where we based ourselves while visiting Arches and Canyonlands and is also pretty famous for its back country scenery. We were super lucky to find a tour company that could accommodate a wheelchair user like myself. Its called Big Iron Tours And the owner Mike has outfitted one of his vehicles with a lift so wheelchair users can hop on board and take part. Here are a couple of pictures. The list is located in the back and once you get on you do have to transfer to a seat in order to be strapped in securely. If you are a power chair user who has difficulty transferring I would check to see if he has any way to secure you in while staying in your chair. If you are ever in the Moab area (Southeastern Utah) and want the thrill of a lifetime check him out.

I know others have asked about travel scooters previously but looking for a few more suggestions or personal experiences, if possible. I have had several travel scooters over the years. Previously I always had ones with four wheels and it didn‚Äôt matter how much it weighed as much because I was married and my ex husband would typically be there on long trips. I am now a single mom and while my kids are getting stronger they aren‚Äôt always with me when I go on trips and I have to rely on others for help. In the past year my newest scooter, which only has three wheels, and is much lighter, has allowed me to travel easier and get around in hotel rooms a bit better as well. The issue I am having is that it has tipped over with me on it 3 or 4 times in the last year with me on it. It always tips to the left right onto my leg that is amputated and left hip. I‚Äôm so scared that I will end up breaking something like my hip if it keeps happening. I‚Äôm about 150 lbs so should be under the weight capacity. It has happened when going from a sidewalk to the grass, grass to sidewalk, going up a hill and on a bumpy lawn leaving a barn wedding. I try to not let my disability keep me from trying to go places but now I get really anxious anytime there isn‚Äôt a paved even path. Anyone have suggestions?

I am 68 and my wife is 65, both disabled without mobility issues. We attempt to stay in shape and use the stairs whenever we are on the ship. Two of our last cruises were on Koningsdam (24 days) and Rotterdam (16 days). We found the cruisers that acted the most entitled and rude on the ship to be those with scooters. They parked them where ever they wanted, near stairs, elevators, in the hall way outside of their cabins. Even saw some parked in front of automatic fire doors. I complained to the guest services, the hotel manager and even the captain. Since none of them took action I wrote certified letters to the President of Holland America, CEO of Carnival and the Chairman of the Board stating that the crew of their vessels were not enforcing the corporate policy or U.S. Coast Guard policy in regard to mobility devices. In the event of a serious emergency these devices and the people that require them are a safety hazard to the rest of the passengers. I received a letter back from the President of Holland America. He stated that they took safety very serious and that they would start enforcing the corporate policy. He went on to say they had a team of 16 people that would go around and help those who used mobility devices in an emergency. Think about it, there are far more folks using mobility devices on Holland America cruise ships than the 16 crew members would be able to help. If a person is so disabled they can't help themselves and pose a risk to other passenger or the crew they should stay home. I will get a lot of flak from people, but if you think about it I am correct on this subject.
